cases.name: Tweddle v Atkinson [1861] EWHC QB J57
cases.summary:
Facts
• Tweddle v Atkinson [1861] EWHC QB J57 is a foundational English contract law case that established the doctrine of privity of contract.
• The case involved an agreement made between the fathers of a couple who were to be married.
• The fathers promised each other that they would both make payment to the son-in-law, Tweddle, after the marriage.
• One of the fathers, Atkinson, failed to make the promised payment.
• The issue arose when Tweddle sued Atkinson for breach of contract after the death of both fathers.

Issues
• Tweddle argued that he was a party to the contract and was entitled to enforce the payment promise made by Atkinson.
• Atkinson argued that Tweddle was not a party to the contract between the fathers and therefore had no standing to sue for its enforcement.
• The case turned on whether Tweddle was entitled to enforce the promised payment as a third party to the contract.

Decision
• The English High Court held that Tweddle could not enforce the payment promise made by Atkinson.
• The court established the principle of privity of contract, which stipulates that only parties to a contract can enforce its terms or be subject to its liabilities.
• Tweddle, as a third party to the contract between the fathers, had no standing to sue for enforcement.

Key passage(s)
• 'Privity of contract is established in this case: for the consideration moved wholly between the fathers of the plaintiff and defendant, and the plaintiff cannot sue.' (Wightman J)'
• '...it is quite clear that no stranger can take advantage of a contract, although made for his benefit; for such a stranger, being neither privy to the act nor to the contract, no consideration proceeds from him to the contracting parties, and he is therefore totally incapable of suing upon it.' (Crompton J)

cases.name: Williams v Roffey Bros & Nicholls (Contractors) Ltd [1991] 1 QB 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Williams v Roffey Bros & Nicholls (Contractors) Ltd [1991] 1 QB 1, the defendants were building contractors.
• They subcontracted some carpentry work to the plaintiff, Mr. Williams, for a fixed price.
• The original contract was poorly estimated by Mr. Williams causing financial difficulties leading him to request an additional payment for each flat.
• Roffey Bros agreed to pay Williams the additional amount as they were keen to avoid the potentially costly delays of finding a new subcontractor.
• However, Roffey Bros did not pay the additional amount after Williams had completed several flats.
• Williams ceased work and claimed the additional payment.

Issues
• The main legal issue was whether the agreement to pay more constituted an enforceable contract given Williams' promise to complete work he was already contractually bound to complete.
• Roffey Bros argued that the promise of additional payment was not legally binding as the plaintiff provided no extra consideration for this promise and was merely performing an existing contractual duty.
• Williams contended that his performance of the existing duty constituted valid consideration for Roffey Bros' promise.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal upheld Williams' claim and found the promise of additional payment to be enforceable.
• Their decision was based on the practical benefit doctrine, which was originated in the case of Stilk v Myrick (1809) 2 Camp 317, where a party could provide valid consideration by conferring some practical benefit upon the promisor.
• The court found that Roffey Bros had derived a practical benefit from the promise of additional payment, as it avoided the delays and likely termination of the original contract if Williams had not continued the work.

Key passage(s)
• 'The consideration to support the promise by one party is...the conferring of a practical benefit on that party, or of a detriment to the other' (Glidewell LJ).
• 'In my judgment, that obligation is capable of being good consideration. The fact that the promisor can call for it as of right is neither here nor there' (Glidewell LJ).

cases.name: Foakes v Beer [1884] UKHL 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• Dr. Foakes owed Mrs. Beer a sum of money arising from a judgment debt and court costs.
• They reached an agreement in which Mrs. Beer accepted Dr. Foakes' undertaking to pay the debt by instalments.
• In return, Mrs. Beer agreed not to take any further action to enforce the debt and not to seek any interest on the debt.
• Upon Dr. Foakes paying the sum, Mrs. Beer claimed interest was still owed under the judgment and brought an action to recover it.

Issues
• Dr. Foakes argued that the earlier agreement constituted a binding contract, which barred Mrs. Beer from claiming interest.
• Mrs. Beer argued that the principle in Pinnel's Case (1602) applied, which states that part-payment of a debt does not discharge the whole debt unless there is some fresh consideration for the agreement.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the agreement was not binding as there was no consideration provided by Dr. Foakes.
• Since Dr. Foakes was only paying his existing legal obligation, the principle in Pinnel's Case applied, and Mrs. Beer was entitled to claim the unpaid interest.

Key passage(s)
• 'Now if there is one proposition which has more firmly been established than any other, it is that an agreement to accept a sum of money in satisfaction of an existing debt is not binding unless it is an accord and satisfaction,...' (Lord Blackburn)
• 'There being no novation (new obligation) of the original obligation it follows that the original obligation continues to hold the creditor not with standing his agreement not to sue, and that agreement not being binding on him, he has the original right of action fully and completely.' (Lord Fitzgerald)

cases.name: Hadley v Baxendale [1854] EWHC J70
cases.summary:
Facts
• Hadley, the owner of a flour mill, had to shut down operations when the mill's crankshaft broke.
• He entered into a contract with Baxendale, a carrier, to transport the broken crankshaft to the manufacturer to create a replacement.
• Baxendale failed to deliver the crankshaft on the agreed date, causing Hadley to suffer additional financial losses due to the further delay in reopening the mill.
• Hadley sued Baxendale for these losses.

Issues
• Hadley argued that Baxendale was liable for all losses caused by the late delivery.
• Baxendale countered that he was not liable for losses he could not have reasonably foreseen at the time of entering the contract.

Decision
• The English court held that Baxendale was not liable for the losses suffered by Hadley because the damages were not within the 'reasonable contemplation' of the parties at the time the contract was made.
• The court established a rule for determining the extent of liability for breach of contract, known as the 'Hadley rule'.
• Under the Hadley rule, damages resulting from a breach of contract are only recoverable if they were reasonably foreseeable by both parties when entering into the contract, or if they arise naturally from the breach itself.

Key passage(s)
• 'Where two parties have made a contract which one of them has broken, the damages which the other party ought to receive in respect of such breach of contract should be such as may fairly and reasonably be considered either arising naturally, (...) or such as may reasonably be supposed to have been in the contemplation of both parties, at the time they made the contract, as the probable result of the breach of it.' (Alderson, B.)

cases.name: Penn v Lord Baltimore (1750) 1 Ves Sen 444
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case of Penn v Lord Baltimore (1750) involved a territorial dispute between the Penn family, proprietors of Pennsylvania, and Lord Baltimore of Maryland in Colonial America.
• In 1681, King Charles II granted a piece of land to the Penn family, later to become the Pennsylvania colony.
• In 1632, King Charles I granted land to Lord Baltimore, which became Maryland.
• The exact boundary between Pennsylvania and Maryland was not clearly defined, leading to territorial disputes between the Penn family and Lord Baltimore.
• In 1732, both parties entered into an agreement (the Articles of Agreement) setting the boundaries of their respective territories, but disputes continued.

Issues
• In 1750, the Penn family brought suit against Lord Baltimore in the English Court of Chancery, asking the court to enforce the 1732 agreement setting the boundaries, and to grant an injunction against Lord Baltimore.
• The Penn family argued that the Articles of Agreement were binding and should be enforced by the court, as they were the result of negotiations conducted by both parties.
• Lord Baltimore contended that the agreement was not binding because there was no enabling clause, no consideration, and that the agreement was not sufficiently specific.

Decision
• The Court of Chancery held that the 1732 agreement was binding and equitable, and should be enforced.
• The court granted an injunction against Lord Baltimore, preventing him from asserting any territorial claim beyond the agreed-upon boundary.
• The boundary line between the two colonies was ultimately determined by two surveyors, Charles Mason and Jeremiah Dixon, resulting in the Mason-Dixon Line.

Key passage(s)
• 'Equity, in this Instance, by Virtue of the Common Agreement and Consent of the Parties, took place of the Constellation of a Jury, and of an enabling Act of Parliament; and by the united Consent of the Parties, deriv'd a Jurisdiction in the Case, from the equitably adjusting the Boundary by them agreed on.' (Lord Hardwicke)

cases.name: Tulk v Moxhay [1848] EWHC Ch J34
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Tulk v Moxhay [1848] EWHC Ch J34, the claimant (Tulk) sold a piece of land to the defendant (Moxhay).
• The land included Leicester square gardens, which was subject to a covenant that restricted the use of the land to maintaining the gardens for the pleasure of the residents in the area (with no buildings or other use allowed).
• The covenant was included in the conveyance deed of the land.
• Some years later, Moxhay sold the land to another purchaser, wherein the covenant was not contained in the conveyance.
• This new purchaser then sold the land to another person (M to D), where the conveyance once again did not contain the covenant.
• Eventually, Moxhay sought to build on the land, which led Tulk to object and seek the enforcement of the covenant.

Issues
• The issue before the court was whether equity will enforce a restrictive covenant against a subsequent purchaser of the land who is on actual or constructive notice of the covenant, despite the covenant not being included in the conveyance.
• Tulk argued that the covenant should be enforceable against Moxhay because the court could infer that subsequent purchasers of the land would be bound by the covenant.
• Moxhay argued that the covenant should not be enforceable because restrictive covenants should not bind subsequent purchasers unless they had direct notice of the covenant, which Moxhay claimed he did not have.

Decision
• The court decided in favor of Tulk, holding that equity will enforce a restrictive covenant against subsequent purchasers of the land if they are on actual or constructive notice of the covenant, even if the covenant was not included in the conveyance of the land.
• The court reasoned that the covenant continued to run with the land, and was therefore enforceable against Moxhay, since he was on constructive notice of the covenant.
• The decision established the principle of notice, which asserts that subsequent purchasers of land are bound by any covenant on the land they are on notice of.

Key passage(s)
• 'If a party purchasing has notice that another person is entitled to a covenant over the land, and he purchases with that knowledge and without sufficient notice, and in the absence of circumstances which would not make him subject to the burden if he knew it, then a person not having actual notice is bound by the same rule.' (Lord Cottenham LC)
• 'A man shall not be allowed to purchase parcels of land charged with a common burden, and sell part of such parcels without the burden, and apply the purchase money to his own use.' (Lord Cottenham LC)
• 'I agree that he (M) was bound to know the release, and being so, he must abide by the common principle of this Court, that a man cannot protect himself by neglecting to know that which he is bound to know.' (Lord Cottenham LC)

cases.name: Errington v Errington & Woods [1952] 1 KB 290
cases.summary:
Facts
• A father, the defendant, purchased a house for his daughter and son-in-law, who made mortgage repayments directly to the building society.
• The defendant orally promised to transfer the property to them once the mortgage had been paid.
• The marriage ended, and the son-in-law stopped making payments.
• The defendant took possession of the house and refused to transfer the property to his daughter or son-in-law.
• The daughter claimed she had a right to the beneficial ownership of the property.

Issues
• The claimant argued that there was an implied trust that benefits the daughter and son-in-law upon fulfillment of the oral condition.
• The defendant argued that the house was a gift to the couple (inter vivos), conditional upon payment of the mortgage.
• The defendant claimed the gift was incomplete since the condition had not been met, and thus the trust was invalid.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that an implied trust existed in favour of the daughter and son-in-law.
• The father could not revoke the trust once they had started to make the mortgage payments.
•The trust was not invalidated on the grounds of an unmet condition.

Key passage(s)
• 'There is no doubt that, if the property were freehold property, and the father did what he did and said what he said, the property would then have been impressed with a trust in favour of the daughter and her husband on their paying off the mortgage.' - Lord Justice Denning
• 'Equity regards the transaction as binding on the donee from the moment that he commences to act upon it by making purchases in the joint names.' - Lord Justice Romer

cases.name: Walsh v Lonsdale (1882) 21 Ch D 9
cases.summary:
Facts
• Walsh entered into an agreement to let a warehouse from Lonsdale.
• The agreement was made prior to the lease being executed in writing.
• Lonsdale sought to terminate the agreement on the grounds of non-payment of rent and arrears.
• Walsh claimed he was entitled to continue the occupation of the warehouse due to the agreement.

Issues
• Whether the prior agreement to let the warehouse was sufficient to create a legal right for Walsh to continue to occupy the property.
• Whether Lonsdale had the right to terminate the agreement on the grounds of non-payment of rent and arrears.
• Walsh argued that the rights and obligations in an equitable lease should be specifically enforced and the occupant should enjoy full ownership.
• Lonsdale contended that Walsh's rights were insufficient to prevent the termination of the agreement as there was no legal lease.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that Walsh's equitable lease was effectively the same as a legal lease due to the Maxims of Equity that dictated equity follows the law.
• Hence, Lonsdale was not permitted to terminate the agreement on the grounds of non-payment.
• The decision in this case established the principle that equity will enforce legal obligations (specific performance) even though they have yet to be formalised in writing.

Key passage(s)
• 'The moment you have a valid contract for sale [or lease] the vendor [or lessor] becomes in equity a trustee for the purchaser [or tenant] of the estate sold...he acquires equitable rights of property and those equitable rights attach to the land itself' (Thesiger LJ)

cases.name: Re Rose [1952] EWCA Civ 4
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Re Rose [1952] EWCA Civ 4, Mr. Rose transferred shares he owned in a family company to three trustees for the benefit of his wife and daughter.
• The transfer was not immediate and was only completed several months later when the share certificates and transfer forms were handed over to the trustees.
• Mr. Rose died in the meantime, and his executors argued that the gift was incomplete and therefore the shares formed part of his estate for tax purposes (Estate Duty).

Issues
• The main issue debated was whether Mr. Rose had done everything in his power to transfer the shares, thus constituting a complete gift in terms of equity.
• The executors argued that Mr. Rose's actions were not enough to complete the gift, while the trustees maintained that the gift was complete as Mr. Rose had done everything he could to effect the transfer of the shares.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the gift was complete, as Mr. Rose had done everything in his power to make the transfer.
• The court relied on the principles established in Milroy v Lord (1862) as well as Mascall v Mascall (1886) in reaching its decision. These cases emphasized that in order for an equity to recognize a completed gift, the donor must have done all in his power to transfer the property.
• The court further held that Mr. Rose's actions to transfer the shares had removed them from his estate, therefore reducing the Estate Duty payable.

Key passage(s)
• 'If the donor has done all that is necessary to be done by him to effect a change of legal title and has put it in the power of his transferee to effect such change of title, then it is a question of intent whether the gift is complete.' (Lord Evershed MR)

cases.name: Lloyds Bank v Rosset [1991] 1 AC 107
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Mr. Rosset, purchased a house in joint names with his wife using funds borrowed from the respondent, Lloyds Bank.
• Mrs. Rosset spent considerable time and money renovating the property, believing that this would give her a beneficial interest in the property.
• When Mr. Rosset defaulted on the loan, Lloyds Bank sought to repossess the property, claiming that Mrs. Rosset had no beneficial interest in it.

Issues
• Lloyds Bank argued that Mrs. Rosset did not have a beneficial interest in the property because there was no express agreement between the parties, and her contributions did not amount to a constructive trust.
• Mrs. Rosset contended that she had a beneficial interest in the property under a constructive trust due to her direct financial and labor contributions.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Mrs. Rosset did not have a beneficial interest in the property.
• There was no evidence of an express agreement between the parties, and her contributions did not amount to a constructive trust as they were not directly related to the initial acquisition of the property.
• Consequently, Lloyds Bank was entitled to repossess the property.

Key passage(s)
• 'There can be no doubt that many circumstances can easily be imagined where in equity, conscience decrees that one person has acquired an interest in property, even though he does not hold the legal title in one or other of the several forms of equitable interest.': Lord Bridge
• 'The first and fundamental question which must always be resolved is whether, independently of any inference to be drawn from the conduct of the parties in the course of sharing the house as their home and managing their joint affairs, there has at any time prior to acquisition, or exceptionally at some later date, been any agreement, arrangement, or understanding reached between them that the property is to be shared beneficially.': Lord Bridge

cases.name: Factortame Ltd v Secretary of State for Transport (No 2) [1991] 1 AC 603
cases.summary:
Facts
• In the 1980s, a number of Spanish fishing companies, including Factortame Ltd, registered their vessels in the UK to take advantage of the British fishing quotas.
• In response, the UK government enacted the Merchant Shipping Act 1988 and created the Merchant Shipping (Registration of Fishing Vessels) Regulations 1988.
• The Act required companies owning fishing vessels to be 75% British-owned, effectively excluding Factortame Ltd and other Spanish companies.
• Factortame Ltd sought judicial review, claiming the Act breached their rights under European Community (EC) law, specifically under the Treaty of the European Economic Community (EEC).

Issues
• Factortame Ltd argued that the UK's Merchant Shipping Act and the Regulations were inconsistent with their rights of freedom of establishment and non-discrimination provided under Articles 52 and 221 of the Treaty of the EEC.
• The Secretary of State for Transport argued that the Act and the Regulations were valid and necessary to preserve the UK's fishing industry and protect resources.
• A key issue was whether UK courts had the power to disapply UK legislation that conflicted with EC law.

Decision
• The House of Lords held in favour of Factortame Ltd, ruling that UK courts have the power to disapply UK legislation that conflicts with EC law.
• This case reaffirmed the decision in R v Secretary of State for Employment, ex parte Equal Opportunities Commission [1994] 1 AC 1, which established that EC law has direct effect and supremacy over domestic laws.

Key passage(s)
• 'As a matter of the constitutional law of the United Kingdom, the doctrine of the supremacy of Parliament, the Crown, and the courts in defining their respective jurisdictions, the courts have by virtue of section 3 of the [European Communities] Act been entrusted with jurisdiction at the suit of a subject to override national legislation on the ground that it is inconsistent with Community law.' (Lord Bridge)
• 'Thus far at any rate, a principle of Community law is enforceable by action in the English courts by persons who can establish that such is necessary for the protection of their rights under Community law.' (Lord Goff)

cases.name: R v Secretary of State for Transport, ex p Factortame (No 5) [2000] 1 AC 524
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Factortame case involved a group of Spanish vessel owners (Factortame Ltd) who challenged the UK legislation (the Merchant Shipping Act 1988) that required UK fishing vessels to have a majority of British-owned shares to be registered.
• Factortame argued that this legislation violated EU law, specifically the principle of non-discrimination based on nationality.
• In previous rulings, Factortame had established this claim, and the UK had been required to pay damages.
• In this fifth and final stage, the focus was on calculating the compensation owed to Factortame.

Issues
• The key issue was how to calculate the compensation owed by the UK government to Factortame, and whether gross or net lost profits should be used in these calculations.
• Factortame argued for the use of gross lost profits, while the UK government countered that net lost profits should be used, reducing the compensation amount.
• Additionally, the UK government argued that the damages should be apportioned based on the percentage of factortame shareholders who were unlawfully discriminated against.

Decision
• The House of Lords held in favour of Factortame, deciding that gross lost profits should be used in the calculations of damages.
• The court rejected the UK government's proposed approach to apportion damages and found the whole Act incompatible with EU law.
• Consequently, the damages were not reduced by the percentage of unlawfully discriminated shareholders.

Key passage(s)
• 'The right to compensation does not arise from the directive [EU law] itself. It arises from the domestic law which has been found to be incompatible with the directive.' (Lord Slynn of Hadley)
• 'By selecting a business which they knew could not lawfully be carried on they brought the losses on to themselves.' (Lord Hope)

cases.name: Van Gend en Loos v Nederlandse Administratie der Belastingen [1963] ECR 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• Van Gend en Loos (VGL), a Dutch transport company, imported chemicals from Germany into the Netherlands.
• The Dutch government increased its customs duties on the imported chemicals, which VGL challenged as violating the European Economic Community (EEC) Treaty.
• VGL argued that the increase was unlawful under Article 12 of the Treaty.
• The legal dispute was referred to the European Court of Justice (ECJ) for a preliminary ruling.

Issues
• The key question was whether VGL could rely on Article 12 and claim damages from the Dutch government for unlawfully increased duties.
• VGL argued that the Treaty had created fundamental rights, which could be relied upon by individuals.
• The Dutch government argued that the Treaty provisions could only impose obligations on Member States and not give rights to individuals.

Decision
• The ECJ held that certain provisions of the Treaty could create rights for individuals, which national courts must protect.
• The ECJ introduced the concept of 'direct effect,' meaning that individuals could rely on Treaty provisions in national courts if the provisions met certain conditions.
• The ECJ found that Article 12 met these conditions and thus had direct effect.
• VGL was entitled to rely on Article 12 and claim damages from the Dutch government for unlawfully increased duties.

Key passage(s)
• 'The Community constitutes a new legal order of international law...the subjects of which comprise not only Member States but also their nationals...The transfer by the States from their domestic legal system to the Community legal system of the rights and obligations arising under the Treaty carries with it a permanent limitation of their sovereign rights.' (Judge Robert Lecourt)
• 'The objective of the EEC Treaty, which is to establish a common market...implies that this Treaty is more than an agreement which merely creates mutual obligations between the contracting States.' (Judge Robert Lecourt)
• 'In view of the foregoing considerations, the answer to the question submitted to the Court must be that the provisions of Article 12 of the EEC Treaty are unconditional and are not qualified by any reservations and have, in the framework of the Treaty as a whole, a similar character to the provisions of national law.' (Judge Robert Lecourt)

cases.name: Costa v ENEL [1964] ECR 585
cases.summary:
Facts
• Costa, an Italian citizen and shareholder in Edison, an electricity company, sued ENEL (Ente Nazionale Energia Elettrica) after the Italian government amalgamated electricity production in Italy and bought majority shares of Edison.
• Costa claimed that this was a breach of the Treaty of Rome, which established the European Economic Community (EEC), and sought relief through the Italian courts.

Issues
• Can Italian national law undermine the application of EEC law?
• Costa argued that the measures taken by Italy violated the Treaty of Rome, while ENEL and the Italian government contended that national law could still apply despite the Treaty.

Decision
• The European Court of Justice (ECJ) held in favor of Costa, finding that the Treaty of Rome takes precedence over Italian national law.
• The ECJ stated that to allow national law to undermine EEC law would undermine the very purpose and effectiveness of the Treaty.

Key passage(s)
• 'By contrast with ordinary international treaties, the EEC Treaty has created its own legal system which, on the entry into force of the Treaty, became an integral part of the legal systems of the Member States and which their courts are bound to apply.' - (Court of Justice)
• 'The executive force of Community law cannot vary from one state to another... without jeopardizing the attainment of the objectives of the Treaty.' - (Court of Justice)

cases.name: Marleasing SA v La Comercial Internacional de Alimentacion SA [1990] ECR I-4135
cases.summary:
Facts
• Marleasing SA (plaintiff) brought an action against La Comercial Internacional de Alimentacion SA (CISA, defendant) for non-performance of an exclusive agency contract.
• CISA relied on a provision in a national law that allowed unilateral termination of agency contracts.
• Marleasing claimed that the national law was incompatible with European Union (EU) law, specifically the Council Directive 86/653/EEC on the harmonization of the laws of the Member States relating to self-employed commercial agents.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the national law allowing unilateral termination of contracts was compatible with the EU directive on self-employed commercial agents.
• Marleasing argued that the national law was contrary to the directive and should not be applied to the case.
• CISA argued that the directive had not yet been implemented in national law, and therefore was not applicable to the case.

Decision
• The European Court of Justice (ECJ) held that the national law should be interpreted in light of the directive, even if it had not yet been implemented in national law.
• The ECJ followed the principle established in cases like Von Colson and Kamann v Land Nordrhein-Westfalen (80/87), where it was held that national courts must interpret domestic law in line with the objectives of EU directives.
• As a result, the ECJ found that the national law could not be relied upon for unilateral termination of contracts, and thus ruled in favor of Marleasing.

Key passage(s)
• 'In applying national law, whether the provisions in question were adopted before or after the Directive, the national court called upon to interpret it is required to do so, as far as possible, in the light of the wording and the purpose of the Directive in order to achieve the result pursued by the latter.' (Judge Cesare Grassi)

cases.name: Unibet (London) Ltd v Justitiekanslern [2007] ECR I-2271
cases.summary:
Facts
• Unibet, a Maltese registered online gambling company, was fined SEK 100 million by the Swedish National Gaming Board for providing gambling services in Sweden without a permit.
• Unibet requested to refer the Swedish Gaming Act to the ECJ (European Court of Justice) for a preliminary ruling on whether it was compatible with EU law, particularly the freedom to provide services under Article 49 EC (now Article 56 TFEU).
• The Swedish courts declined the request for a preliminary ruling, stating that Unibet could apply for a permit and contest the lawfulness of the Gaming Act at that stage.
• Unibet appealed to the ECJ.

Issues
• Unibet argued that a direct challenge to the Gaming Act was necessary, and the refusal of the Swedish courts to refer the question for a preliminary ruling violated its right to effective judicial protection under EU law.
• The Justitiekanslern (Swedish Chancellor of Justice) contended that the opportunity for Unibet to apply for a permit and contest the legality of the Gaming Act during that process was sufficient to comply with EU law.

Decision
• The ECJ agreed with Unibet that the exclusive right system for gambling services in Sweden was contrary to Article 49 EC, but did not declare the Gaming Act invalid.
• The ECJ ruled that the right to effective judicial protection does not require a complete disregard for national procedural rules, and upheld the Swedish courts' refusal to refer the preliminary ruling.

Key passage(s)
• '...the requirement relating to procedural conditions for actions must be subordinated to the principle of effective judicial protection.' (AG Maduro)
• 'National procedural law must be interpreted in such a way as to avoid, as far as possible, a conflict with EU law.' (AG Maduro)

cases.name: Thoburn v Sunderland City Council [2002] EWHC 195 (Admin)
cases.summary:
Facts
• Thoburn v Sunderland City Council (2002) concerned a greengrocer, Steven Thoburn, who was convicted for using imperial units (pounds and ounces) instead of metric units (kilograms) when selling fruit and vegetables.
• Thoburn challenged the validity of the Weights and Measures Act 1985, which required the use of metric units, arguing that it conflicted with the European Communities Act 1972 (ECA), thus creating a constitutional question for the courts.

Issues
• Thoburn argued that the Weights and Measures Act 1985 was impliedly repealed by the ECA since they were inconsistent.
• Sunderland City Council countered that the Weights and Measures Act 1985 was a later, more specific enactment, and thus the ECA could not have impliedly repealed it.

Decision
• Mr Justice Laws rejected Thoburn's argument and upheld his conviction.
• He held that the ECA was a 'constitutional statute' that had a special status, which means it could only be expressly repealed, not impliedly.
• He also held that the Weights and Measures Act 1985 was not inconsistent with the ECA but rather gave effect to it.
• The judgement created the 'Thoburn principles', which established that some statutes have a special constitutional status and cannot be impliedly repealed.

Key passage(s)
• 'Ordinary statutes may be impliedly repealed. Constitutional statutes may not…' (Mr Justice Laws)
• 'The ECA clearly is, by force of the common law, a constitutional statute…' (Mr Justice Laws)
• 'The 1985 [Weights and Measures] Act is a later enactment in a series by which Parliament has affirmed and re-affirmed the supremacy of Community law.' (Mr Justice Laws)

cases.name: Osman v United Kingdom [1998] ECHR 101
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Osman v United Kingdom, the applicants, a father and son, were targeted by a disturbed teacher, Paul Paget-Lewis.
• Paget-Lewis murdered a young boy and attacked the applicants, killing the father and severely injuring the son.
• The police had been aware of Paget-Lewis's obsession and received numerous warnings, but failed to take sufficient action to protect the applicants.
• The applicants brought a case against the United Kingdom (UK) under Article 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights (right to life), alleging the state breached its positive obligation to protect their lives.

Issues
• The applicants argued that the police's failure to act constituted a breach of Article 2 of the Convention.
• The UK government argued that police action must not be subject to scrutiny by the European Court of Human Rights, except in extreme circumstances where the police were acting in bad faith (following the Hill v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire [1989] case).

Decision
• The European Court of Human Rights held that the UK government's reliance on Hill v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire was misplaced, as it restricted the scope of Article 2 too narrowly.
• The Court held that a positive obligation to protect lives does exist under Article 2, which must be read in conjunction with Article 13 (right to an effective remedy).
• The Court found that the UK failed to provide a framework for addressing claims of police negligence or to allow for an effective remedy in such cases, thereby violating Article 13 in conjunction with Article 2. The Court did not find a separate violation of Article 2.

Key passage(s)
• 'Where there is an allegation that the authorities have violated their positive obligation to protect the right to life in the context of their above-mentioned duty to prevent and suppress offences against the person, it must be established to its satisfaction that the authorities knew or ought to have known at the time of the existence of a real and immediate risk to the life of an identified individual or individuals from the criminal acts of a third party and that they failed to take measures within the scope of their powers which, judged reasonably, might have been expected to avoid that risk' (Judge Akay).

cases.name: Douglas v Hello! Ltd [2001] EWCA Civ 595
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 2000, Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones entered into an exclusive agreement with OK! Magazine to publish photographs of their wedding.
• The couple took extensive measures to ensure privacy, including security and confidentiality agreements with guests and staff.
• Hello! Magazine, OK!'s competitor, obtained unauthorized photographs of the event and published them several days before OK! published their authorized version.
• The Douglases and OK! sought an injunction to restrain Hello! from further publishing and selling the unauthorized photographs.

Issues
• The Douglases argued that their right to privacy under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) had been breached.
• They also claimed a breach of confidence, asserting that the unauthorized photographs were taken and published in circumstances importing an obligation of confidence.
• Hello! contended that the Douglases had no reasonable expectation of privacy since they had already entered into a commercial agreement with OK! to publish the wedding photographs.
• Hello! also argued that an injunction would have a chilling effect on media freedom under Article 10 of the ECHR (freedom of expression).

Decision
• The Court of Appeal dismissed Hello!'s appeal and granted the injunction.
• It held that the Douglases had a reasonable expectation of privacy, despite entering a commercial agreement with OK!.
• The court also found that Hello! had breached an obligation of confidence by publishing the unauthorized photographs.
• The court balanced the rights under Articles 8 and 10 and determined that the interference with Hello!'s freedom of expression was permissible in this case.

Key passage(s)
• 'The fact that they were staged does not mean that the appellants were not invading the Douglases' privacy by publishing them. The mere fact that one person sees another in a particular situation does not destroy the privacy of the latter in relation to another person who was not also present.': (Sedley LJ)

cases.name: Hirst v United Kingdom (No 2) [2005] ECHR 681
cases.summary:
Facts
• Hirst v United Kingdom (No 2) [2005] ECHR 681 involved a challenge to the UK's blanket ban on prisoners voting in elections.
• The applicant, John Hirst, was a prisoner serving a life sentence for manslaughter.
• He argued that the ban, imposed by the Representation of the People Act 1983, violated his right to vote under Article 3 Protocol 1 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).

Issues
• The main issue was whether the blanket ban on prisoner voting was proportionate and within the UK's margin of appreciation under Article 3 Protocol 1.
• The UK government argued that the ban was necessary to ensure the proper functioning of parliamentary democracy and to maintain the link between the right to vote and the social contract between citizens and the state.
• Hirst contended that the ban was disproportionate and infringed his right under Article 3 Protocol 1, as it did not take into account the nature or gravity of his offence, the duration of his sentence, nor any individual circumstances.

Decision
• The European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) held by a majority that the blanket ban on prisoner voting violated Article 3 Protocol 1.
• The Court found that the ban was disproportionate, as it applied automatically to all convicted prisoners, regardless of their individual circumstances.
• Furthermore, the Court held that the UK had not adequately justified the ban, and that there was no international consensus on prisoner disenfranchisement.

Key passage(s)
• 'The question whether a general restriction on the right of convicted prisoners to vote can still be said to be proportionate and not discriminatory in the sense of Article 14 of the Convention has not yet been examined by the Court.' (Judge Loucaides)
• 'The automatic and indiscriminate restriction on a vitally important Convention right must be seen as falling outside any acceptable margin of appreciation, however wide that margin may be.' (Judge Costa)

cases.name: Pepper v Hart [1993] AC 593
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1976, a group of teachers at a UK public school (Hart) brought an action against the school's governors (Pepper) to recover salary arrears under their contracts of employment.
• Hart teachers claimed that the salaries were not paid according to scales that had been approved by the Minister for Education post-1972.
• The case later reached the House of Lords, where the primary question was whether parliamentary material, specifically the debate on a Finance Bill that affected the teachers, should be admissible as evidence to assist in interpreting ambiguous legislation.

Issues
• Hart argued that parliamentary debates can be used as an aid to interpreting ambiguous statutes, while Pepper argued that they should not be permitted under the principle of parliamentary sovereignty.
• Prior to this case, the court's reliance on parliamentary materials to interpret legislation was limited by rules of evidence and the doctrine of separation of powers.

Decision
• The House of Lords, by a majority, held that the rule excluding reference to legislative history as an aid to statutory construction should be relaxed.
• In cases where legislation is ambiguous or obscure or leads to an absurdity, the courts may refer to parliamentary materials to resolve the ambiguity, provided the statements relied upon are clear.

Key passage(s)
• 'Under English law the primary duty of the courts is to give effect to the intention of Parliament as expressed in the words enacted.' (Lord Browne-Wilkinson)
• '[R]eliance on ministerial statements may ... be a valuable aid in testing the potential effect of the various alternative meanings that are open on the plain wording of the statute.' (Lord Griffiths)
• 'It is better to have resort to a Parliamentary statement by a Minister when the circumstances justify than to ignore what Parliament meant and, in doing so, take the risk of giving effect to a meaning which Parliament did not intend.' (Lord Bridge)

cases.name: Balfour v Balfour [1919] 2 KB 571
cases.summary:
Facts
• Mr. and Mrs. Balfour, a married couple, entered into an agreement whereby Mr. Balfour agreed to pay his wife a monthly allowance while he was employed overseas.
• The relationship later broke down, resulting in Mrs. Balfour leaving for England.
• After the separation, Mr. Balfour stopped making the payments, prompting Mrs. Balfour to sue for breach of contract.

Issues
• The central question was whether a legally binding contract existed between the parties.
• Mrs. Balfour argued that the agreement amounted to a legally binding contract, enforceable in court.
• Mr. Balfour argued that the promise to pay was a domestic arrangement between spouses and, as a result, lacked the necessary legal intent to create a binding contract.

Decision
• The court agreed with Mr. Balfour, ruling that there was no legally binding contract.
• The court held that arrangements made between husband and wife lack the necessary intention to create legal relations and thus, do not amount to legally enforceable contracts.
• As a result, Mrs. Balfour's claim for breach of contract was dismissed.

Key passage(s)
• 'The matter really reduces itself to an absurdity when one considers it. If we were to hold that there was a contract in this case we should have to hold that with regard to all the more or less trivial concerns of life where a wife, at the request of her husband, makes a promise to him, that promise is a legally binding promise which can be enforced in law' (Atkin LJ).
• 'The small courts of this country would have to be multiplied one hundredfold if these arrangements were held to result in legal obligations enforceable in the courts' (Warrington LJ).

cases.name: Lloyds Bank v Bundy [1975] QB 326
cases.summary:
Facts
• Lloyds Bank (the bank) held a mortgage over the farm of Edward Bundy (Bundy).
• Bundy, due to financial hardship, became unable to make the required repayments on the mortgage.
• The bank pressured Bundy to provide additional security for the mortgage as a guarantee for a loan granted to his son's company.
• Bundy agreed and signed the guarantee under undue influence from the bank, without independent advice.
• The son's company defaulted, and the bank sought to enforce the guarantee against Bundy.

Issues
• Bundy argued that the guarantee was voidable due to the bank's undue influence and lack of independent advice.
• The bank argued that there was no undue influence and that Bundy voluntarily entered into the guarantee.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the guarantee was voidable due to the undue influence exerted by the bank upon Bundy.
• It was established that the bank owed a 'duty to advise' Bundy, which it failed to do, taking advantage of Bundy's vulnerable state.
• The court introduced the concept of 'inequality of bargaining power' as a basis for setting aside a contract.

Key passage(s)
• 'The case will depend on proof of the existence of a special relationship which, combined with improvidence of the transaction, required the exercise by the plaintiff (creditor) of the overriding duty to advise the defendant (debtor) in his own best interest.' - (Lord Denning MR)
• 'It starts with a relationship of trust and confidence which leads the one to assume that the other will act in his best interests... The creditor does not have a lien, but uses his power to ensure that the debtor enters into a transaction most improvident for the debtor.' - (Lord Denning MR)

cases.name: Sturges v Bridgman (1879) 11 Ch D 852
cases.summary:
Facts
• Sturges v Bridgman (1879) 11 Ch D 852 is a key English land law case that established the rule in the doctrine of coming to the nuisance.
• Dr. Sturges operated a medical practice in London's West End. To the rear of his premises, was a property owned by Bridgman, a confectioner.
• Bridgman installed a steam-powered mortar in a workshop on his premises; he used it to grind sugar for 26 years without any complaints.
• Dr. Sturges built a consultation room next to the workshop; noise and vibrations caused by the mortar interfered significantly with his practice.
• Dr. Sturges brought a claim for private nuisance against Bridgman.

Issues
• The main question was whether Bridgman was entitled to continue operating the mortar.
• Bridgman argued that 1) putting up with the noise was a reasonable thing to do; and that 2) the vibration complaints only arose because of the new construction.
• Dr. Sturges argued that the noise and vibrations caused by the mortar unreasonably interfered with his enjoyment of his property.

Decision
• The Court held in favour of Dr. Sturges, ordering Bridgman to abate the nuisance.
• Bridgman's long-term use of the mortar made the coming to the nuisance defence ineffective because the level of interference must be considered on the date that suit was brought forward.
• This case illustrates the limits of the coming to the nuisance defence: a right to continue performing an action cannot be acquired merely due to the passage of time.

Key passage(s)
• 'What would be a nuisance in Belgrave Square would not necessarily be so in Bermondsey.' (Thesiger LJ)
• 'It is an actionable interference with my enjoyment of the property to carry on a trade in the vicinity which involves, when I have built, a noise intolerable to inhabiters of an ordinary dwelling-house.' (Thesiger LJ)
• 'The property having been built under these circumstances, the nuisance is in my judgment just as much a nuisance as if no machinery had been there.' (Cotton LJ)

cases.name: Donoghue v Folkestone Properties [2003] EWCA Civ 231
cases.summary:
Facts
• Donoghue v Folkestone Properties [2003] EWCA Civ 231 concerned an occupiers' liability claim arising out of a personal injury.
• The claimant (Donoghue) dove into Folkestone harbour at night and struck his head on a submerged object, sustaining severe spinal injuries.
• The defendant (Folkestone Properties) was the owner and statutory undertaker of the harbour.

Issues
• The key issues were whether the defendant breached its duty under the Occupiers' Liability Act 1957 (OLA 1957) to 'take such care to ensure that the visitor will be reasonably safe in using the premises for the purpose for which he is invited'.
• The claimant argued that the defendant was in breach of its duty under OLA 1957, as they failed to ensure safety around the harbour.
• The defendant argued that the claimant's action was outside the scope of their invitation and hence outside the protection of the OLA 1957.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the defendant had not breached its duty under OLA 1957.
• The court found that the claimant's action of diving into the harbour at night was outside the scope of any implied permission given by the defendant and therefore not protected by the OLA 1957.
• Additionally, the court held that the defendant was not required to protect against the possibility of the claimant undertaking such an activity.

Key passage(s)
• 'There was no question of the dive being save for a most exceptional case. It [the claimant's dive] was an act not within any implied permission given by the second defendant [Folkestone Properties].' - (Lord Justice Ward)
• 'If there is no implied permission to do such a thing, there is no duty to alter the premises so that a person doing it will not suffer injury.' - (Lord Justice Ward)

cases.name: Hunter v Canary Wharf [1997] AC 655
cases.summary:
Facts
• In the case of Hunter v Canary Wharf [1997] AC 655, the claimants were residents in the docklands area of London.
• They alleged that the construction and existence of Canary Wharf Tower had caused various detriments to their enjoyment of their homes, including interference with television reception and an increase in dust particles.
• The claimants sought relief under the tort of private nuisance and invoked the rule in Rylands v Fletcher (tort of strict liability for damage caused by the escape of dangerous substances from a defendant's land).

Issues
• The main issues in this case were whether interference with television reception could amount to a private nuisance and whether the rule in Rylands v Fletcher could apply to the construction dust.
• The defendants argued that interference with television reception did not fall within the ambit of private nuisance, and the natural accumulation of dust did not constitute an 'escape' of a dangerous substance under Rylands v Fletcher.
• The claimants contended that both issues were actionable under the aforementioned legal principles.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that interference with television reception could not constitute a private nuisance.
• In reaching this decision, their Lordships cited the distinction between the right to the enjoyment of property and personal sensitivity, arguing that the latter is not protected in the context of private nuisance.
• Furthermore, the rule in Rylands v Fletcher did not apply, as the dust was naturally occurring and did not escape from the defendants' land in a dangerous or unpredictable manner.
• The claimants' case was dismissed.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is the right to enjoyment of the land ... that is protected by the law of private nuisance, not the right to enjoy television reception ...' Lord Hoffmann}
• 'The liability of the defendant depends upon whether the interference is reasonable because it does not trespass upon the claimant's right to the reasonable enjoyment of his property…' Lord Goff.

cases.name: Thornton v Shoe Lane Parking [1971] 2 QB 163
cases.summary:
Facts
• Thornton entered a car park owned by Shoe Lane Parking Ltd. (SLP).
• He obtained a ticket from an automatic machine near the entrance.
• The ticket contained a contractual term imposing a two-hour parking limit.
• A notice near the entrance also contained various terms and conditions, including a clause excluding SLP's liability for damage caused to a vehicle or the death of a driver while the vehicle was in the car park.
• Thornton was injured in the car park due to SLP's negligence.

Issues
• Was a contract formed between Thornton and SLP?
• If so, were the exclusionary terms incorporated into the contract?
• SLP argued that a contract was formed and the exclusionary terms applied.
• Thornton argued that the exclusionary terms were not incorporated into the contract because they were not brought to his attention.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that a contract was formed between Thornton and SLP.
• However, the exclusionary terms were not incorporated into the contract because they were not brought to Thornton's attention before he entered the car park.
• The decision was based on the reasoning in Chapelton v Barry UDC [1940] 1 KB 532, where it was held that an exclusion clause must be brought to the other party's attention before a contract is formed.

Key passage(s)
• 'In order to give sufficient notice it would need to be printed in red ink with a red hand pointing to it – or something equally startling.' (Lord Denning MR)
• 'The customer is bound by the notice if it is so placed that he ought in all reason to have seen it.' (Edmund-Davies LJ)

cases.name: R v Collins [1973] QB 100
cases.summary:
Facts
• Collins was charged with burglary with intent to commit rape, under section 9 of the Theft Act 1968, after he climbed a ladder and entered a girl's bedroom through an open window.
• The girl initially believed Collins was her boyfriend and engaged in a conversation with him before eventually realizing he was a stranger and chased him out of her house.
• Collins claimed he believed the girl had consented to his presence in her bedroom in the circumstances.

Issues
• The defendant argued that he should not be convicted of burglary as he had not entered the property as a trespasser, in accordance with section 9 of the Theft Act 1968.
• The prosecution maintained that Collins was a trespasser as he was unlawfully present within the girl's house, and had committed burglary by entering with the intent to commit rape.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal quashed Collins' conviction, ruling that he was not a trespasser when he entered the girl's property.
• The court held that the girl's consent to the defendant's presence, even if mistaken, negated any trespass.
• In addition, the court found that there was insufficient evidence to prove the defendant had formed the requisite intent to commit rape at the time of entry.

Key passage(s)
• 'An entry in response to an invitation, though fraudulently obtained by an impersonation, is not, in my judgement, an entry as a trespasser' (Lord Justice Edmund-Davies)
• 'It is not possible to enter an open window as a trespasser' (Lord Justice Winn)

cases.name: R (Pretty) v DPP [2001] UKHL 61
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case involved Diane Pretty, who suffered from motor neurone disease, a terminal, degenerative illness.
• Mrs. Pretty wished to die in a dignified manner, choosing the timing of her death.
• Assisted suicide was a criminal offense under s.2(1) of the Suicide Act 1961, but Mrs. Pretty was physically unable to commit suicide without assistance due to her illness.
• Her husband, Brian Pretty, was willing to assist his wife, but doing so would expose him to criminal liability.
• Mrs. Pretty applied to the Director of Public Prosecution (DPP) for an assurance that her husband would not be prosecuted, which was refused.
• She sought judicial review of the DPP's decision.

Issues
• Mrs. Pretty claimed the DPP's decision violated her rights under Article 2 (right to life), Article 3 (prohibition of torture or inhuman or degrading treatment), Article 8 (right to respect for private and family life), and Article 14 (prohibition of discrimination) of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).
• The DPP argued that the ECHR did not confer a right to assisted suicide and respected the UK's current law on the subject.

Decision
• The House of Lords dismissed Mrs. Pretty's appeal.
• The Lords held that no ECHR right conferred a right to assisted suicide.
• Article 2 protected the sanctity of life and imposed a positive obligation on states to protect vulnerable individuals from others, including themselves.
• Article 8 protected autonomy within the sphere of private life, but was subject to limitations, and the interference was justified by the law.
• Article 14 was not applicable since Mrs. Pretty was not discriminated against.

Key passage(s)
• 'The absolute prohibition in law of intentional killing is ... based on the ethics of protecting human life and the observance of the principle of the sanctity of life.' (Lord Bingham)
• 'The fact that the applicant is prevented by law from exercising her choice to avoid what she considers will be an undignified and distressing end to her life is an interference with her right to respect of her private life [...]. Such an interference can only be justified if it is in accordance with the law and is necessary in a democratic society.' (Lord Steyn)

cases.name: R v Cunningham [1957] 2 QB 396
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Cunningham [1957] 2 QB 396 is a leading criminal case in English law, which established the mens rea (mental element) requirement for reckless harm.
• The defendant, Cunningham, had stolen money from a gas meter in a neighbouring property, which resulted in gas seeping through the walls into the occupied property next door, endangering the life of the occupant.
• Cunningham was charged with administering a noxious substance so as to endanger life, contrary to section 23 of the Offences Against the Person Act 1861.

Issues
• The key issue in this case was whether Cunningham’s actions met the mens rea requirement necessary for his conviction under section 23, and thus whether he should be found guilty.
• The prosecution argued that the defendant had at least been criminally negligent in his actions, and that his recklessness should be seen as sufficient to establish mens rea.
• The defence argued that Cunningham had not foreseen the risk of harm to others, and as such, did not have the necessary mens rea for this specific crime.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal allowed Cunningham's appeal and quashed his conviction.
• The court held that the mens rea requirement for reckless harm is the subjective test of whether the defendant foresaw the risk, as opposed to the objective test of whether a reasonable person would have foreseen the risk (previously used in cases such as R v Faulkner).
• The court found that Cunningham had not foreseen the risk of harm, and therefore did not possess the necessary mens rea for this specific crime.

Key passage(s)
• 'In any statutory definition of a crime, the malice which is required to be established by the prosecution (in addition to an actus reus) must be particularized. In the present case, there can be no doubt that the required malice is that which underlies the mens rea of the offence.' (Lord Goddard CJ)
• 'We think that in a statutory crime the words 'will give the accused person notice of the need to meet evidence of a fact,' which determines the nature of the crime and which must be proved to make him guilty, connote some degree of advertence or awareness.' (Lord Goddard CJ)

cases.name: Attorney General v Blake [2000] 1 AC 268
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendant, George Blake, was a former British secret service agent convicted of espionage in 1961.
• He escaped from prison in 1966 and fled to the Soviet Union.
• In 1990, he published his autobiography which detailed his activities as a double agent for the Soviet Union.
• The Attorney General, on behalf of the Crown, sought an account of profits made from the book, claiming that Blake had breached his obligations of confidence to the Crown.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the Crown could claim an account of profits from Blake.
• The Attorney General argued that the claim was in relation to Blake's breach of trust and the misuse of official information.
• Blake argued that the claim was based on his breach of confidentiality, which is an equitable remedy and not available to the Crown.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that an account of profits was available as a remedy for breach of confidence, and awarded the Crown the profits from the book.
• The court established the test for such a remedy, which allows it only in exceptional circumstances, such as a manifestly unconscionable conduct.
• The case distinguished itself from the earlier case of Boardman v Phipps [1967] AC 46, on the basis that Blake's behaviour was considered 'more than ordinarily abominable'.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Nicholls: '[T]he jurisdiction to award an account of profits in a case of fiduciary breach is not limited to cases where the fiduciary's profit would have been payable to the principal had the breach not occurred.'
• Lord Woolf: '[T]he remedy...is not dependent on whether the source of the defendant's gain is property in which the plaintiff has a proprietary interest.'
• Lord Browne-Wilkinson: '[T]he remedy is one which is limited to cases where the plaintiff has an unanswerable case against the Defendant...'.

cases.name: R v Hinks [2000] UKHL 53
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Hinks [2000] UKHL 53, the defendant, Juliana Hinks, befriended Edward Haskell, an elderly man with a reduced mental capacity.
• She persuaded him to 'gift' her considerable sums of money, totaling over £60,000, which ultimately resulted in him transferring the entirety of his life savings to her.
• Haskell passed away, and Hinks was charged with theft.
• The defendant was convicted at trial and attempted to appeal her conviction on the grounds that a gift cannot be the subject of theft and that her actions did not possess the required mens rea [guilty mind] for theft.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the act of Hinks inducing Haskell to gift her money constituted the actus reus [guilty act] of theft, specifically the 'dishonest appropriation' of another's property.
• Additionally, Hinks argued that even if her actions constituted the actus reus of theft, she lacked the necessary mens rea, as she believed she was rightfully entitled to the money.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the defendant's actions dd constitute the actus reus of theft, as 'dishonest appropriation' should be given a wide interpretation.
• Furthermore, the House of Lords determined that Hinks possessed the requisite mens rea for theft, as she knew that she was acting dishonestly and without legal claim to the money.
• Hinks' appeal was dismissed, and her conviction was upheld.

Key passage(s)
• 'The appropriation in the present case was undoubtedly dishonest. The appellant must have appreciated that she was appropriating the property of another, because she must have known that Mr. Haskell did not know that the money was going to her.' (Lord Steyn)
• 'The act of inducing a vulnerable person to part with property as an unconditional gift can amount to dishonest appropriation, and there is no need for a further act by the defendant to give effect to the appropriation.' (Lord Hobhouse)

cases.name: Ashby v White [1703] 92 ER 126
cases.summary:
Facts
• Ashby, a qualified voter, attempted to cast his vote in a parliamentary election, but the constable, White, refused to accept his vote.
• Ashby brought an action against White for damages, claiming that the refusal violated his constitutional right to vote.
• The case eventually reached the House of Lords, the highest court in England at the time.

Issues
• White's defence rested on the argument that Ashby's remedy was through parliament and not through the courts.
• Ashby contended that his right to vote had been violated and that he was entitled to damages.
• The key issue was whether the courts had jurisdiction to decide the matter, or whether it was an issue for parliament to resolve.

Decision
• The House of Lords, by a majority, held that White had indeed wronged Ashby by neglecting to accept his vote, and that Ashby was entitled to damages.
• The court reasoned that the right to vote was a fundamental principle of the English constitution, and that protecting this right was within the jurisdiction of the courts.
• Lord Holt and Chief Justice Powell dissented, believing that only parliament had the authority to address the matter.

Key passage(s)
• 'If the plaintiff has a right, he must of necessity have a means to vindicate and maintain it, to recover damages in case of an injury, and an action (in the present case) seems the only method that can be applied to do justice to him.' (Lord Chief Justice Holt)

cases.name: Pinnel's Case (1602) 5 Co Rep 117a
cases.summary:
Facts
• Pinnel's Case (1602) 5 Co Rep 117a involved a dispute between Pinnel (plaintiff) and Cole (defendant).
• The plaintiff had loaned £8 and 10 shillings to the defendant. The defendant had failed to repay the loan when it became due.
• The parties had agreed that the defendant could discharge his debt by paying £5 and 4 pence in installments, and the plaintiff would write off the remainder if the defendant made these payments.
• However, the plaintiff later sued the defendant for the remainder of the original debt.

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether the agreement between the parties to accept partial payment in satisfaction of the full debt was legally enforceable.
• The plaintiff argued that the agreement was not enforceable as the defendant had not provided any consideration (something of value) for the plaintiff's promise to forgive the remainder of the debt.
• The defendant argued that the agreement was enforceable as the partial payment had been agreed upon by both parties and constituted sufficient consideration.

Decision
• The court held that the agreement was not enforceable, and that partial payment of a debt does not constitute sufficient consideration for the discharge of the full debt, unless there is some additional element, such as a benefit conferred to the creditor, or some detriment suffered by the debtor.
• This principle, known as the rule in Pinnel's Case, states that payment of a lesser sum cannot be considered sufficient consideration for the release of the entire debt.

Key passage(s)
• 'Payment of a lesser sum on the day in satisfaction of a greater sum, cannot be any satisfaction for the whole, because it appearcth to the judges that by no possibility, a lesser sum can be a satisfaction to the plaintiff for a greater sum.' (Coke CJ)

cases.name: White v Jones [1995] 2 AC 207
cases.summary:
Facts
• In White v Jones [1995] 2 AC 207, a father (Mr. White) had fallen out with his two daughters and subsequently decided to disinherit them.
• Upon reconciliation, he instructed his solicitor to prepare a new will in which the daughters were to be beneficiaries again.
• However, the solicitor negligently delayed in preparing the new will, and Mr. White died before it could be executed.
• Consequently, the daughters were disinherited under the previous will.
• The daughters sued the solicitor for negligence in causing their loss of inheriting under the new will.

Issues
• The daughters argued that the solicitor owed them a duty of care, and that his breach of this duty led to their loss of inheriting under the new will.
• The solicitor argued that there was no duty of care owed to the daughters since they were not the clients and had no contract with him.
• The case raised the question of whether a solicitor owes a duty of care to someone who was intended to benefit from a will but did not due to the solicitor's negligence.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that a solicitor could indeed owe a duty of care to beneficiaries in certain circumstances.
• In this case, it was found that the solicitor owed a duty of care to the daughters and thus was liable for their loss, resulting from his negligence.

Key passage(s)
• 'The plaintiff daughters' claim is based upon the existence of an assumption of responsibility by the testator's solicitor, coupled with reliance by the daughters, which as a matter of justice and good sense, gives rise to a responsibility sounding in damages.' (Lord Browne-Wilkinson)
• 'Once it is accepted, as I think it must be, that the defendant owed a duty of care to the testator, it is but a short step to hold that the same solicitor is under a duty to protect the plaintiffs, the testator's daughters, against this harm.' (Lord Goff)

cases.name: McGhee v National Coal Board [1973] 1 WLR 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• In McGhee v National Coal Board [1973] 1 WLR 1, Mr. McGhee, an employee of the defendant, the National Coal Board (NCB), suffered dermatitis while working in the company's brick kiln.
• The NCB had failed to provide Mr. McGhee with sufficient washing facilities to remove the harmful irritants on his skin after work.
• The House of Lords was asked to determine whether the NCB was liable for Mr. McGhee's resulting medical condition.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the defendant's failure to provide adequate washing facilities constituted a breach of duty and whether this breach directly caused Mr. McGhee's dermatitis.
• The plaintiff argued that there was a direct causal link between the NCB's failure to provide adequate facilities and the dermatitis.
• The defendants contended that the dermatitis could have been caused by other factors unrelated to the lack of washing facilities.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the NCB was indeed liable for Mr. McGhee's dermatitis.
• The court applied the 'material increase in risk' test, which provides that a defendant is liable if their negligence materially increases the risk of harm occurring.
• Thus, NCB's failure to provide adequate washing facilities increased the risk of dermatitis, making them liable.

Key passage(s)
• 'If one asks oneself what is a common sense answer to the question posed at the outset, the answer is that the Appellant was entitled to wash, that the kiln was a source of danger and that there was a total absence of washing facilities on the spot.' (Lord Reid)
• 'The Respondents were in breach of one obligation which they admittedly owed to the Appellant, but he cannot succeed unless he can show that the breach of that obligation resulted in contracting dermatitis.' (Lord Simon)
• 'In my view, material contribution to injury and material increase in risk of injury are different ways of describing the same thing.' (Lord Wilberforce)

cases.name: Attorney-General’s Reference (No. 2 of 1992) [1994] QB 91, [1993] 3 WLR 982
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendant, a lorry driver, was charged with causing death by dangerous driving after his vehicle struck a stationary vehicle, killing its occupant.
• The defendant claimed that he suffered from a medical condition that caused his leg muscles to become rigid, rendering him incapable of controlling his vehicle.
• The trial judge directed the jury to consider whether the defendant's behaviour constituted automatism, a defence to criminal liability.
• The jury acquitted the defendant, and the Attorney-General referred the case to the Court of Appeal for clarification on the law pertaining to automatism.

Issues
• The Attorney-General argued that automatism should not have been considered as a defence, as the defendant's condition was neither a total loss of control nor completely involuntary.
• The defendant argued that the condition rendered him incapable of controlling his vehicle, therefore satisfying the requirements for automatism.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the defence of automatism was not available in the circumstances, as the defendant's condition did not involve a total loss of control.
• To establish the defence of automatism, it is necessary to demonstrate a complete loss of control (R v T [1990] Crim LR 256) or a complete loss of voluntary control (Bratty v Attorney-General for Northern Ireland [1963] AC 386).
• The Court found that although the defendant was unable to control his leg muscles, he retained substantial control over his vehicle and could have taken measures to prevent the collision.

Key passage(s)
• 'A state of automatism means a state in which a person has no control over his bodily movements at the material time' (Lord Lowry in Bratty v Attorney-General for Northern Ireland).
• 'A momentary loss of self-control is not sufficient to establish automatism. Automatism requires a total loss of voluntary control' (Lord Taylor CJ).

cases.name: R v Golding [2014] EWCA Crim 889
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Golding [2014] EWCA Crim 889, David Golding was convicted for grievous bodily harm (GBH) under Section 20 of the Offences Against the Person Act 1861 (OAPA) for infecting his then-girlfriend with genital herpes.
• Golding knew about his infection but failed to disclose it or use protection during sexual intercourse.
• His former girlfriend subsequently contracted the virus, resulting in painful outbreaks.

Issues
• The prosecution argued that Golding's conduct amounted to a Section 20 GBH offence due to his non-disclosure and reckless transmission of the virus.
• The defence argued that Golding's conduct did not satisfy the elements of the offence, and his conviction should be quashed.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal upheld Golding's conviction, reasoning that deliberately or recklessly transmitting a serious disease such as genital herpes could amount to a Section 20 GBH offence under the OAPA.
• The Court found that Golding's infection had a significant and long-lasting impact on the victim's health and well-being, satisfying the seriousness threshold for GBH.
• Furthermore, Golding's knowledge of his infection and failure to take precautions constituted the requisite mens rea (guilty mind) for the offence.

Key passage(s)
• 'What is plain is that as a result of his reckless behaviour he has caused his girlfriend very serious injury. It is, in our view, difficult to regard that as anything other than really serious bodily harm for the purposes of the 1861 Act' (Lord Justice Leveson).
• 'But for the fact of this relationship and particularly the fact that intercourse took place repeatedly over protective measures were not used, she would NOT have suffered from genital herpes' (Lord Justice Leveson).

cases.name: Bell v Lever Bros [1932] AC 161
cases.summary:
Facts
• In this case, Lever Brothers Ltd (Lever) employed two men, Sir William Watson and Mr. Goodwin, as chairman and vice-chairman respectively.
• They entered into an agreement with Lever to terminate their contracts and paid them compensation for the loss of their positions.
• Lever later discovered that Watson and Goodwin had been involved in secret speculation in the cotton market, acting against the best interests of the company.
• Lever sought to rescind the agreement for compensation and recover the payments made, claiming that they were induced by the mutual mistake of fact.

Issues
• The key issue in this case was whether the agreement for compensation could be set aside on the grounds of mutual mistake of fact.
• Lever argued that they wouldn't have agreed to the compensation if they had known about the secret speculation.
• Watson and Goodwin contended that the mistake, if any, did not relate to the essential substance of the contract and, therefore, the contract could not be rescinded.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the agreement for compensation could not be set aside on the grounds of mutual mistake of fact.
• The court reasoned that the mistake of fact was not essential to the substance of the contract as the true consideration for the agreement was the release of the two men from their contracts, not the fact they hadn't been involved in the secret speculation.
• In terms of the law governing mistake, the case established that a contract could only be rescinded on the grounds of a mistake of fact if the mistake was essential to the substance of the contract.

Key passage(s)
• 'However extensive the doctrine of mutual mistake may be, it applies only in Cases where, either from the terms of the contract or otherwise, the essence of the contract is the truth of the common assumption': (Viscount Hailsham).
• 'The thing which in such a case is common to both parties to the contract and is in their mutual contemplation is not a fact which is or is not a term of the contract but a fact which does or does not affect the very substratum of the contract': (Viscount Dunedin).
• 'The contract is not voidable because the parties were under a mistake of fact in assuming that a certain state of affairs existed; it is voidable because that mistake relates to the essential basis on which the contract was made': (Lord Atkin).

cases.name: Stannard v Gore [2012] EWHC 1655
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Stannard v Gore [2012] EWHC 1655, the claimant, Mr Stannard, was the owner of a tyre fitting business.
• He stored a large number of tyres on his property, which subsequently caught fire due to an electrical fault.
• The fire spread to the neighboring property owned by Mr Gore, causing significant damage.
• Mr Gore initiated legal proceedings against Mr Stannard, claiming that the storage of the tyres constituted a 'nuisance' in tort law.

Issues
• The primary issue for determination was whether the storage of the tyres constituted a nuisance.
• Mr Gore argued that the storage of the tyres, which led to the fire, amounted to an unreasonable interference with the use of his property.
• Mr Stannard, on the other hand, contended that the storage of tyres was part of his lawful business activity and was not unreasonable in the circumstances.
• For a nuisance claim to succeed, Mr Gore needed to prove that the defendant's use of the land had caused substantial and unreasonable interference.

Decision
• The High Court judge, Mr Justice Coulson, found in favor of Mr Stannard, holding that the storage of tyres did not constitute a nuisance.
• The court reasoned that, while the fire had caused substantial interference, the necessary requirement of it being unreasonable had not been met.
• This was based on previous case law, such as Leakey v National Trust for Places of Historic Interest [1980] QB 485, that held the defendant's use of land must be unreasonable as opposed to the consequences of that use.
• As a result, Mr Gore's claim was dismissed.

Key passage(s)
• 'There was no evidence that the mere storage of the tyres amounted to a nuisance before the fire started.' (Coulson J)
• 'I have come to the conclusion that Mr Stannard's use of his land, that is, the storage of the tyres, was not unreasonable.' (Coulson J)
• 'Accordingly, Mr Gore's claim for damages for nuisance fails.' (Coulson J)

cases.name: Entick v Carrington [1765] EWHC KB J98
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1762, the King's messengers, John Entick and Nathan Carrington, were granted a warrant by Lord Halifax, the Secretary of State, to search Entick's home for seditious materials.
• The messengers broke into Entick's house, causing damage, and seized his papers.
• Entick sued Carrington and the other messengers for trespassing and damaging his property.

Issues
• Entick argued that the warrant granted by Lord Halifax was invalid because it was a general warrant and therefore did not specify any legal basis for the search.
• Carrington claimed that the authority of the Secretary of State granted them the right to search and seize material under a general warrant.

Decision
• The court held that the warrant was invalid, as it was a general warrant without any legal basis for the search and seizure of Entick's papers.
• Carrington was held liable for the trespass and damage caused during the search.
• The court emphasized the importance of the sanctity of an individual's home and the protection of property rights.

Key passage(s)
• 'Every invasion of private property, be it ever so minute, is a trespass. No man can set his foot upon my ground without my license, but he is liable to an action, though the damage be nothing.' (Lord Camden)
