• 'If authority is needed for the proposition that the owner of a ship is responsible for damage caused by her negligent navigation in a collision, Barrat v Phenix Insurance Co (1883-L.R.SP & E vii. 446) is authority for it' - Lord Shaw
• 'The directors' powers of delegation in no way enable them to divest themselves of the statutory functions and responsibilities throughout the statutory holding period' - Lord Atkinson

cases.name: Fitzpatrick v British Railways Board [2004] UKHL 34
cases.summary:
Facts
• Fitzpatrick worked for the British Railways Board (BRB) from 1968 to 1993.
• In 1972, the National Union of Railwaymen entered into a collective agreement with the BRB regarding terms and conditions of employment.
• This agreement provided a guaranteed pension for employees if they retired due to permanent ill health.
• Fitzpatrick retired in 1993 due to ill health, but the BRB refused to provide him with the guaranteed pension.
• Fitzpatrick sued the BRB for breach of contract.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the collective agreement, which guaranteed the pension, was incorporated into Fitzpatrick's employment contract.
• Fitzpatrick argued that the agreement was incorporated through an express term in his employment contract.
• The BRB disagreed, arguing that the agreement was not part of the employment contract because it did not specifically mention pensions.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the collective agreement was incorporated into Fitzpatrick's employment contract.
• This was because collective agreements are generally incorporated into employment contracts if they impact significantly on the terms and conditions of employment.
• As the guaranteed pension was an important aspect of Fitzpatrick's remuneration, it was found to be covered by the agreement.
• Therefore, the BRB was in breach of contract for not providing Fitzpatrick with the pension.

Key passage(s)
• 'The question is not whether the clause, as drafted, gives effect to the intention of the parties...but whether, as a matter of objective interpretation, it gives effect to the agreement reached in the collective bargaining process, which the parties must be intended to have wanted to give effect...' (Lord Nicholls)
• 'I cannot see any reason why a collective agreement, duly adopted as the governing instrument for a fund, should not be read, in its whole context, as giving the employer a contractual undertaking to establish and maintain the fund...' (Lord Walker)

cases.name: Chappell & Co Ltd v Nestle Co Ltd [1960] AC 87
cases.summary:
Facts
• Chappell & Co Ltd (Chappell), a music publisher, held the copyright for a song.
• Nestle Co Ltd (Nestle), a chocolate manufacturer, ran a promotion offering a record of the song for 1s 6d (shilling and pence) and three chocolate bar wrappers.
• Chappell contended that no royalty fees were paid for the records, while Nestle argued that the payment for the chocolate bars constituted payment.
• Chappell sued Nestle for copyright infringement.

Issues
• The main issue before the court was whether the chocolate bar wrappers could be considered as 'consideration' (something of value given in exchange for goods or services) for the records under the Copyright Act 1956 (the Act).
• Chappell argued that the wrappers had no value and thus could not be considered consideration under the Act.
• Nestle argued that the wrappers, along with the monetary payment, constituted consideration.

Decision
• The case went all the way to the House of Lords (now the Supreme Court).
• The House of Lords held in favor of Chappell, finding that the chocolate bar wrappers could not be considered consideration under the Act.
• They opined that the wrappers had no value to Chappell and therefore could not be considered as payment for the records.
• As a result, Nestle had not satisfied the 'sufficient acknowledgment' requirement of the Act, and was found guilty of copyright infringement.

Key passage(s)
• 'In my view the respondents offered, and the public who took advantage of the offer gave, the three wrappings plus 1s 6d in exchange for the gramophone record. Both the wrappings and the 1s 6d formed part of the consideration given for the record.' (Lord Reid)
• 'It seems to me that, on a true construction of the statute, the consideration must be something which benefits the copyright owner in the sense that it is something which he can turn to account.' (Lord Somervell)
• 'To hold the view that the copyright owner is to be paid in chocolate is to substitute one absurdity for another.' (Lord Denning)

cases.name: Hyde v Hyde and Woodmansee (1866) LR 1 P&D 130
cases.summary:
Facts
• Hyde v Hyde and Woodmansee (1866) LR 1 P&D 130 is a leading English case that sets out the definition of 'marriage' in the context of English law.
• Mr. Hyde was the husband of Mrs. Hyde, who left him to cohabit with Woodmansee in England; both parties, however, were originally Mormons from Utah.
• Mr. Hyde sought to nullify the marriage between him and his wife in an English court.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the court had the jurisdiction to grant an annulment in England for a Mormon from Utah.
• Mr. Hyde argued that since the marriage took place under a polygamous religious system (Mormonism), it was not a valid marriage, and the court should declare it null and void.
• Mrs. Hyde and Woodmansee contended that their marriage was valid under the laws of Utah and that the English courts should not intervene.

Decision
• The court, led by Sir James Wilde (later Lord Penzance), held that the English legal system did not recognize polygamous marriages and that the court had jurisdiction to declare the marriage null and void.
• Therefore, Mr. Hyde was granted the annulment he sought.

Key passage(s)
• 'Marriage (...) may be defined as the voluntary union for life of one man and one woman, to the exclusion of all others.' (Sir James Wilde)
• 'I conceive that marriage, as understood in Christendom, may (...) be defined as I have recited it.' (Sir James Wilde)

cases.name: Re G (Children) (Residence: Same-sex Partner) [2005] UKHL 43
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Re G (Children) (Residence: Same-sex Partner) [2005] UKHL 43, the appellant and respondent were a lesbian couple who had entered into a same-sex relationship.
• The appellant was the biological mother of two children, conceived through donor insemination.
• The couple's relationship ended and the appellant formed a new relationship with a man and subsequently moved with the children to Cornwall.
• The respondent sought a shared residence order, which was initially granted by the family court.
• The Court of Appeal subsequently set aside the shared residence order, granting a limited contact order in favor of the respondent.

Issues
• The House of Lords had to determine the appropriate standard of appellate review in cases involving disputes between a biological parent and a non-biological parent.
• The appellant argued that the Court of Appeal had erred in overturning the shared residence order, and that the best interests of the children were served by granting her sole residence.
• The respondent argued that the shared residence order should be reinstated, as she had played a significant role in the children's lives.

Decision
• The House of Lord reversed the decision of the Court of Appeal, reinstating the shared residence order.
• It held that the Court of Appeal had erred in its approach to appellate review, as it was not entitled to interfere with the exercise of discretion by the family court unless the appellate court could establish that the judge's decision was plainly wrong or resulted from an error of law.
• In the present case, it was determined that there was no error of law or plainly wrong result in the judge's decision to grant the shared residence order.

Key passage(s)
• 'In my view it is clear that the judge's decision can only be overturned if it is shown either that he made errors of law, or that no reasonable judge applying the right law could have arrived at his conclusion, or that his decision was wrong so as to be unjust.': (Baroness Hale)
• 'I agree that the same-sex aspect of this case does not have a bearing on the outcome, and should not have a bearing on the result of other cases which are now proceeding or which will come before the courts in the future.': (Lord Nicholls)
• 'The question for the appellate court is not whether they would have made the same order but whether the order which was made by the experienced specialist judge was within the ambit of proper judicial decision-making.': (Lord Walker)

cases.name: Ready Mixed Concrete (South East) Ltd v Minister of Pensions and National Insurance [1968] 2 QB 497
cases.summary:
Facts
• Ready Mixed Concrete (South East) Ltd (RMC) entered into a contract for the supply of labour to deliver goods to their customers.
• The contract required the workers to provide a lorry, fuel and a driver for the lorry.
• The contract also stated that the workers were self-employed, and not employees of RMC.
• The contract contained a clause that the parties did not intend it to create a legal relationship.

Issues
• The issue before the court was whether the workers were employees or independent contractors.
• The Minister of Pensions and National Insurance argued that the workers were employees, as they were under RMC's control.
• RMC contended that the workers were independent contractors, as per their contract.

Decision
• The court held that the workers were independent contractors, not employees of RMC.
• The court applied the 'control test' (from Yewens v Noakes [1880] 6 QBD 530) and found that RMC had inadequate control over the workers for them to be considered employees.
• The court also considered other factors relevant to the worker's relationship with RMC, including their right to substitute a driver and the fact that they provided their own equipment and resources.

Key passage(s)
• 'A contract of service exists if these three conditions are fulfilled. (i) The servant agrees that, in consideration of a wage or other remuneration, he will provide his own work and skill in the performance of some service for his master. (ii) He agrees, expressly or impliedly, that in the performance of that service he will be subject to the other's control in a sufficient degree to make that other master. (iii) The other provisions of the contract are consistent with its being a contract of service.' (Diplock LJ)
• 'One of the considerations to which emphasis is often given in distinguishing between a contract of service and a contract for services is the degree of control which the hirer exercises.' (Diplock LJ)

cases.name: Salomon v A Salomon & Co Ltd [1897] AC 22
cases.summary:
Facts
• Aron Salomon, a leather merchant, incorporated his business under the Companies Act 1862, creating A Salomon & Co Ltd. He transferred his business assets to the company in exchange for shares for himself and his family.
• The company subsequently issued a £10,000 debenture, secured by the company’s assets, to Salomon.
• When A Salomon & Co Ltd later went insolvent, the liquidator, Broderip, sought to recover the outstanding debt from Salomon, claiming the debenture was fraudulent.

Issues
• The liquidator argued that A Salomon & Co Ltd was a sham created to benefit Salomon and his family, and thus the company’s actions should be treated as Salomon’s actions.
• Salomon claimed that as a separate legal entity, the company was liable for its own debts and the debenture was a legitimate transaction.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that A Salomon & Co Ltd was a separate legal entity distinct from its members, as required by the Companies Act.
• The court ruled that the company’s actions could not be attributed to Salomon, and the debenture was valid.
• This decision established the principle of ‘corporate veil,’ which separates companies’ legal liabilities from their members.

Key passage(s)
• 'The company is at law a different person altogether from the subscribers to the memorandum:', Lord Macnaghten
• 'The company’s business is not the business of the subscribers but is its own business, and the company is primarily liable to indemnify any loss', Lord Watson
• 'We are asked to treat the company as identical with the subscribers, because the subscribers have the control which is the attribute of shareholders, and the Court of Appeal have assented to the request. I cannot', Lord Herschell

cases.name: Foss v Harbottle (1843) 67 ER 189
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Foss v Harbottle (1843) 67 ER 189, two minority shareholders (Foss and Turton) in a company called Victoria Park Company sought relief from the court for alleged mismanagement by the company's board of directors (Harbottle, White, Chapman, and Booth).
• They claimed that the defendants misappropriated the company's funds and caused the company to enter into illegal and unauthorized contracts.
• The claimants demanded that the company bring a lawsuit against the directors for the alleged breaches of their fiduciary duty.

Issues
• The claimants argued that the directors' actions constituted a breach of their fiduciary duty and that a derivative action (where shareholders bring an action on behalf of the company) should be allowed.
• The defendants argued that the alleged wrongs could be ratified by a simple majority of shareholders, and since the majority had approved the directors' actions, there was no legal basis for the derivative action.

Decision
• The court dismissed the claimants' case, holding that the wrongs alleged were capable of being ratified by a simple majority of shareholders, and as such, the court had no jurisdiction to intervene.
• The court established the Foss v Harbottle rule, which states that a claim by an individual shareholder on behalf of the company (derivative action) can only be pursued if the alleged wrong is incapable of being ratified by a simple majority of shareholders.
• This case laid the foundations for the separate legal personality of a company in English law, as well as the proper plaintiff principle (Rule in Foss v Harbottle).

Key passage(s)
• 'There must always be some differences in disputes between the management and the corporators; but courts of law were not instituted to determine such matters, provided the directors are acting within their authority; if there is an abuse of that authority, if the majority or the body act fraudulently or collusively, then, indeed, the jurisdiction of the court is properly appealed to,' (Wigram VC).
• 'The whole mischief complained of was, in truth, the misapplication of the funds of the company; now this being the case, although that misapplication might be a great practical grievance to those who are members of the company, yet the parties who suffered have the means, by means of their legal rights, of redressing the wrong.' (Wigram VC).

cases.name: Gilford Motor Co Ltd v Horne [1933] Ch 935
cases.summary:
Facts
• Gilford Motor Co Ltd (GMC) was a company manufacturing and selling motor vehicles.
• E. B. Horne, a former managing director of GMC, left the company and formed a rival business called J.M. Horne & Co Ltd (JMH).
• Horne had a non-compete clause in his employment contract with GMC, which prevented him from directly competing with GMC for a certain period.
• To avoid the non-compete clause, Horne incorporated JMH, where his wife held most of the shares and was the nominal director, while Horne himself managed the day-to-day affairs of the company.
• GMC sued Horne and JMH for breach of the non-compete clause.

Issues
• GMC argued that Horne, by incorporating JMH, had created a 'sham' company to avoid his non-compete obligations under his employment contract.
• Horne and JMH argued that the company was a separate legal entity, and therefore not subject to the non-compete clause.

Decision
• The court found in favour of GMC, holding that JMH was a mere 'cloak' or 'sham' created by Horne to avoid the non-compete clause.
• In doing so, the court pierced the corporate veil, looking beyond the legal fiction of JMH as a separate entity, and held that Horne and JMH were in breach of the non-compete clause.

Key passage(s)
• 'The claims of the company to be treated as a separate entity may be disregarded if it is really a cloak or sham for the defendant's own trading and nothing else.' (Maugham LJ)
• 'For my part, I can see no reason why the knowledge of the real principal, assuming that the company was the agent for him in this she heard, should not be imputed to the company.' (Romer LJ)

cases.name: Re Spectrum Plus Ltd [2005] UKHL 41
cases.summary:
Facts
• BNY (Bank of New York) loaned money to S Ltd (Spectrum Plus Limited), a retail business dealing in toiletries.
• BNY and S Ltd signed a debenture, which included a legal charge over S Ltd's property and a fixed charge over its book debts.
• S Ltd became insolvent and its administrators made payments using the book debts to BNY.
• The Official Receiver challenged the validity of BNY's right to receive payments.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the charge created by the debenture over the book debts was a fixed charge or a floating charge.
• BNY argued that the charge was fixed because it had control over S Ltd's book debts.
• The Official Receiver contended that the charge was floating, not fixed.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the charge over book debts was a floating charge, not a fixed one.
• This decision reversed previous authorities such as Siebe Gorman v Barclays [1979] 2 Lloyd's Rep 142 and Brumark Investments Ltd v Barclays Bank plc [2001] BCC 494.
• The correct test for determining whether a charge is fixed or floating was set out in Agnew v Commissioner of Inland Revenue [2001] Ch 106.
• This test requires that the chargeholder must be able to exercise control over the charged asset without the need for any further permission.

Key passage(s)
• 'The distinguishing feature of a floating charge, the characteristic which gives it its name, is that the asset subject to the charge is not finally appropriated as a security for the payment of the debt until the occurrence of some future event. In the meantime the chargor is left free to use the charged asset and to remove it from the security.' (Lord Walker)
• 'For a charge over an asset to be a fixed charge, the charge-holder must have control over the disposal of the charged asset without any further step needed to be taken by the charge-holder to obtain the protection of the charge.' (Lord Walker)

cases.name: Moohan and another (AP) (Appellants) v The Lord Advocate (Scotland) (Respondent) [2014] UKSC 67
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Scottish government passed the Scottish Independence Referendum (Franchise) Act 2013, which set out the rules for voting in the 2014 Scottish independence referendum.
• The Act excluded prisoners from voting in the referendum.
• Moohan and another prisoner challenged this exclusion in court, arguing that it breached their rights under the common law and EU law, and constituted a discriminatory infringement on their right to freedom of expression.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether the exclusion of prisoners from voting in the Scottish independence referendum breached their common law and EU law rights.
• The appellants argued that the Scottish government had a duty under the common law to adopt a more proportionate approach to the franchise, such as allowing certain categories of prisoners to vote.
• They also claimed that the referendum was within the scope of EU law as it related to the future of the UK's membership of the EU, and therefore the exclusion of prisoners from voting infringed their EU rights.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously rejected the appellants' arguments and dismissed their case.
• The Court held that the common law did not require a more proportionate approach to the franchise, and that the Scottish government was entitled to exclude prisoners from voting in the same way as the UK government in Westminster.
• The Court also held that the referendum did not fall within the scope of EU law, as it was a matter of internal constitutional change and did not directly affect the UK's EU membership.

Key passage(s)
• 'A common law constitutional right to vote is not of itself sufficient… The issues which emerge from the case law all serve to underline the conclusion that it is for elected representatives to set the limits to prisoners' rights to vote, subject to any mandatory requirements of statute or binding international convention or treaty.' (Lord Hodge, paragraph 41)

cases.name: Liversidge v. Anderson [1942] AC 206
cases.summary:
Facts
• During World War II, Liversidge was arrested and detained without a warrant by Anderson, the Secretary of State for Home Affairs.
• Anderson's order for Liversidge's detention stated that Anderson had reasonable cause to believe that Liversidge was involved in activities prejudicial to public safety.
• Liversidge sought a writ of habeas corpus, claiming his detention was unlawful, as Anderson had not specified the grounds for detention.

Issues
• The main issue was whether Anderson was required to disclose the grounds for detention or if his mere belief that Liversidge was a threat to public safety was sufficient.
• Liversidge argued that the regulation required Anderson to show that he had an objectively reasonable cause to believe Liversidge was a threat.
• Anderson claimed that his subjective belief that Liversidge was a threat was enough to justify the detention order under the regulation.

Decision
• The House of Lords, by a majority of 4-1, sided with Anderson, holding that his belief was enough to justify the detention order.
• The court held that the words 'reasonable cause' should be interpreted as 'subjective reasonable cause,' meaning it was only necessary for Anderson to believe there was a reasonable cause.
• Lord Atkin dissented, arguing that the regulation should be interpreted as requiring an objective reasonable cause.

Key passage(s)
• '[I]n matters of emergency such as those with which the ... regulation deals, and particularly the present kind of emergency ..., it would seem to be inconsistent with Parliament's intentions and impracticable on various accounts to require that there should be an examination of the actual grounds for the belief in the believer's mind. It seems improbable Parliament should have intended to submit the grounds of belief for review on the ground of its inadequacy. There must be a believer, and the test must be applied to him but he is to prevail if he satisfies the prima facie test of having reached the belief and nothing more.' - Lord Greene (Majority Opinion)
• 'In this country, amid the clash of arms, the laws are not silent. They may be changed, but they speak the same language in war as in peace.' - Lord Atkin (Dissenting Opinion)

cases.name: Al-Skeini v Secretary of State for Defence [2007] UKHL 26
cases.summary:
Facts
• Al-Skeini involved the deaths of five Iraqi civilians allegedly killed by British soldiers in Basra during the occupation of Iraq in 2003.
• The families of the deceased sought an independent investigation into the killings by the UK government under Article 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), which protects the right to life.
• The Secretary of State for Defence argued that the UK did not have jurisdiction (or control) over these cases under the ECHR.

Issues
• The central issue was whether the UK had jurisdiction under Article 1 of the ECHR for the deaths of Iraqi civilians during the occupation of Iraq.
• The claimants argued that the UK had jurisdiction and was bound to comply with the ECHR when controlling detainees on foreign soil (R v Secretary of State for the Home Department, ex p Quark Fishing Ltd [2005] UKHL 57).
• The respondentSecretary of State for Defence argued that the UK's extraterritorial jurisdiction did not include these five cases.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the UK did not have jurisdiction over these cases under the ECHR.
• It was decided that the ECHR could only apply where the UK had jurisdiction (control) over an area, and the cases in question did not meet this requirement.
• The Lords did, however, confirm jurisdiction for one case, where the individual was in the physical custody of UK forces, in line with the decision in Banković v Belgium and Others (2001) 11 BHRC 435.

Key passage(s)
• '[R]equires that the respondent State should have had effective control of the area in which the alleged violation of human rights occurred.' (Lord Rodger)
• '[I]t is only if a contracting party has had effective control of an area that, in the absence of an Article 56 declaration by the occupying power, its obligations under the Convention apply.' (Lord Rodger)
• 'In my view, the Secretary of State's submission is correct: the death of the applicant's brother does not engage the responsibility of the United Kingdom under the Convention.' (Lord Brown)

cases.name: Re F (Mental Patient Sterilisation) [1990] 2 AC 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• Re F (Mental Patient Sterilisation) [1990] 2 AC 1 is a landmark case in English law regarding the courts' jurisdiction over medical treatment for mentally incapacitated individuals.
• The plaintiff, Ms. F, was a 36-year-old woman with the mental capacity of a child, who had formed a sexual relationship with another patient at her residential home.
• Doctors concluded that if she were to become pregnant, the pregnancy and childbirth would pose significant health risks to Ms. F.
• Her mother sought the court's permission to authorize a sterilization procedure, which the hospitals were unwilling to perform without legal authority.

Issues
• The main legal issue in the case was whether the courts had the jurisdiction to authorize medical treatment for a mentally incapacitated individual who was unable to give consent, and if so, under what legal principle.
• The plaintiff argued that the court had the inherent jurisdiction to act as a parens patriae, a role typically applied in cases involving minors, to authorize medical treatment for Ms. F.
• The defendants argued that there was no existing legal authority which allowed the court to act in such capacity.

Decision
• The House of Lords established the principle of 'necessity' to authorize medical treatment for an adult who is unable to provide consent due to mental incapacity.
• This ruling was based on the idea that a medical practitioner could act in the best interests of the patient by providing necessary medical treatment.
• The court ultimately authorized the sterilization procedure.

Key passage(s)
• 'The authority of a court or a parent to give consent on behalf of a minor to medical treatment dates back at least as far as Marion's case (Secretary, Department of Health and Community Services v. JWB and SMB (1992) 175 CLR 218).' (Lord Goff of Chieveley)

cases.name: Bellinger v. Bellinger [2003] UKHL 21
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Bellinger v. Bellinger [2003] UKHL 21, the appellant, Elizabeth Bellinger, had undergone male-to-female gender reassignment surgery, and had sought a declaration that her marriage to her husband Michael was valid.
• Importantly, her birth certificate still identified her as male, and her chromosomal sex remained XY (male).
• In arguing the validity of the marriage, Elizabeth relied on the European Convention of Human Rights (ECHR), particularly Article 8 (respect for private and family life) and Article 12 (right to marry).

Issues
• The main issue before the House of Lords was whether a post-operative transsexual person should be regarded as a woman under English marriage law, or whether the biological definition at birth should prevail.
• Elizabeth's argument was based on the concept of evolving social conscience, suggesting that the UK legislation failed to keep up with the times, and that strict adherence to the biological definition violated her rights under the ECHR.
• In response, the House of Lords considered whether the interpretation of the English marriage law should be adapted in light of the decision in Goodwin v United Kingdom (2002) 35 EHRR 18, a case where the European Court of Human Rights held that the UK had failed to adequately respect the right to private life of a transsexual person.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the English marriage law could not be adapted to recognise Elizabeth as a woman, and therefore her marriage was deemed to be void.
• The Lords noted that the interpretation of the term 'woman' in the context of marriage law was based on biological factors, rather than the psycho-social factors.
• They further held that although the ECHR could be relied upon to alter the UK law, it was not within the competence of the courts to make such a change; it fell under the purview of Parliament.

Key passage(s)
• 'There are no convincing grounds for changing the interpretation of woman to include those who have undergone male-to-female gender reassignment surgery. It is for Parliament, not the courts, to decide whether and how the law should be changed.' (Lord Nicholls)

cases.name: AG v. Prince Ernest Augustus of Hanover [1957] AC 436
cases.summary:
Facts
• In this case, Prince Ernest Augustus of Hanover, a resident of Germany, was the subject of a magazine article in the UK, which he claimed was defamatory.
• The German court awarded him damages, but the defendant (AG) sought a declaration from the English court that the German judgment should not be enforced in the UK.
• AG argued that the German court did not have jurisdiction over the case, and that the UK should not recognize a foreign judgment in a different legal system.

Issues
• Argument by AG: The German court lacked jurisdiction because the tortious act was committed in the UK, and a UK court should determine the outcome.
• Argument by Prince: As the publication's distribution occurred in Germany, and the alleged defamation damaged his reputation there, the German court had jurisdiction.

Decision
• The House of Lords unanimously held that the German judgment could be enforced in the UK.
• The court determined that the German court had jurisdiction because the place of distribution was Germany, and the alleged defamation impacted Prince's reputation there.
• The court also noted that the principles established in Boys v Chaplin [1971] AC 356 applied in this case.

Key passage(s)
• 'There is no warrant for the view that the Act of State doctrine enjoins an English court from pronouncing any judgment which might be regarded as enforcing a foreign legislative or executive act or a foreign judgment given in accordance with that act' (Viscount Simonds).
• '...the English court is not concerned to inquire what the proper law for the assessment of damages is, or to assess the damages on a different basis; it is merely asked to enforce the foreign judgment, as it will enforce equitable orders or orders for alimony or orders in personam generally...' (Lord Denning).

cases.name: Blake v. Galloway [2004] 1 WLR 2840
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimant, Ian Blake, and the defendant, Simon Galloway, were friends engaged in horseplay after a pub visit when the incident occurred.
• Galloway, attempting to scare Blake, feigned throwing a wooden pole at him.
• In response, Blake flung his hands up in self-defence, which Galloway took as a signal to start play-fighting.
• During the exchange, Galloway accidentally struck Blake's face with a wooden pole, causing a serious eye injury.
• The claimant sued the defendant for negligence and battery.

Issues
• The issue at hand was whether the defendant was in breach of the duty of care owed to the claimant when engaging in horseplay.
• The claimant argued that the defendant's actions were negligent, whereas the defendant contended that the claimant had consented to horseplay and the risk of accidental injury.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal found in favour of the defendant.
• It was held that the claimant consented to the risk of injury inherent in horseplay, and therefore the defendant was neither negligent nor in breach of any duty of care owed to the claimant.
• The court emphasized that when assessing the standard of care in cases involving rough and undisciplined games, such as this one, the relevant standard is a lower one, recognizing the claimant's consent to take physical risks.
• The claim for battery failed as the court found no intent to harm the plaintiff.

Key passage(s)
• '...where the parties are engaged in an activity in which they both voluntarily accept some physical risk, the threshold of liability will equally be influenced by the fact the claimant voluntarily accepts a risk of injury which is inherent in the game.' (Lord Justice Dyson)
• '...it is not sustainable to view the defendant's actions as having gone beyond the scope of what had been accepted by the claimant.' (Lord Justice Potter)

cases.name: R v. Secretary of State for the Home Department, ex parte Brind [1991] 1 AC 696
cases.summary:
Facts
• The applicants, journalists and editors, challenged a decision by the Home Secretary to issue directions prohibiting the broadcasting of direct statements by individuals representing certain proscribed Irish organizations, under the Broadcasting Act 1981.
• These directions were made due to concerns about the effect of such broadcasts on potential violence in Northern Ireland.

Issues
• The applicants argued that the Home Secretary's decision violated their rights under the European Convention of Human Rights (ECHR), especially Article 10 (freedom of expression).
• The government contended that the decision was necessary to prevent disorder and crime.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the Home Secretary's decision was lawful and did not violate the applicants' rights under the ECHR.
• Their Lordships reasoned that the ECHR had not been incorporated into English law and therefore could not be relied upon in domestic legal proceedings.
• They also noted that the Home Secretary's decision was not irrational, given the aims of preventing disorder and crime.

Key passage(s)
• 'While every reasonable person would, I am sure, share the wish of the applicants that the guarantees contained in article 10(2) of the European Convention should be available to be relied upon in the domestic courts of this country, the fact remains that the treaty by which the convention was ratified is not such as to make it part of English law.' - Lord Bridge
• 'Whatever one may think of the merits of the Secretary of State's policy or the merits of the Broadcasting Act, the decision cannot be impugned as being irrational.' - Lord Ackner

cases.name: R v Simon Slingsby [1995] Crim LR 570
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendant, Simon Slingsby, and the victim, a woman with whom he had a consensual sexual relationship, were engaging in a consensual sexual act involving the insertion of his fist into her vagina.
• During the act, the defendant wore a ring which caused injuries to the victim's vaginal wall, ultimately causing septicemia and her death.
• The defendant was charged with manslaughter, and convicted at the trial.

Issues
• The defence argued that, since the sexual act was consensual and not unlawful, and the harm was unforeseen, the defendant should not be held criminally responsible for her death.
• The prosecution contended that the defendant owed a general duty of care to the victim, and his breach of that duty while engaged in an act dangerous to life was sufficient for a manslaughter conviction.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal quashed the defendant's conviction, holding that there was no basis in law for finding that he owed a duty of care to the victim in the course of their consensual sexual relationship and that the act was not inherently dangerous.
• The court relied on the precedent set in R v Brown [1994] 1 AC 212, where it was held that consensual acts between adults resulting in injury or death, in the course of an otherwise lawful personal relationship, do not give rise to criminal liability.
• The court distinguished R v Adomako [1995] 1 AC 171, where a doctor's anesthetic error leading to the death of a patient was found to be the basis for a conviction of manslaughter, on the ground that the medical professional had a legal duty of care towards his patient.

Key passage(s)
• 'The conduct in question was not defined as criminal by either statute or common law. It seems to us that if he is to be held guilty of manslaughter there must be some new development of the common law to enable the required duty of care to be found in the particular circumstances.' (Lord Taylor of Gosforth, CJ)

cases.name: R v Clegg [1995] 1 AC 482
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Clegg [1995] 1 AC 482 was a case involving a British soldier stationed in Northern Ireland, Private Clegg.
• Private Clegg was part of a vehicle checkpoint operation when a car sped towards them, disobeying the order to stop.
• Fearing a terrorist attack, Private Clegg fired shots at the car. The first two shots hit the windscreen but the third (fatal) shot hit the passenger, a 17-year-old female, who was later found to be an innocent civilian.
• Private Clegg was charged and convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment.

Issues
• The main issue before the House of Lords was whether Private Clegg had a valid claim of self-defence or if his use of force was excessive.
• The defence argued that Private Clegg's actions should be judged in the context of fear for his own life and the lives of his fellow soldiers, and that the third shot was fired in quick succession as part of a single act.
• The prosecution maintained that the third shot was excessive, given the evidence that the danger had passed the checkpoint at the time of the fatal shot.

Decision
• The House of Lords upheld Private Clegg's conviction, ruling that the third shot was excessive and that the trial judge had correctly instructed the jury to consider the matter.
• It was held that it was for the jury to determine whether the use of force was reasonable in the circumstances, considering factors such as the degree of force used and the immediacy of the threat.
• This case confirmed the principles set out in Palmer v R [1971] AC 814 that a person can lose the protection of self-defence if the force used is excessive.

cases.name: A-G's Reference (No 1 of 1975) [1975] QB 773
cases.summary:
Facts
• D added alcohol to P's soft drink without P's knowledge.
• P was later stopped by police and convicted of drink driving under section 6(1) of the Road Traffic Act 1972 (RTA 1972).

Issues
• The court had to determine whether D's actions amounted to the offense of 'aiding, abetting, counseling, or procuring' the commission of an offense by P under the Accessories and Abettors Act 1861 (AAA 1861).
• D argued that P's conviction was not a crime he intentionally encouraged or assisted.
• The Attorney General (A-G) contended that D's act of spiking P's drink was an intentional act that procured the commission of P's drink-driving offense.

Decision
• The court held that D could not be guilty of aiding and abetting P's crime under the AAA 1861.
• It was found that there must be a joint criminal enterprise between D and P, which was not present in this case since P was unaware of D's actions.
• The court made clear that there is no offense for aiding and abetting an unwitting or reluctant offender.

Key passage(s)
• 'An 'aider and abettor' has been defined...as 'a person who, with knowledge of the essentials of what is to be done, acts as an aider and abettor either before or at the time of the commission of the offence': R v Bowen (1832) 6 Car & P 635, at p 640.' (Lord Widgery CJ).
• 'But there is an essential difference between facilitating the commission of an offence and acting so as to influence another to commit an offence while he is ignorant of his actions and their consequences.' (Lord Widgery CJ)

cases.name: R v. S of S for Home Dept, ex p. Fire Brigades Union [1995] 2 AC 513 (HL)
cases.summary:
Facts
• In response to a series of high-profile disasters, the UK Government conducted a review of emergency services, leading to the enactment of the Criminal Justice Act (CJA) 1988.
• The Act contained a statutory scheme for compensating victims of crime, which was to be implemented by the Home Secretary. However, the Home Secretary decided not to implement the new scheme at all.
• The Fire Brigades Union (FBU) sought judicial review, arguing that the Home Secretary's decision was unlawful as it frustrated the intention of Parliament.

Issues
• The FBU argued that the Home Secretary was under a legal duty to implement the statutory scheme, even if there was no specified date in the Act for its implementation.
• The Home Secretary argued that, in the absence of a specified date, it was for the executive to decide when, if ever, to implement the statutory scheme.

Decision
• The House of Lords held, by a majority, that the Home Secretary had acted unlawfully in refusing to implement the statutory scheme.
• The court relied on the principle established in Padfield v. Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food [1968], which confirmed that statutory discretion could not be used in a way that would frustrate Parliament's intention.
• The Lords emphasised that the intention of Parliament in enacting the scheme was to provide compensation for victims of crime, which was frustrated by the Home Secretary's decision not to implement it.

Key passage(s)
• 'Once it is shown that a public authority's discretion arises from an enactment whose policy it is the duty of the authority to promote, matters relevant to its decision must include the effect of any proposed decision on the promotion of the policy' - Lord Browne-Wilkinson (at 552C-D).

cases.name: R v S of S for the Home Dept, ex p Venables [1998] AC 407
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v S of S for the Home Dept, ex p Venables [1998] AC 407, commonly known as the 'Bulger case', concerned the two applicants, Venables and Thompson, who were convicted of the murder of a toddler when they were 11 years old.
• They were sentenced to be detained during Her Majesty's pleasure, and the trial judge recommended a minimum term of eight years.
• The Home Secretary, acting on Lord Chief Justice's recommendation, increased the minimum term to 15 years, which essentially meant the Home Secretary would decide their release date.

Issues
• The applicants argued that the Home Secretary's decision infringed their rights under Article 6 (right to a fair trial) of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) and they claimed that their case should be reviewed by an independent body.
• The Home Secretary contended that Article 6 was not applicable, as a 'sentence' was subject to decisions made by the executive branch, and that their role in making such decisions did not infringe the ECHR.

Decision
• The House of Lords ( UK's top court) held that the Home Secretary's decision amounted to an infringement of the applicants' rights under Article 6 of the ECHR.
• The court decided that 'sentencing' required an independent judicial assessment and could not be left to the executive, considering it a violation of the independence of the judiciary.
• They further held that the Home Secretary's role in such matters was incompatible with Article 6.

Key passage(s)
• 'The determination of the minimum term by the Secretary of State... is not compatible with article 6(1) of the European Convention on Human Rights' - Lord Hoffmann.

cases.name: R v S of S for the Home Dept, ex p Pierson [1998] AC 539
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Secretary of State for the Home Department, ex parte Pierson (1998) AC 539, the applicant, Pierson, was a life prisoner convicted of murder.
• In 1993, the Secretary of State (S of S) decided to fix a minimum term to serve before Pierson was eligible for parole.
• Pierson argued that the S of S had no power to decide the minimum term under the law.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the Secretary of State had the power to fix a minimum term for a life prisoner under English law.
• Pierson argued that fixing a minimum term was the court's function and not the executive's.
• The Secretary of State contended that he did have the power to fix a minimum term, based on precedent in R v S of S for the Home Dept, ex parte Handscomb [1988] QB 677.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the Secretary of State did not have the power to fix a minimum term for a life prisoner.
• In their Lordships' view, the Secretary of State improperly exercised the power of the courts by fixing a minimum term.
• The decision in Handscomb was distinguished, as it did not concern life prisoners.

Key passage(s)
• 'In a case... where the Secretary has by statute been given power to decide the date of a prisoner's release on licence…the power to fix the minimum term of his imprisonment will necessarily be implied': Lord Browne-Wilkinson.
• 'The discretion in fixing the tariff primarily lies with the courts': Lord Steyn.

cases.name: Ellen Street Estates v Minister of Health [1934] 1 KB 590
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Ellen Street Estates v Minister of Health [1934] 1 KB 590, the appellant (Ellen Street Estates) owned land which had been previously allocated for housing under the Housing Act 1925 (HA 1925).
• The Minister of Health was empowered by statute to purchase the land compulsorily under section 45 of the Housing, Town Planning, &c. Act 1919 (HTPCA 1919).
• However, HA 1925 contained no provision repealing HTPCA 1919.
• The appellant argued that it was exempted from compulsory acquisition due to HA 1925 and sought a declaration regarding the minister's power to purchase the land compulsorily.

Issues
• The main issue at trial was whether the powers of compulsory acquisition under the HTPCA 1919 were impliedly repealed by the provisions of the HA 1925.
• The appellant argued that HA 1925 repealed the HTPCA 1919 by implication (since there were no express repeal provisions) due to the later statute's detailed and comprehensive regulations.
• The respondent (Minister of Health) argued that HA 1925 did not repeal HTPCA 1919, and therefore the minister still had the power to purchase the land compulsorily.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the provisions of the HTPCA 1919 were not impliedly repealed by the HA 1925, and the minister retained the power to purchase the land compulsorily.
• The court reasoned that implied repeal requires a clear inconsistency between the two statutes, which was not present in this case. The court also suggested that the principle of implied repeal should only be applied as a last resort when no other interpretation is possible.

Key passage(s)
• 'The repeal of an earlier statute by implication by a later statute is a question of construction of the later, and depends upon there being in it such provisions as will demonstrate a legislative intention to make the earlier cease to have any operation.' (Lord Justice Maugham)

cases.name: AG for NSW v Trethowan [1932] AC 526
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1929, the New South Wales (NSW) state legislature passed a statute amending its constitution.
• The amendment involved abolishing the Legislative Council and required a referendum pass a majority vote.
• In 1930, the then-government sought to pass an Act preventing the referendum.
• The plaintiff, Trethowan, claimed that the amending law violated the state constitution and sought to prevent the government from taking further action.

Issues
• The central issue debated was whether the statute was valid under the NSW constitution and whether the government could proceed without a referendum.
• The defendants argued that the statute was valid under the state constitution and it wasn't necessary to hold a referendum.
• The plaintiff contended that the statute violated the state constitution and that the referendum was a necessary precondition to any amendment.

Decision
• The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council (JCPC) held that the NSW constitution contained an implied limitation on legislative power regarding constitutional amendments.
• To amend the NSW constitution, the legislature must follow the 'manner and form' specified in the Constitution. In this case, the specified requirement was the holding of a referendum.
• As the government failed to abide by the 'manner and form', its amending statute was declared invalid, and the referendum was necessary.

Key passage(s)
• 'The word ['Constitution'] must mean the whole of the Constitution, and to restrict it to certain self-chosen parts would be inadmissible' (Lord Sankey).
• 'The true view is that, except where it otherwise provides, an Act of Parliament self-executing, is an exercise of sovereign power: but so far as a law made by a colonial legislature is not self-executing it, too, derives its force from express provisions in a Constitution which has been made by exercise of sovereign power.' (Lord Sankey).

cases.name: The UK Withdrawal from the European Union (Legal Continuity) (Scotland) Bill – A Reference by the Attorney General and the Advocate General for Scotland [2019] UKSC 64; [2019] 2 WLR 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• The UK Withdrawal from the European Union (Legal Continuity) (Scotland) Bill ('the Bill') was passed by the Scottish Parliament in response to Brexit.
• The Bill aimed to ensure legal continuity in Scotland post-Brexit by maintaining EU law in certain areas, and giving powers to Scottish Ministers to amend retained EU law.
• The Attorney General and the Advocate General for Scotland referred the Bill to the UK Supreme Court, arguing that certain provisions of the Bill were outside the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament.

Issues
• The key issue was the compatibility of the Bill with the UK's constitutional framework, in particular, the devolution settlement between the UK and Scotland.
• The UK Government argued that certain provisions of the Bill conflicted with the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 ('EUWA') and fell outside the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
• The Scottish Government argued that the Bill was within the competence of the Scottish Parliament under the Scotland Act 1998.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the majority of the Bill was within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament.
• However, certain provisions were deemed to be outside the legislative competence, as they either conflicted with the EUWA or related to reserved matters under the Scotland Act 1998.
• As a result, the Bill was partially invalidated, and only the provisions within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament remained in effect.

Key passage(s)
• 'We have concluded that a provision of the Scottish Bill would be outside the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament if it has the same subject matter of, or the same subject matter but a different purpose from, that of a provision of the [EU Withdrawal] Act' (per Lord Reed, para 62)
• 'The purpose of the Bill, in a case where there is a conflict between its provisions and those of the UK Act, is to provide a distinct and different scheme of retained EU law specific to Scotland.' - Lord Reed (para 69).

cases.name: R v Transport Secretary, ex parte Factortame [1990] 2 AC 85
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Factortame case involves a group of Spanish fishers ('Factortame Ltd') who operated in British waters under British-registered companies to avoid quotas under the Common Fisheries Policy.
• The UK government introduced the Merchant Shipping Act 1988 (MSA), which introduced a nationality requirement for British-registered fishing vessels and aimed to exclude non-British fishers to conserve fish stocks.
• Factortame challenged the legality of the MSA and sought interim relief, preventing the enforcement of the MSA while the case was pending.

Issues
• Factortame argued that the MSA's nationality requirement violated European Union (EU) law, specifically the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community (EEC), which guarantees the right of EU nationals to establish businesses in other member states.
• The UK government countered that the MSA was necessary and proportionate to protect fish stocks and that the court should not grant interim relief.
• The primary legal issue was whether UK courts could grant interim relief by suspending application of national legislation in breach of EU law.

Decision
• The House of Lords followed the guidance of the European Court of Justice (ECJ) and held that UK courts can grant interim relief, suspending the MSA's application while the case was pending.
• The decision established that EU law takes precedence over UK national law and that UK courts can order remedies, including interim relief, to safeguard EU law rights.

Key passage(s)
• '[T]he full effectiveness of Community law would be impaired if a rule of national law could prevent a court seised of a dispute governed by Community law from granting interim relief in order to ensure the full effectiveness of the judgment to be given on the existence of the rights claimed under Community law' - Lord Bridge of Harwich

cases.name: Town Investments v Department of the Environment [1978] AC 359
cases.summary:
Facts
• The plaintiff, Town Investments, attempted to purchase the London Employment Exchange Building after the government announced they were no longer vacant, as demanded by the 1969 White Paper.
• After finalizing the terms with the Ministry, the purchase price was agreed upon and the completion set for the 27th of October 1971. However, the disposal of the property was delayed due to a necessary statutory consent remaining outstanding.
• Town Investments alleged that the Department of Environment had breached their contract as they failed to complete the statutory transfer of the property.

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether the contract was enforceable, considering the nature of the parties involved and the powers bestowed upon the Department of Environment through statutory provisions.
• Town Investments argued that the contract was valid and enforceable, claiming equitable remedies for the breach.
• The Department of Environment (defendant) argued that the contract was not enforceable, as it was not authorized by any statutory powers and should be considered as an administrative act.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the contract was enforceable and not ultra vires (beyond the powers) of the public authority.
• According to the majority opinion, the Department of Environment had the power to enter into the contract under the statutory provisions mentioned in Schedule 3 of the Local Government, Planning and Land Act 1980.
• The court also noted that entering into a building contract could be considered an administrative act, however, in this case, it fell within the Department of Environment's statutory powers.

Key passage(s)
• 'The powers can be used...to make the administrative act effective' - Lord Wilberforce.
• 'When a corporation or a public authority (such as a County Council) is given power to contract, that power must, of necessity, have limits which will invite inquiry in a case near the borderline' - Lord Diplock.

cases.name: AG v. De Keyser’s Royal Hotel [1920] AC 508
cases.summary:
Facts
• The British government requisitioned part of De Keyser's Royal Hotel during World War I under the Defence of the Realm Act 1914 (DORA).
• The hotel owner claimed compensation under the DORA, but the government contended that it was entitled to requisition the property under the royal prerogative without compensation.

Issues
• The issue in question was whether the government could rely on the prerogative powers when there was a statutory duty (DORA) governing the same issue.
• The claimant argued that the government's reliance on the prerogative was inappropriate, and they should compensate them under DORA.
• Conversely, the government contended that it could choose between exercising its prerogative powers without compensation or applying DORA with compensation.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the government could not exercise its prerogative powers in a situation where a statute was enacted to deal with that specific situation (in this case, DORA).
• Therefore, the government must compensate the hotel owner as mandated by DORA.

Key passage(s)
• 'My Lords, I think that the proper course to pursue is, first, to inquire whether in any statutory enactment Parliament has provided a method by which the thing sought to be done by means of the Prerogative may be carried into effect; and, if such enactment is found, then the Crown must proceed by the Statute.' (Viscount Haldane)
• 'It seems to me that, inasmuch as the prerogative in question did exist in the Crown at the time when the Act of 1914 [DORA] was passed, one must construe that Act with reference to the existence of such prerogative.' (Lord Atkinson)

cases.name: Laker Airways Ltd. v. Department of Trade [1977] QB 643
cases.summary:
Facts
• Laker Airways Ltd., a British airline, sought judicial review of a decision made by the United Kingdom Department of Trade (the 'Department').
• The Department issued a directive to the British Airways Board, which effectively halted Laker Airways' proposed 'Skytrain' service between London and the United States.
• The Department argued that it had the legal authority to issue the directive as an exercise of its prerogative power.
• Laker Airways contended that the Department lacked such authority.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether the Department had the legal authority to issue the directive that halted Laker Airways' Skytrain service.
• Laker Airways argued that because it was operating under a valid Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) license, the Department had no authority to restrict its activities by way of prerogative power.
• The Department asserted that it was within its authority to issue the directive under its prerogative power to regulate international aviation policy.

Decision
• The Court held that the Department lacked the authority to issue the directive.
• It was determined that the Department's prerogative power did not extend to the domestic civil aviation sector, especially when there was a comprehensive statutory system in place that governed international aviation agreements.
• The Court argued that if the Department had been allowed to exercise its prerogative power, it would have effectively nullified the existing statutory system and the Civil Aviation Authority's (CAA) licensing process.

Key passage(s)
• 'Once a statute has been passed it prevails over any attempt by the executive to exercise the prerogative to the extent that the prerogative is inconsistent with the statute.' (Lord Denning MR)
• 'The prerogative can and should be curtailed, so as to achieve harmonious development of the law, consistently with the policy of the statute.' (Lord Denning MR)

cases.name: Malone v. Metropolitan Police Commissioner [1979] Ch. 344
cases.summary:
Facts
• Malone, the plaintiff, alleged that the police had tapped his telephone line unlawfully.
• He claimed that this violated his common law rights to privacy and was a breach of his human rights under the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).
• He brought an action against the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, seeking a declaration that telephone tapping was unlawful and an injunction to stop any further tapping.

Issues
• Malone argued that telephone tapping constituted an interference with his constitutional rights and was a violation of his administrative law rights.
• He further contended that it infringed his right to privacy under common law principles and amounted to a breach of his rights under the ECHR.
• The Commissioner argued that there was no legal basis for any such rights to privacy or against telephone tapping.

Decision
• The court held that there was no established common law right to privacy or a prohibition against telephone tapping and dismissed Malone's claim.
• The court found no violation of Malone's constitutional or administrative law rights, as telephone tapping was not prohibited by any statute or common law principle.
• The court also held that the ECHR did not provide a direct cause of action and thus offered no relief to Malone.

Key passage(s)
• 'In our law there is no separate civil action for breach of a person's privacy.' (Megarry V-C)
• 'The lack of an action for breach of privacy, therefore, does not lead me to create one to fill a perceived gap in our law.' (Megarry V-C)

cases.name: Ridge v Baldwin [1964] AC 40
cases.summary:
Facts
• Ridge v Baldwin [1964] AC 40 is a landmark constitutional and administrative law case in the United Kingdom.
• The case involved the dismissal of a police officer, Chief Constable Ridge, by the Brighton Watch Committee.
• Ridge's dismissal occurred after an inquiry was held where he was accused of corruption but was not given the opportunity to present his case or cross-examine witnesses.
• Ridge challenged the dismissal on the basis that natural justice had not been upheld.

Issues
• The key issue in this case was whether the doctrine of natural justice, specifically the right to be heard and to confront witnesses, applied to the dismissal of a police constable by a public authority.
• Ridge argued that his dismissal was unlawful because it breached natural justice principles.
• The Watch Committee argued that the rules of natural justice did not apply as the inquiry was administrative rather than judicial.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Ridge's dismissal was void because it breached the principles of natural justice.
• The court ruled that the doctrine of natural justice applied to the case because the Watch Committee, as a public authority, was exercising its quasi-judicial function.
• The court emphasized the importance of upholding the principles of natural justice, especially in cases that have a significant impact on an individual's rights and reputation.
• This decision significantly impacted English administrative law and established the need to adhere to natural justice principles in public authority actions where individuals' rights are at stake.

Key passage(s)
• 'The deciding body must act judicially. They must deal with the question referred to them without bias, and they must give to each party the opportunity of adequately presenting the case made.' (Lord Reid)
• 'In determining whether or not it [the deciding body] has complied with the law, I apprehend that the court must necessarily inquire what it did.' (Lord Morris)

cases.name: Anisminic Ltd v. Foreign Compensation Commission [1969] 2 AC 147
cases.summary:
Facts
• Anisminic Ltd, a British mining company, claimed compensation from the Foreign Compensation Commission for loss suffered due to the nationalization of their mining operations in Egypt under the Foreign Compensation Act 1950.
• The Foreign Compensation Commission, under powers granted by an Order in Council, issued a Determination Order which decided that Anisminic was not entitled to compensation because the company did not have 'property' in Egypt at the relevant time.
• Anisminic sought judicial review to challenge the determination.
• The legislation governing the Foreign Compensation Commission contained an 'ouster clause' stating that the determination was 'not subject to appeal or liable to be questioned in any court of law'.

Issues
• Anisminic argued that the ouster clause did not prevent the courts from exercising judicial review and that the Foreign Compensation Commission had made an error of law in interpreting the legislation governing its powers.
• The Foreign Compensation Commission argued that the ouster clause rendered its decisions immune from judicial review.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the ouster clause did not oust the jurisdiction of the courts to review the determination of the Foreign Compensation Commission.
• The court found that the determination made by the Foreign Compensation Commission was based on an error of law and was therefore void, allowing the courts to exercise judicial review.
• The court expressed that the ouster clause could only apply to a valid determination by the Foreign Compensation Commission.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is true that there are authorities which support the view that a provision, like the conclusiveness provision in the present case, should be read as referring to the valid decisions of a tribunal and that decisions which are in fact unlawful, as distinct from mistaken, are necessarily excluded.' (Lord Reid)

cases.name: Council of Civil Service Unions v Minister for the Civil Service (GCHQ case) [1985] AC 374
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1984, the Minister for the Civil Service, on behalf of the government, issued a notice restricting the rights of employees at the Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ) to join or consult with Civil Service trade unions.
• The restrictions were made based on national security concerns.
• The Council of Civil Service Unions (CCSU) challenged the Minister's decision as unlawful.

Issues
• The CCSU argued that the decision was (1) an unlawful breach of legitimate expectations, as employees had an understanding that their right to belong to trade unions would be protected;
• and (2) that the Minister had failed to consult with the trade unions before issuing the notice, which breached the duty to act fairly.
• In defence, the Minister argued that the decision was within the scope of the prerogative powers due to national security concerns, and therefore non-justiciable and not subject to judicial review.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the restrictions placed on GCHQ employees' trade union rights were lawful. Although the decision was an exercise of the prerogative powers, it was subject to judicial review as it affected individual rights.
• However, the Court ruled that national security concerns justified the government's decision, even though the Court also found a breach of the duty to consult trade unions.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is not…a sufficient answer to say that judicial review of the actions of the officers of the executive and of the lower courts is always available for any error of law. That is certainly true. But it leaves unanswered the question whether the individual who is affected by the error has a remedy.'(Lord Diplock)
• 'A decision…is subject to judicial review if the subject matter of the decision is amenable to the judicial process. The question whether it is amenable to the judicial process depends on its nature.'(Lord Roskill)

cases.name: Porter v Magill [2001] UKHL 67, [2002] 2 AC 357
cases.summary:
Facts
• Porter v Magill [2001] UKHL 67 was a constitutional and administrative law case that involved a politically biased housing policy.
• The case arose from the London Borough of Westminster's (the council) decision in 1987 to sell a majority of its council flats to tenants, influenced by the political bias of the council's leader, Dame Shirley Porter, and her deputy, David Weeks.
• This strategy was aimed at increasing the Conservative voting population in marginal wards, ahead of local elections.
• The council also falsely described the policy as a means of generating funds to repair and maintain its housing stock.
• The District Auditor found Dame Shirley Porter and David Weeks guilty of wilful misconduct and surcharged them £31 million.

Issues
• The key issues before the House of Lords were whether the scheme was improperly motivated by political bias, and whether the councillors could be held personally liable for wilful misconduct.
• Dame Shirley Porter and David Weeks argued that the sale of council flats was within the council's legal powers, and that political considerations did not constitute misconduct.
• The District Auditor argued that the councillors acted with improper purposes and breached their fiduciary duties to the council, which amounted to wilful misconduct.

Decision
• The House of Lords unanimously held that the councillors were guilty of wilful misconduct for their politically biased housing policy.
• The court found that Dame Shirley Porter and David Weeks had misused their powers for an ulterior political purpose, and breached their fiduciary duty by acting dishonestly.
• The councillors were ordered to pay the surcharge, which was later reduced to £12 million on appeal.

Key passage(s)
• 'In my opinion, if councillors, in exercising their powers, are influenced by some ulterior motive (such as a desire to achieve advantage for their political party) and act accordingly, their conduct will be improper, even if, leaving aside the ulterior motive, it could be seen as rational; and it will be for the courts so to declare.' - Lord Bingham (para 103)

cases.name: R (Osborn) v Parole Board [2013] UKSC 61, [2014] AC 1115
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R (Osborn) v Parole Board [2013] UKSC 61, [2014] AC 1115, two prisoners who were serving indeterminate sentences for public protection (IPP) sought judicial review of the Parole Board's decisions not to recommend their release or transfer to open conditions.
• Both prisoners had committed serious offences, but their minimum terms were relatively short and had expired.
• The Parole Board refused their requests on the basis of written dossiers without holding a hearing or giving reasons for its decisions.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the Parole Board had breached the prisoners' right to a fair hearing under Article 5(4) of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) and common law principles of procedural fairness.
• The Parole Board argued that there was no such duty as the decisions had no significant impact on the prisoners as long as they continue to present an unacceptable risk to public safety.
• The prisoners argued that they were entitled to a hearing to challenge the information in the dossiers and the risk assessments.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court unanimously held that the Parole Board had breached the prisoners' right to a fair hearing under Article 5(4) ECHR and common law principles of procedural fairness.
• The court established that a hearing was required when its outcome may have a real bearing on the determination of a prisoner's liberty and the grounds for concluding that there was such an issue were not evidently without substance.
• The court also found that the Parole Board's failure to give reasons for its decisions was a breach of procedural fairness as it prevented the prisoners from effectively challenging the decisions.

Key passage(s)
• 'First and foremost, the common law imposes a duty to act fairly… the duty to act fairly is therefore inherent in the constitutional relationship between the judicial branch of government and the individual.' (Lord Reed)
• 'The right to a fair hearing is not only a fundamental common law right, but also a fundamental aspect of the rule of law.' (Lord Hope)

cases.name: Lewis v Attorney-General of Jamaica [2001] 2 AC 50
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Lewis v Attorney-General of Jamaica [2001] 2 AC 50, the appellants were convicted of murder and sentenced to death in Jamaica.
• Following their convictions, their cases were reviewed by both the Jamaican Court of Appeal and the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council.
• The Privy Council advised Her Majesty The Queen to recommend that their death penalties be commuted to life imprisonment, but the Jamaican Governor-General exercised his discretion and upheld the death sentences.
• The appellants applied for judicial review of the Governor-General's decision.

Issues
• The appellants argued that their constitutional rights to seek clemency under section 90(1) of the Jamaica (Constitution) Order in Council and to an impartial and independent administrative process had been violated by the Governor-General's failure to follow the advice of the Privy Council.
• The Attorney-General argued that the exercise of the Governor-General's discretion was not justiciable, i.e. not subject to judicial review, because it concerned matters of royal prerogative and was a non-reviewable executive decision.

Decision
• The case reached the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, which held that the Governor-General's decision was subject to judicial review after finding that it fell within the scope of appropriate administrative matters and affected the appellants' rights.
• The court further held that if the Governor-General's decision was found to be tainted by unfairness, bias, or unlawfulness, it could be quashed on judicial review, and the appellants would be entitled to a fair and independent clemency process.
• Ultimately, the Privy Council found that the constitutional rights of the appellants had been breached, and their death sentences were commuted to life imprisonment.

Key passage(s)
• 'It has never been doubted that an exercise of the royal prerogative is subject to judicial review' - [Lord Slynn of Hadley]

cases.name: Wheeler v Leicester CC [1985] AC 1054
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case of Wheeler v Leicester CC (1985) involved the Leicester City Council (local authority) imposing a ban on two rugby clubs from using its facilities due to their decision not to cancel a tour in apartheid South Africa.
• The local authority took this action in line with its political stance against apartheid.

Issues
• The case raised the question of whether the local authority had acted ultra vires (beyond its powers) by making this decision based on political reasons.
• The appellants (rugby clubs) argued that there was no proper basis for the ban under administrative law as it constituted political discrimination.
• The respondents (Leicester City Council) argued that it was within their powers to take this decision, and that it was a rational decision in pursuit of a legitimate policy objective.

Decision
• The House of Lords (HL) held that the local authority had acted ultra vires and had unreasonably imposed the ban.
• The decision was found to be an unlawful exercise of power, as it was based on political discrimination rather than any relevant considerations appropriate to administrative law.
• Consequently, the ban was quashed.

Key passage(s)
• 'Their Lordships held that the denial of the facilities at the sports centre for the purpose of opposing apartheid amounted to imposing a political condition which was neither necessary nor expedient for the promotion of the use of the sports centre.' - Lord Fraser of Tullybelton
• 'The general rule is that neither the adoption of political policies, nor the enforcement of them as such, is within the province of a local authority.' - Lord Scarman
• 'In the instant case, the council’s decision did not rest merely on the design of a political attitude. It proceeded to enforce the policy by denying their facilities to the appellants.' - Lord Brandon of Oakbrook

cases.name: R v S of S for Education, ex p Begbie [2000] 1 WLR 1115
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Secretary of State for Education, ex parte Begbie (2000) 1 WLR 1115 is a constitutional and administrative law case concerning school selection.
• The applicant, Begbie, challenged the government's withdrawal of a policy that allowed children living near grant-maintained schools to gain admission to them after taking a selective entrance test.
• The policy withdrawal was included on a policy manual published to give effect to a new law on school admissions, which aimed to establish fair and open access to all schools irrespective of a child's background or circumstances.

Issues
• Begbie argued that the policy withdrawal amounted to a substantive change in the law and required an affirmative resolution of Parliament.
• The Secretary of State for Education maintained that it was a mere change in policy and did not need parliamentary approval.

Decision
• The court held that among other things, stating a new policy did not necessarily amount to laying down a mandatory rule, even if it had legal consequences.
• The policy withdrawal was simply a change in policy, and the legislature did not require that Parliament approve of every change in policy.
• Furthermore, the policy manual did not purport to create new legal rules, but instead gave guidance on how to correctly apply existing statutory provisions.
• For these reasons, the court found in favor of the Secretary of State and held that the policy withdrawal did not need parliamentary approval.

Key passage(s)
• 'A minister's statement of policy... may not be taken as laying down a mandatory rule to which, by law, he is himself bound' (Lord Woolf).
• 'If administrative policy, announced by ministers, were capable of creating a mandatory rule of law, which could be enforced in the ordinary courts, many of the ministerial proposals which are the stuff of party politics could only be made legally effective with the consent of Parliament' (Simon Brown LJ).

cases.name: R v S of S for the Home Dept, ex p Doody [1994] 1 AC 531
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v S of S for the Home Dept, ex p Doody [1994] 1 AC 531, a group of prisoners were serving life sentences for murder.
• The Secretary of State, who has the power to determine the length of time a life-sentenced prisoner must serve before being released on parole, increased the minimum term to be served by the prisoners, but did not disclose the reasons for the increases.
• The prisoners sought judicial review of the Secretary of State's decision not to disclose the reasons for their increased sentences.

Issues
• The prisoners argued that they had a common law right to be informed of the reasons for the Secretary of State's decision and to make representations before their sentences were increased.
• The Secretary of State argued that there was no such common law right and that he had unfettered discretion in determining sentencing policy.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that, under the principles of the common law, people have a right to be heard before a decision adversely affecting them is made ('audi alteram partem'). This right includes an opportunity to make representations to a relevant authority.
• The Court also held that the prisoners had a right to know the reasons for the increased sentences in order to effectively exercise their right to make representations.
• In consequence, the decision to increase the sentences without disclosing reasons was quashed.

Key passage(s)
• In the words of Lord Mustill (at 564): 'I see no reason why [...] the prisoner should not be informed in clear and simple terms what it is recommended he should serve, even if he is not also told of the reasoning leading to the recommendation; for without this information he is deprived of the substance of his common law right [...]'

cases.name: R v Ministry of Defence, ex p Smith [1996] QB 517
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Applicants, four former members of the Royal Navy, challenged their dismissal from military service after they were investigated and their homosexuality was confirmed.
• MOD policy at the time stipulated that homosexuals were not to be employed in the Armed Forces.

Issues
• Applicants argued their dismissal was unjustified, homophobic, and contravened their rights under the European Convention on Human Rights, particularly the right to respect for private life (Article 8).
• They sought judicial review of their dismissal, contending that the ban was irrational as it was not based on a legitimate aim.
• The Ministry of Defence (MOD) maintained the policy was necessary for maintaining operational effectiveness and morale within the military.

Decision
