• The Court of Appeal held that the ban was a breach of Article 8 of the Convention and was not justified in that it pursued a legitimate aim.
• The court further held that the MOD failed to provide evidence showing a rational connection between the ban and any of its objectives of military efficiency, morale, and discipline.
• The dismissal was held to be unlawful, discriminatory, and irrational.

Key passage(s)
• 'In my judgment, the policy of the Ministry of Defence to refuse to employ any homosexual men or women in Her Majesty's Armed Forces is unlawful. It cannot any longer be justified, if ever it could. It infringes the human rights of those men and women of homosexual orientation who are prepared to serve their country.' (Lord Justice Staughton)

cases.name: Barnard v National Dock Labour Board [1953] 2 QB 18
cases.summary:
Facts
• Barnard, a registered dock worker, was summarily dismissed by the National Dock Labour Board (NDLB) without any opportunity for a hearing or appeal.
• Barnard brought an action against the NDLB, claiming that his dismissal was unconstitutional, as it was contrary to natural justice and amounted to a wrongful interference with his employment.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether the NDLB, a statutory body, had acted unconstitutionally by not providing Barnard with a fair hearing and due process before dismissing him.
• Barnard argued that the NDLB's decision to dismiss him without a hearing amounted to a breach of the rules of natural justice, violating his right to a fair hearing.
• The NDLB countered that it had acted within its powers, and its actions were in accordance with its statutory mandate.

Decision
• The court held that the NDLB had acted unconstitutionally in dismissing Barnard without a hearing, as there was a breach of the rules of natural justice.
• The dismissal was therefore set aside, and Barnard was reinstated in his position.
• The NDLB was required to provide Barnard with a fair hearing before deciding whether to dismiss him.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is now well settled that a person in the position of the plaintiff, whose privileges and interests are invaded by a decision arrived at after following some recognised course of procedure, should have the opportunity of stating his case before the tribunal which has to make that decision.' (Lord Denning)

cases.name: R v Foreign Secretary, ex p World Development Movement [1995] 1 WLR 386
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Foreign Secretary, ex p World Development Movement [1995] 1 WLR 386 is a UK administrative law case involving the overseas aid provided by the UK government.
• The World Development Movement (WDM), a non-governmental organization, sought judicial review of the Foreign Secretary's decision to grant aid (£234 million) for a hydroelectric dam project in Malaysia.
• WDM argued that the decision was made for improper purposes, which included influencing the Malaysian government to award a construction contract to a UK company.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether the decision to grant aid was ultra vires (beyond the legal power or authority).
• WDM argued that the aid was not justified under the Overseas Development and Co-operation Act 1980, which states the purpose of such aid should be to promote the economic development and welfare of developing countries.
• The Foreign Secretary countered that the decision was made for proper purposes and was within the scope of his powers.

Decision
• The court found in favor of the Foreign Secretary and dismissed the application for judicial review.
• The court held that the decision to grant aid was within the Foreign Secretary's authority and the fact that it may have had an additional purpose (such as winning the construction contract) did not make the decision ultra vires.
• The court emphasized the importance of the doctrine of the separation of powers, expressing reluctance to interfere in policy decisions made by elected officials.

Key passage(s)
• 'Judicial review is concerned, not with the decision, but with the decision-making process' (Lord Justice Rose).
• 'If a public officer abuses his power, he may be restrained. But the authority of the court is a purely indirect one. It depends on being able to isolate some legal ground for asserting the decision was ill-founded' (Lord Justice Rose).

cases.name: Elgizouli v Secretary of State for the Home Department [2020] UKSC 10; [2020] 2 WLR 857
cases.summary:
Facts
• Elgizouli challenged the decision of the Secretary of State for the Home Department to provide mutual legal assistance (MLA) to the United States in prosecuting UK citizens (Kotey and El-Sheikh) for terrorist activities, without seeking assurance that the death penalty would not be imposed.
• The appellant's child, El-Sheikh, was allegedly involved in four different murders in Syria.
• The UK government agreed to provide evidence to the United States without seeking death penalty assurances, due to national security concerns.

Issues
• The appellant argued that the Secretary of State's decision violated the common law principle that the UK should not facilitate the execution of a death sentence abroad (Soering v United Kingdom (1989) 11 EHRR 439).
• The Secretary of State argued that there is no absolute prohibition on cooperation in death penalty cases and that the decision was a lawful exercise of executive discretion.
• The appellant also argued that the data transfer violated the Data Protection Act 2018 ('DPA').

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the Secretary of State's decision was unlawful because the provision of MLA constituted the processing of personal data and the transfer was not in accordance with DPA Part 3, Chapter 3.
• The court found that the Secretary of State had not sought appropriate safeguards concerning the information's transfer.
• The common law principle argument was not resolved, as the decision was made on statutory grounds.

Key passage(s)
• 'In this case, where Parliament has addressed the very issues about which the appellant seeks to invoke a common law constraint on executive power, I am not persuaded that the substance of the common law constraint could or should survive the statutory scheme.' - Lady Hale (para 83)

cases.name: Ghaidan v Godin-Mendoza [2004] UKHL 30
cases.summary:
Facts
• Ghaidan v Godin-Mendoza [2004] UKHL 30 is a leading House of Lords case on the interpretation of statutes.
• The plaintiff, Ghaidan, was the landlord of a property occupied by the defendant, Godin-Mendoza, who was the surviving partner of a same-sex couple.
• After the death of the plaintiff's original tenant, the defendant claimed statutory protection under the Rent Act 1977, which provides that the spouse of a deceased tenant who had been living with the tenant as husband and wife has a right to succeed the tenancy.
• The objective was to ascertain whether the protection applied to same-sex partners.

Issues
• Ghaidan (the landlord) argued that the Rent Act 1977 did not apply to same-sex partners, while Godin-Mendoza (the tenant) argued that it did.
• The case was a test of the application of the Human Rights Act 1998, which requires courts to read and interpret legislation so far as it is possible, in a way that is compatible with the Convention rights.

Decision
• The House of Lords, in a unanimous decision, held that the Rent Act 1977 could be read to include same-sex couples, as it would otherwise be incompatible with the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), specifically Article 8 (right to respect for private and family life) and Article 14 (prohibition of discrimination).
• Relying upon the principle established in R v Offen [2001] 1 WLR 253, the court applied a purposive interpretation to the Rent Act 1977 to protect same-sex couples.
• This decision demonstrates the flexibility of statutory interpretation under the Human Rights Act 1998.

Key passage(s)
• 'The real question in the present case is not how far section 3 of the 1998 Act permits the court to depart from the unambiguous wording of a statute but how far it requires the court to do so' - Lord Nicholls.
• 'It is a cardinal principle of our legal order that a judicial decision must be a reasoned decision: an argument must be stated before it can be refuted, and the argument for the other side may contain something unanticipated' - Lord Steyn.

cases.name: Kennedy v The Charity Commissioner [2014] UKSC 20
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Charity Commission, an independent regulator of charities in England and Wales, conducted a statutory inquiry into the affairs of a charity, which was regarded as confidential.
• Kennedy, a journalist, requested information related to the inquiry under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA).
• Most documents were disclosed but, relying on exemptions in FOIA, some were withheld by the Commission.
• Kennedy claimed the exemptions were not justified and appealed the Commission's decision.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the exemptions relied upon by the Charity Commission were justified.
• Kennedy argued that FOIA granted him access to the documents, and it is in the public interest to disclose them.
• The Charity Commission argued that the exemptions in FOIA protected the documents from disclosure, particularly those related to ongoing investigations.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court ruled in favour of the Charity Commission.
• The Court held that the exemptions in FOIA were justified and that there was no public interest override that would require the disclosure of these documents.
• The Court emphasized the importance of maintaining the confidentiality of information in ongoing investigations, particularly in relation to charities.

Key passage(s)
• 'There are obvious reasons why the Charity Commission might have thought it in the public interest for information which would enable other charities to circumvent its inquiries to be withheld rather than generally disclosed.' (Lord Toulson)
• 'While there may be strong public interest arguments in favour of disclosure [...] this will not always be true, and the Court's task is to weigh the public interest arguments on each side of the scale.' (Lord Hughes)
• 'The exemptions provided for in the Freedom of Information Act are clearly necessary for the proper functioning of public bodies and the investigatory role of the Charity Commission would inevitably be undermined if documents were released indiscriminately to the public.' (Lord Sumption)

cases.name: R v Hughes [2013] UKSC 56
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendant, Hughes, drove a car without a valid licence or insurance, contrary to the Road Traffic Act 1988.
• The prosecution argued that the deceased was driving a motorcycle while under the influence of heroin and suddenly drove onto the wrong side of the road into the path of Hughes' vehicle.
• The collision resulted in the death of the motorcyclist.
• Hughes was charged with causing death by driving while unlicensed, disqualified or uninsured pursuant to s.3ZB(1) of the Road Traffic Act 1988.

Issues
• The issue at hand was whether a causal link must be established between the defendant's act of driving without a valid licence or insurance and the death of the victim (i.e., whether Hughes' driving was a substantial cause of the death of the deceased).
• The prosecution argued that no such causal link is required, while the defence maintained that causation must be proved.
• The case of R v Williams [2010] 1 Cr App R 33 was closely considered since it dealt with similar issues relating to causation in a driving scenario.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that causation was required to be proved.
• Hughes' conviction was set aside, as there was no evidence to suggest that his driving contributed to the death of the motorcyclist.
• The court found that the victim's own driving was the sole cause of the collision and subsequent death.

Key passage(s)
• 'Where A's driving is blameless there is in ordinary language, no sense in which it can properly be said that it caused another's death.' - Lord Mance

cases.name: R v Wallace [2018] EWCA Crim 690
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendant, Berlinah Wallace, was convicted of throwing a corrosive substance with intent to burn, maim, disfigure, disable or do grievous bodily harm (GBH), contrary to s 29(1)(a) of the Offences Against the Person Act 1861.
• The victim was her former partner.
• The substance did not burn or cause immediate pain but soaked into the victim's skin and caused severe injuries, and the victim chose to end his life by euthanasia.

Issues
• The issue was mens rea in relation to the offense committed.
• The Crown argued that the defendant intended to cause GBH by throwing the corrosive substance at the victim.
• The defendant argued that her intention was only to distress and humiliate the victim and not to cause physical harm.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal dismissed the defendant's appeal.
• The court considered the decisions in DPP v Armstrong [2000] Crim LR 379 and R v Wint [2012] EWCA Crim 1356, and concluded that criminal liability did not require an intention to cause the specific form of harm or injury that resulted from the defendant's actions.
• It was sufficient if the defendant foresaw the possibility of some harm and that harm was grievous.
• The jurors were entitled to find the defendant guilty based on her culpable foresight of serious harm.

Key passage(s)
• '[I]t is submitted that the appellant threw the substance intending to disfigure and thus to distress and humiliate, but not to cause pain or any injury falling within s 20. That submission is simply not open on the facts of this case' (Gross LJ).
• 'On the facts of this case, the specific nature of the injury was of no consequence; the jury were clearly entitled to find that this appellant foresaw that the liquid she was hurling at the complainant would cause really serious bodily harm or wounding' (Gross LJ).

cases.name: R v Evans [2009] EWCA Crim 650
cases.summary:
{Facts
• In R v Evans [2009] EWCA Crim 650, an English criminal case, the appellant Gemma Evans (GE) supplied her half-sister Carly Townsend (CT) with heroin.
• CT self-administered the drug in the presence of GE, who did not intervene.
• GE later found CT unconscious from the drug but, rather than calling for medical assistance, she went to work and left CT in bed.
• CT died without recovering consciousness, and GE was charged with manslaughter by gross negligence.

Issues
• The key issue was whether GE owed a duty of care to CT as to render GE's actions grossly negligent, and thus amount to manslaughter.
• The prosecution argued that GE's failure to act constituted a breach of a duty of care because she foresaw CT's death as a potential consequence.
• The defence contended that there was no duty of care since GE had not administered the drug to CT herself.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal upheld GE’s conviction for gross negligence manslaughter.
• The court held that GE owed a duty of care to CT because GE had both supplied the heroin and was present when CT self-administered it.
• The court found that GE had ample opportunity to call for medical help when it became clear that CT was in distress, but she failed to do so.
• The court concluded that GE's breach of the duty of care amounted to gross negligence, thereby warranting the conviction for manslaughter.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is...unrealistic, in the singularly tragic circumstances of the present case, to suggest that there was no duty owed by the appellant to her sister...She had ample opportunity to call for medical help as a responsible person.' ([2009] EWCA Crim 650, per Lord Judge LCJ)

cases.name: Environment Agency v Empress Car Company (Abertillery) Ltd [1999] 2 AC 22
cases.summary:
Facts
• Empress Car Company (Abertillery) Ltd ('Empress') was a car-servicing company that stored polluting chemicals onsite.
• One day, chemicals accidentally flowed from their premises into a nearby stream, causing pollution.
• Empress was prosecuted under section 85(1) of the Water Resources Act 1991 (the Act) for causing poisonous, noxious or polluting matter to enter a controlled watercourse without consent.

Issues
• Did the defendant's actions fall within the meaning of the offence under the Act?
• Did the defendant have to intend to cause pollution for it to be culpable?
• The prosecution argued that the defendant's operation of their business resulted in a pollution incident, so they should be held responsible regardless of whether they intended to cause the pollution or not.
• Empress argued that it did not intend to cause pollution, and the incident was the result of an accident.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Empress was guilty of the offence under section 85(1) of the Act, even though it did not intend to cause pollution.
• The offence was one of strict liability, meaning that the accused company would be held responsible for causing the pollution, regardless of their state of mind.

Key passage(s)
• 'In order to establish a causal link the prosecution has to prove that the defendant by a positive act, itself amounting to a breach of some duty of care or foresight, brought about a state of affairs which caused poisonous, noxious or polluting matter to enter the water.' - Lord Hoffman

cases.name: R v Roberts (1972) 56 Cr.App.R 95
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Roberts (1972) 56 Cr.App.R 95, the defendant, Barry Keith Roberts, and the victim, a 21-year-old woman, were in a car together drinking after leaving a party.
• Defendant made aggressive sexual advances towards the victim.
• Fearing the defendant's assault, the victim jumped out of the moving car and injured herself.
• Defendant was charged and convicted of assault occasioning actual bodily harm under Section 47 of the Offenses Against the Person Act 1861.

Issues
• The defendant argued that his actions did not amount to an assault as the injuries were a result of the victim's voluntary action in jumping from the car.
• The prosecution maintained that the defendant's aggressive behavior constituted an assault and the victim's injuries were a direct result of her trying to escape the defendant's advances.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal upheld the conviction.
• The court held that if a person is placed in a position of apparent imminent danger and acts in response to it, then the defendant is liable for any injury which results from their actions.
• The defendant's behavior was an assault, and his aggressive sexual advances were the cause of the victim's decision to jump out of the car and suffer injury.

Key passage(s)
• 'If a person is placed in a position of apparent imminent danger to safety and he cannot escape and wishes to but cannot fend it off by force, it would be very strange indeed if he were not entitled to say that the injuries which he received are only attributable to the acts of the aggressor' - (Lord Justice Edmund Davies).

cases.name: R v Cheshire [1991] 1 WLR 844
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendant, Cheshire, shot the victim in a fast-food restaurant.
• The victim underwent surgery to remove the bullet but experienced complications, such as difficulty breathing, which required a tracheostomy (surgical creation of an opening in the windpipe).
• A junior surgeon performed the tracheostomy but failed to detect an obstruction in the windpipe, which subsequently led to the victim's death.

Issues
• The defendant argued that the victim's death was not a result of the shooting but due to the medical treatment afterward.
• The prosecution argued that the shooting was a significant cause of death, despite the medical negligence.

Decision
• The Court upheld the conviction for murder. They held that the shooting was an operating and substantial cause of death, even though medical treatment was also a significant factor.
• The Court found that the medical treatment did not break the chain of causation because the defendant's actions created the need for the treatment in the first place and the treatment was not 'independent of, and uninfluenced by' his actions.
• The Court built upon R v Jordan (1956) and R v Smith (1959) which established that medical treatment will only break the chain of causation if it is 'palpably wrong' or 'wholly independent' of the defendant's actions.

Key passage(s)
• 'Even though negligence in the treatment of the victim was the immediate cause of his death, the jury were entitled to find that his wounds were a cause of his death...If at the time of death the original wound was still an operating cause and a substantial cause, then the death can properly be said to be the result of the wound.' (Lord Lane CJ)

cases.name: R v Pagett [1983] 76 Cr. App.R. 279
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Pagett [1983] 76 Cr. App.R. 279 was a case involving the defendant Pagett who had used his pregnant girlfriend as a human shield while exchanging gunfire with the police.
• Pagett's girlfriend was fatally shot by the police who were trying to apprehend Pagett for an unrelated crime.
• Pagett was charged with manslaughter and appealed the conviction.

Issues
• The key issue in this case was whether Pagett's actions constituted the actus reus (the 'guilty act') necessary for a conviction of manslaughter.
• The defence argued that because the police officer's bullet was the cause of death, Pagett's conduct was not the legal cause (causation) of his girlfriend's death.
• The prosecution argued that Pagett's actions were the legal cause of death as they had created a dangerous situation that led to the fatal shooting.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal dismissed Pagett's appeal and upheld the conviction.
• The court found that Pagett's actions were a 'substantial and operating cause' of his girlfriend's death.
• The court also held that the police officer's actions were not a novus actus interveniens (a new independent act that breaks the chain of causation).

Key passage(s)
• 'In our judgment what he [Pagett] did was a cause of the death of the innocent young girl and the officers fired and killed her in conscionable performance of their duty' (Lord Lane CJ).

cases.name: R v Miller [1983] 2 AC 161
cases.summary:
Facts
• Miller, a vagrant, was sleeping in a vacant building when he accidently caused a mattress to catch fire.
• Instead of extinguishing the fire, Miller moved to another room, leaving the fire unattended.
• The fire spread, causing extensive damage to the property.
• Miller was charged with arson under Section 1(1) of the Criminal Damage Act 1971.

Issues
• The prosecution argued that Miller's failure to act, known as an omission, amounted to the mens rea (mental element) of recklessness, which is required for the offence of arson.
• The defence argued that Miller's omission could not form the mens rea for the offence since he did not intend to cause the damage.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Miller's omission did amount to recklessness, convicting him of arson.
• The court ruled that Miller's initial inadvertent creation of a dangerous situation gave rise to a duty of care to act to prevent further harm, which he breached by failing to extinguish the fire.
• As a result, his failure to act constituted the mens rea for the offence of arson.

Key passage(s)
• 'The creation of the danger caused a duty to act to arise. The accused's failure to deal with the situation was a breach of the duty which he had himself created. He was therefore reckless within the meaning of Section 1 of the 1971 Act.' (Lord Diplock)
• 'If it had been anyone other than the appellant who had started the fire – a mere passerby who had seen the fire and failed to put it out – the argument on the mens rea for arson would not have run; but a person who starts a fire is in a much more vulnerable position than a passerby.' (Lord Edmund-Davies)

cases.name: R v G and R [2003] UKHL 50
cases.summary:
Facts
• Two boys, aged 11 and 12, were found guilty of arson under the Criminal Damage Act 1971.
• They had started a fire after going into a shop and playing with lighters.
• The fire spread and caused extensive damage to the shop and surrounding properties.
• The trial judge ruled that the jury could convict on the basis of subjective or objective recklessness, following the test laid down in R v Caldwell [1982] (subjective test), and the boys' appeals were dismissed by the Court of Appeal.

Issues
• The House of Lords had to reconsider the test for recklessness in light of the defendants' age and cognitive ability.
• The appellants argued that the test in Caldwell was not appropriate, and the test should be a subjective one, based on what the defendants themselves were aware of or could foresee.
• The respondent argued that the Caldwell test should continue to apply, which would mean the defendants could be found reckless if they had not given any thought to the risk or had recognised the risk and chosen to take it.

Decision
• The House of Lords agreed with the appellants, ruling that the test for recklessness should be subjective, based on what the defendants were actually aware of.
• They held that the Caldwell test was contrary to the basic principles of criminal law and should be abandoned.
• The court established a new test for recklessness, which was whether the defendant had actually exposed others to a risk and recognised that risk.

Key passage(s)
• 'The criminal law generally assumes the existence of free will. It is fitting that it should do so, because the assumption reflects the innate sense of individual responsibility which every normal person feels.' (Lord Bingham)
• 'The effect of Caldwell is to impose criminal liability for 'reckless' damage to property on one who gives no thought to the risk although, if he had given thought to it, he would have recognised it as one he was running. That is not a sensible interpretation of the language of the statute.' (Lord Steyn)

cases.name: R v Heard [2007] EWCA Crim 125
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Heard [2007] EWCA Crim 125 involved an appeal against a conviction for assault occasioning actual bodily harm (s47 Offences Against the Person Act 1861).
• The appellant, Mr. Heard, was extremely drunk at the time of the assault.
• He had no recollection of the event and insisted he had no intention to cause harm.

Issues
• The main issue was whether Mr. Heard's drunken state negated the mens rea (mental element) required for the offence.
• The appellant argued that his drunkenness meant he lacked the necessary intent to cause harm.
• The prosecution argued that Mr. Heard's intoxication did not prevent him from forming the requisite mens rea, as it was not wholly attributable to an external factor (e.g., spiked drinks) and he should be held responsible for his actions regardless of his level of intoxication. They cited cases such as R v Sheehan and Moore [1975] and R v Caldwell [1981].

Decision
• The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal.
• It held that voluntary intoxication cannot negate the mens rea for an offence like assault occasioning actual bodily harm, where the mens rea is recklessness rather than a specific intent.
• The court reasoned that the policy of the law should be to hold individuals who are reckless in getting drunk and then committing crimes responsible for their actions.

Key passage(s)
• 'The policy of the law is not to allow a defendant who voluntarily drinks himself into a state of incapacity to rely on that incapacity as a defence to a charge of specific intent, unless there is something in the facts relevant to the elements of the defendant's intent over and above his intoxication.' (Latham LJ)

cases.name: R v G [2008] UKHL 37
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v G [2008] UKHL 37, the appellant had sex with a 15-year-old girl, who was more than three years younger than him.
• Despite the fact that she willingly went to bed with him and he believed her to be over the age of consent, she was underage, and did not have legal capacity to consent to intercourse.
• The appellant was charged with rape under the Sexual Offences Act 2003 (SOA 2003).

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether the appellant's belief that the girl was of legal age to consent was a reasonable one, making this a case about the necessary mens rea (mental element) for rape.
• The prosecution argued that the appellant's belief was not reasonable, as he had not taken sufficient steps to ascertain the girl's age.
• The defence contended that the girl had actively misled him and that he had been mistaken in good faith.

Decision
• The House of Lords (now the Supreme Court) held that the appellant's belief in the girl's age was not relevant, as the requirement of 'reasonableness' applied to the belief he had in her consent, not her age.
• The court reasoned that the policy aim of the SOA 2003 was to protect young people from sexual exploitation, and allowing a defendant's subjective belief in age to suffice as a defence would undermine this goal.
• The appellant's conviction for rape was therefore upheld.

Key passage(s)
• 'If Parliament had intended to create [a] defence in relation to either of the reasonable belief provisions, it is, in my opinion, most likely that it would have made express provision for it.' (Lord Carswell)

cases.name: R v Thabo Meli [1954] 1 WLR 228
cases.summary:
Facts
• In the case R v Thabo Meli, the defendants had decided to kill a man, Simunya, as an act of ritual murder.
• They lured him to a remote location, assaulted him, and left him unconscious, believing him to be dead.
• To avoid suspicion, they rolled his body down a cliff to make it appear as an accidental fall.
• However, it was discovered that Simunya was still alive after the defendants left, and he later died due to exposure and the resultant effects of the fall, rather than from the initial assault.

Issues
• The prosecution argued that the defendants had the intention (mens rea) to commit murder and carried out an act (actus reus) contributing to the victim's death, so they should be convicted of murder.
• The defence argued that because the mens rea and actus reus were not simultaneous, the defendants should not be held responsible for the murder.

Decision
• The Privy Council, comprised of Lords Reid, Tucker, and Morris, upheld the murder convictions.
• The court held that there is no strict requirement for mens rea and actus reus to occur simultaneously.
• The Lords held that the defendants' actions were part of a 'series of acts or a transaction constituting the offence'.
• The intended results (Simunya's death) and the planned acts (the assault) were sufficiently connected for the court to establish liability.
• It did not matter that the individual parts that made up the sequence of events were separate or temporally distant.

Key passage(s)
• 'We do not think that [the sequence argument] can any longer be supported. In our opinion the appellant's actings formed a series of acts which led up to the deceased's death and which were done with the intention of causing that death.' (Lord Reid)

cases.name: R v AG Ref (no. 3 of 1994) [1998] AC 245
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v AG Ref (No. 3 of 1994) [1998] AC 245, a man stabbed his pregnant girlfriend, resulting in premature labour and the eventual death of the child four months later due to injuries sustained during the attack. It was not disputed that the attacker deliberately intended to harm the mother.
• At the time of the attack, the foetus was 16 weeks old, and according to medical evidence, incapable of being born alive. The attacker was charged with murder and causing grievous bodily harm to the foetus.

Issues
• The issues before the cases were whether a person could be guilty of murder for causing the death of a child born alive due to injuries suffered while still in foetus, and whether English law recognizes a crime of causing grievous bodily harm to a foetus.
• The prosecution argued that the defendant should be found guilty of murder because the child was born alive and the defendant's unlawful act ultimately caused its death.
• The defence contended that the defendant could not be found guilty of murder because the foetus was not a human being when the act was committed and the Crimes Against the Person Act did not specifically mention the term 'child' or 'foetus'.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that a person can be convicted of murder if their unlawful act causes a child to be born alive with injuries sustained in the womb, and the child subsequently dies from those injuries.
• The Court also found that a person cannot be guilty of causing grievous bodily harm to a foetus because such an offence is not recognized by English law.

Key passage(s)
• 'Where, as in the present case, the victim was a person in being, albeit an unborn child, when the injury was inflicted, and was subsequently born alive, the fact that the victim was not a person in being at the time the injury was inflicted is irrelevant' (Lord Mustill)

cases.name: R v Clinton [2012] EWCA Crim 2
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Clinton [2012] EWCA Crim 2 concerned the appeal of a man, Clinton, against his conviction for murder.
• The defendant had killed his wife after finding out about her adultery and her taunting him about it.
• At trial, the judge ruled that the defence of 'loss of control' (a partial defence to murder under s.54 and 55 of the Coroners and Justice Act 2009) was unavailable to the defendant because the alleged trigger for his loss of control, adultery, was specifically excluded by s.55(6)(c) of the Act.
• The defendant was convicted of murder and appealed on the basis that he should have been allowed to raise the defence.

Issues
• The Court of Appeal was required to consider whether the judge had been correct in ruling that the loss of control defence was unavailable, given the adultery exclusion in s.55(6)(c) of the Act.
• The prosecution argued that the trial judge was correct in excluding the defence, given the clear wording of the statute.
• The defendant argued that the exclusion should not have applied in the particular circumstances.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the trial judge had been wrong to exclude the defence in the circumstances.
• The Court looked beyond the specific exclusion and found that it was the wider circumstances of the case, and not just the adultery, that led to the loss of control.
• As such, it was for the jury, not the judge, to determine whether the defence applied.
• Clinton's conviction was quashed and a retrial ordered.

Key passage(s)
• 'If sub-section 55(6)(c) is read and applied literally, we are satisfied that, especially in combination with section 54(4), an anomaly or unfairness might arise in the circumstances of a particular case, such as in the present case, where the circumstances to which paragraphs (a) or (b) applied were of sufficient gravity in all the circumstances as to not undermine Parliament's intention in enacting section 55(6)' (Lord Judge LCJ)

cases.name: R v Rejmanski [2017] EWCA Crim 2061
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Rejmanski, pled guilty to murder and sought to appeal the conviction, claiming that he should have been convicted of manslaughter based on diminished responsibility, under the Homicide Act 1957.
• The appellant's drug use at the time of the murder caused a psychotic state, during which he killed the victim.
• Expert witnesses for the defence and prosecution agreed that if the psychosis was brought on only by his voluntary drug use, diminished responsibility would not apply.
• However, if the appellant had a pre-existing susceptibility to psychosis that was triggered by drug use, diminished responsibility could be applicable.

Issues
• The appellant argued that, as a result of his pre-existing vulnerability to mental illness, his drug use caused the psychosis which led to the killing, thus making the diminished responsibility plea relevant.
• The Crown's argument was that the psychosis was solely due to voluntary self-induced drug use, and therefore diminished responsibility should not apply.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, upholding the murder conviction.
• The court found that, even if the appellant had a pre-existing vulnerability, this vulnerability did not amount to an 'abnormality of mental functioning' that would allow the diminished responsibility defence to be applicable.
• This decision highlighted that even if there was both a pre-existing susceptibility and a triggering event, they must combine to create a substantial impairment in the defendant's mental responsibility for their actions to satisfy the test for diminished responsibility.

Key passage(s)
• 'When considering the nature and extent of the appellant's existing mental state ... we are unable to conclude that it amounted to an abnormality of mental functioning within the meaning of s.2(1) of the Homicide Act 1957.' (Davis LJ)

cases.name: R v Asmelash [2013] EWCA Crim 157
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Asmelash [2013] EWCA Crim 157 was a criminal murder case where the defendant, Mr. Asmelash, had an extensive history of alcohol abuse and raised a defence of diminished responsibility.
• He killed the victim by strangulation in a drunken state.
• At trial, the jury rejected his defence and Mr. Asmelash was convicted of murder.

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether voluntary drunkenness could be considered when assessing diminished responsibility, more specifically if drunkenness could contribute to an abnormality of mental functioning.
• The defence argued that Mr. Asmelash's long history of alcohol abuse had caused permanent physical and mental impairments, which coupled with his intoxicated state at the time of the killing, amounted to diminished responsibility.
• The Crown argued that voluntary drunkenness should not be considered when assessing diminished responsibility as intoxication can impair someone’s mental function.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that voluntary drunkenness alone cannot form the basis of a diminished responsibility defence, but it can be considered if there is a pre-existing condition that is substantially caused or exacerbated by the intoxication.
• In this case, the court found no evidence that Mr. Asmelash's voluntary drunkenness had significantly impaired his mental functioning, so his diminished responsibility defence was rejected.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Judge LCJ: 'If the only feature of the case bearing on responsibility is...voluntary drunkenness or...voluntary consumption of other substances, then that condition cannot provide the basis...for establishing that the defendant's responsibility for killing was diminished.'
• Lord Judge LCJ: 'If the facts proved in a particular case disclose that, by reason of the alcoholic dependency, the defendant experienced a substantially different effect...on his mental faculties than he might have expected if he had been sober, then diminished responsibility may be available.'

cases.name: R v Dowds [2012] EWCA Crim 281
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Dowds [2012] EWCA Crim 281, the defendant, Terence Dowds, killed his partner by stabbing her with a knife.
• At his trial for murder, Dowds did not deny the killing but claimed diminished responsibility based on his severe intoxication due to excessive alcohol consumption on the night of the killing.
• The judge ruled that voluntary intoxication, standing alone, could not amount to an abnormality of the mind under the partial defence of diminished responsibility.
• Unsurprisingly, the jury found Dowds guilty of murder, and he appealed.

Issues
• The issue before the Court of Appeal was whether severe voluntary intoxication could, by itself, amount to an exceptional circumstance providing evidence of an abnormality of mental functioning (AMF) within the scope of the defence of diminished responsibility under the Coroners and Justice Act 2009, s. 2(1).
• The appellant argued that the new statutory test of diminished responsibility should be interpreted broadly, to include voluntary intoxication.
• The Crown, on the other hand, argued that Parliament had not intended to include voluntary intoxication as a basis for diminished responsibility, and that this had been made clear in the Law Commission's reports preceding the legislation.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, holding that voluntary intoxication, even if extreme, could not amount to an AMF for the purpose of diminished responsibility under s. 2(1) of the 2009 Act.
• The Court found that there was no need for a jury to consider whether the appellant was suffering from an AMF arising solely from his intoxication, as this was not an abnormality of mental functioning as required by the statute.
• In reaching its decision, the Court relied on the Law Commission's report and the historical treatment of voluntary intoxication in the context of diminished responsibility.

Key passage(s)
• 'Parliament did not intend the term “abnormality of mental functioning” in section 2(1) to cover an abnormality of mental functioning induced by voluntary consumption of alcohol.' (Lord Judge LCJ)

cases.name: R v Golds [2016] UKSC 61
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Golds [2016] UKSC 61 deals with the statutory interpretation of the phrase 'abnormality of mental functioning' in the context of the partial defence of diminished responsibility to a charge of murder.
• Golds was convicted of murder; he then appealed on the grounds that the trial judge misdirected the jury regarding the diminished responsibility partial defence.

Issues
• The significant issue in this case was the interpretation of the phrase 'abnormality of mental functioning' contained in the Homicide Act 1957 (HA 1957), as amended by the Coroners and Justice Act 2009 (CJA 2009).
• Should the phrase be limited by any requirement of substantiality?
• The appellant argued that the judge, in interpreting the phrase, had given too much emphasis to the 'substantial impairment of the ability' element by using the term 'truly exceptional', which did not belong in the statutory test.
• The Crown contended that the judge's direction was equivalent to the Gough [1954] standard, involving a 'judicial gloss' on the statute.

Decision
• The Supreme Court upheld the murder conviction.
• It was found that the trial judge did not misdirect the jury by using the term 'truly exceptional.'
• The term was held to be an appropriate way for the jury to understand the concept of 'abnormality of mental functioning' when required by the statutory language of HA 1957 and CJA 2009.
• The interpretation of the phrase was not confined to truly exceptional cases but required a substantial impairment of mental function to satisfy the statutory test.

Key passage(s)
• 'It may be that in some cases the description abnormality of mental functioning may provide the jury with an escape route, but that accords with the conscience of society, which is reflected in the statutory language.' (Lord Hughes)

cases.name: R v Church [1966] 1 QB 59
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendant, Church, had a quarrel with a woman in a van.
• He knocked her unconscious, believing her to be dead, and threw her body into a river.
• The woman drowned and Church was charged with her manslaughter.

Issues
• Was Church's act of throwing the woman's body into the river an unlawful and dangerous act, sufficient to support a charge of manslaughter?
• The prosecution argued that an unlawful and dangerous act causing death is enough to establish manslaughter.
• The defence argued that only an intentional act causing death or serious injury could satisfy the mens rea for manslaughter.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the trial judge had not correctly directed the jury on the test for an unlawful act manslaughter.
• A new test was laid down: an unlawful act will be sufficient for manslaughter if it is dangerous, in that it carries a risk of causing some harm to someone, although it need not be serious harm.
• The Court concluded that the act of throwing an unconscious person into a river was clearly an unlawful and dangerous act.
• Church's conviction for manslaughter was therefore upheld.

Key passage
• 'A sober and reasonable person would inevitably realise that it carried with it the risk of some harm to the [victim], short of killing her. It is enough that they would recognize that the act was one which all sober and reasonable people would inevitably recognise must subject the other person to, at least, the risk of some harm resulting therefrom, albeit not serious harm': Lord Parker CJ

cases.name: R v Kuddus [2019] EWCA Crim 837
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Kuddus was a case before the England and Wales Court of Appeal (Criminal Division) in 2019.
• The defendants were convicted of gross negligence manslaughter after a customer with a peanut allergy died from an anaphylactic shock upon consuming a meal prepared by the defendants.
• The customer had explicitly informed the defendants of his allergy in his takeaway order.
• At first instance, the judge ruled that the defendants breached their duty of care in providing food that was not safe for the customer.

Issues
• The defendants appealed the conviction, arguing that they did not owe a duty of care to the customer because the relationship between the parties was too remote.
• The prosecution contended that there was a clear duty of care as food businesses have obligations under food safety laws.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal affirmed the conviction, holding that a duty of care did exist.
• The court reasoned that the defendants were aware of the customer's allergy, and it was reasonably foreseeable that providing food containing peanuts could cause serious harm to the customer.
• The court also referenced the Food Safety Act 1990 and the general health and safety duties owed by food businesses.

Key passage(s)
• '[We] conclude that the duty of care existed and extended to the taking of reasonable care to avoid subjecting the appellant's customers to reasonably foreseeable risks of injury of the kind this appellant suffered. [The] duty of care forms part of the regulatory offence which the Defendants had already admitted.' (Lord Justice Haddon-Cave)

cases.name: R v BM [2018] EWCA Crim 560
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, known as BM, was convicted under s20 of the Offences Against the Person Act 1861 for causing grievous bodily harm without lawful excuse.
• BM, a body modification practitioner, conducted three procedures on consenting individuals that resulted in harm, specifically: a tongue splitting, an ear removal, and a nipple removal.
• Consent was a central issue as the surgeries were not authorized by medical professionals and were not considered medical treatment.

Issues
• The appellant argued that the consent of the individuals involved should provide a lawful excuse for the harm caused.
• The Crown argued that an individual cannot consent to intentional harm unless an exception, such as a properly regulated surgical intervention, applies.
• The appellant also relied on R v Wilson [1996] and R v Dica [2004], arguing for a distinction between harm from tattoos, piercings, and consensual violence in sports.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the appellant's actions were indeed unlawful, and consent could not provide a lawful excuse in this context.
• The Court found that the medical treatment exception did not apply as the procedures were not medically justified or carried out by a registered medical practitioner.
• The Court rejected the analogy to tattooing and cosmetic piercing and distinguished the rulings in Wilson and Dica.

Key passage(s)
• 'The causing of really serious harm for no good reason is a crime. The fact that, in particular circumstances, a person may wish to do it to himself or have it done to another is not a reason for any different legal outcome.' (Lord Justice (LJ) Holroyde)
• 'Absent a good reason or legitimate excuse for the harm that was caused, it was not in the public interest that people should try to cause serious harm for no good reason.' (LJ Holroyde)

cases.name: R v Dica [2004] EWCA Crim 1103
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Dica ([2004] EWCA Crim 1103) is a landmark criminal law case concerning the transmission of HIV.
• The defendant, Mohammed Dica, had unprotected sex with two women without informing them that he was HIV positive.
• Both women subsequently contracted HIV and reported the defendant to the police, leading to his prosecution under s.20 of the Offences against the Person Act 1861 for inflicting grievous bodily harm (GBH).
• The trial judge directed the jury that if the women decided to have unprotected sex with Dica, even if they were unaware of his HIV status, they were consenting to the risk of becoming infected.
• On that basis, the defendant was acquitted.

Issues
• The Crown appealed the trial judge's ruling on consent, arguing that the women could not consent to the risk of becoming infected because Dica failed to inform them of his HIV status.
• The defendant argued that the trial judge's direction on consent was correct, as the women had chosen to have unprotected sex and thus had consented to the risk of transmission.
• The appeal court had to decide whether non-disclosure of HIV status essentially vitiated the victims' purported consent.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal allowed the Crown's appeal, quashed the acquittal, and ordered a retrial.
• The court ruled that the trial judge's direction on consent was wrong and that non-disclosure of HIV status would be sufficient to vitiate consent to sexual intercourse, potentially rendering the defendant's actions criminally reckless.
• Following R v Clarence (1888), the court determined that consent must be genuine and can be invalidated by misrepresentation or deception.

Key passage
• 'In a case such as this, in which a person has consensual sex knowing that he is suffering from the HIV virus without disclosing that fact to his partner, the transmission of the HIV virus is guilty of an offence contrary to s.20 if he transmits the virus to her' (Lord Woolf CJ).

cases.name: R v Konzani [2005] EWCA Crim 706
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Konzani [2005] EWCA Crim 706, involved an appeal by Feston Konzani, who was charged with causing grievous bodily harm (s20 of the Offences Against the Person Act 1861) by transmitting HIV.
• The defendant was aware of his HIV-positive status but failed to disclose it to three women he engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse with - each of them contracted the virus.
• The defendant claimed that the consent of the victims to unprotected sex purged his liability for the dangerous act.

Issues
• The central issue was whether consent to unprotected intercourse where the other party was unaware of their partner's HIV-positive status could negate the actus reus (guilty act) of the offence in question.
• The argument of the Crown was that, like in R v Dica [2004] EWCA Crim 1103, there can be no valid consent in such circumstances, which characterised the defendant's conduct as a 'dangerous act'.
• The defence maintained that the women's consent to unprotected sex constituted a voluntary assumption of risk, thus negating the actus reus of the offence.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, holding that consent to unprotected intercourse was not an answer to s20 of the Offences Against the Person Act 1861 in the absence of knowledge by the victims of Konzani's HIV status.
• The court reasoned that consent cannot negate the actus reus, where the defendant engaged in a culpable, dangerous activity and knew of the risk but failed to communicate it.

Key passage(s)
• 'Genuine voluntary consent to the risk of a harmful activity does not necessarily negative the required element of the actus reus for an offence under s 20 of the 1861 Act' (Lord Justice Judge).
• 'In order to make a voluntary choice the person must be in possession of sufficient information on which to base a decision' (Lord Justice Mantell).

cases.name: R v Jheeta [2007] EWCA Crim 1699
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendant, Jheeta, was convicted of ten counts of incitement to sexual assault by penetration and six counts of incitement to rape.
• Jheeta created fictitious personas via email to deceive his victim, a woman with whom he was in a relationship, into performing sexual acts on him.
• The victim believed she was being instructed by the defendant's alter ego, who claimed to be a secret government operative.

Issues
• Jheeta’s main defence was that the victim had consented to the sexual acts.
• The prosecution argued that consent obtained through deception is not valid.
• The appeal hinged on the legal definition of consent as it pertains to deception, specifically in the context of rape and sexual assault.

Decision
• The court quashed the convictions for counts of incitement to sexual assault by penetration and incitement to rape.
• The court held that the deception did not relate to the nature or purpose of the act, but to the identity of the person instructing the acts.
• The court relied on previous cases, including R v Linekar [1995] QB 250, which established that consent remains valid as long as the deception does not relate to the nature and purpose of the act.

Key passage(s)
• '...where a representation is made as to the person's own state of mind, the law will continue to regard consent obtained in that way as true consent.' (Lord Justice Thomas)

cases.name: Assange v Swedish Prosecution Authority [2011] EWHC 2849 (Admin)
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case Assange v Swedish Prosecution Authority (2011) involved the founder of WikiLeaks, Julian Assange.
• Assange was accused of committing sexual offenses in Sweden in 2010, including one count of unlawful coercion, two counts of sexual molestation, and one count of rape.
• The Swedish Prosecution Authority issued a European Arrest Warrant (EAW) for Assange's extradition to Sweden to face the charges.
• Assange challenged the validity of the EAW before the UK courts.

Issues
• Julian Assange argued that the EAW was invalid for several reasons:
- The Swedish prosecutor did not have the 'judicial authority' to issue an EAW.
- He had not been accused of any offenses, only suspected.
- The extradition was not necessary or proportionate as Swedish authorities could have questioned him in the UK.
• The Swedish Prosecution Authority argued that the EAW was valid, and Assange should be extradited to face the charges.

Decision
• The High Court rejected Assange's arguments and held that the extradition was lawful as per the European Extradition Act (2003).
• It was ruled that the Swedish prosecutor did have the 'judicial authority' to issue an EAW, and that Assange was accused of a crime and not merely suspected.
• The court found that the extradition was necessary and proportionate since Assange was a flight risk and had failed to cooperate with the Swedish authorities.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Justice Thomas and Mr. Justice Ouseley:
- 'If the conduct alleged here in relation to the EAW [...] had taken place in the United Kingdom and Mr Assange were a British citizen, there would be no doubt whatsoever that this conduct would constitute a very serious crime that would clearly be triable in this jurisdiction.' (para 159)

cases.name: R v McNally [2013] EWCA Crim 1051, [2014] QB 593
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v McNally [2013] EWCA Crim 1051, [2014] QB 593, the defendant, McNally, was born female but identified as male and engaged in a sexual relationship with the complainant under the male persona.
• The complainant thought she was engaging in a heterosexual relationship and only discovered the true nature of McNally's gender after the end of their relationship.
• McNally was charged with and convicted of sexual assault.

Issues
• The main issue for the Court of Appeal was whether McNally's deception as to gender identity vitiated the complainant's consent to sexual activity, thus constituting sexual assault under the Sexual Offences Act 2003 (SOA 2003).
• McNally's argument was that the complainant's consent was valid despite her deception as to her gender identity, and therefore there was no sexual assault under the SOA 2003.
• The prosecution argued that McNally's deception as to her gender was sufficient to render the complainant's consent invalid in law.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal upheld McNally's conviction for sexual assault, holding that her deception as to her gender identity was a material fact that went to the very nature of the sexual act.
• The court concluded that the complainant's consent was vitiated by the defendant's deception, and thus, McNally's conduct constituted sexual assault under the SOA 2003.

Key passage(s)
• 'There are, no doubt, many cases where the proposition that lies do not necessarily vitiate apparent consent remains sound, but there are cases where the lies go to the nature of the act or the identity of the perpetrator, or both, where the law is clear that such deceit does, as a matter of law, vitiate consent' (Lord Judge CJ).

cases.name: R (Monica) v DPP, ex pte Boyling [2018] EWHC 3508 (Admin), [2019] QB 1019
cases.summary:
Facts
• In this case, R (Monica) v DPP, ex pte Boyling [2018] EWHC 3508 (Admin), [2019] QB 1019, a former undercover police officer, Jim Boyling, had a sexual relationship with a woman, Monica, while carrying out covert operations.
• After his true identity was revealed, Monica claimed that the sexual relationship amounted to a criminal offence under the Sexual Offences Act 2003.
• The Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) decided not to prosecute Boyling on the basis that it was not in the public interest.
• Monica challenged this decision through judicial review.

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether an undercover police officer's conduct, in having a sexual relationship with a target, could amount to a criminal offence under the Sexual Offences Act 2003.
• Monica argued that Boyling's actions constituted 'misconduct in public office,' while the DPP contended that it did not meet the necessary elements for such an offence.

Decision
• The High Court dismissed Monica's challenge.
• The court held that the DPP's decision not to prosecute was rational and lawful, as there was insufficient evidence to establish that Boyling's conduct amounted to a criminal offence.
• The court recognized the importance of public interest considerations, including the need to maintain public trust in the police force and ensure effective undercover policing, but ultimately held that these considerations did not warrant criminalizing Boyling's actions in this case.

Key passage(s)
• 'The obtaining of consent to sexual activity through an abuse of position does not involve the commission of an offence under the Sexual Offences Act 2003.' (Gross LJ)

cases.name: R v Lawrance [2020] EWCA Crim 971
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Lawrance [2020] EWCA Crim 971, the defendant, Jason Lawrance, had sexual intercourse with the complainant, known as 'C', on two occasions.
• On the first occasion, Lawrance explicitly agreed to withdraw (ejaculate) before climax.
• However, he did not withdraw on the second occasion.
• C, at the time, could conceivably become pregnant.

Issues
• The central question in this case concerned whether Lawrance's deception about withdrawing before climax could vitiate C's consent to having sexual intercourse, and hence constitute rape.
• The Prosecution argued that this deception was similar to cases where individuals lie about their fertility or use of contraception, which might vitiate consent.
• The Defence argued that this deception did not operate at the point where consent was obtained but related to circumstances after obtaining consent.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal quashed Lawrance's conviction, concluding that his deception did not vitiate C's consent to the sexual act in question.
• In reaching this conclusion, the Court drew a distinction between deceptions that vitiate consent and those that do not, as laid down in R v Assange [2011] EWHC 2790 (Admin).
• The Court held that in this case, the deception by Lawrance did not operate at the point of obtaining consent, but rather after consent was given.

Key passage(s)
• '[We] are concerned with the commission of a criminal offence, and it is not appropriate to attach criminality to every breach of a highly nuanced and fact-specific agreement made by two consenting parties... The appellant's behaviour is morally and socially unacceptable behaviour, but we do not consider that the appellant's failure to withdraw amounted to a deception that vitiated the complainant's consent to sexual intercourse' (Lord Burnett CJ).

cases.name: R v Saik [2006] UKHL 18
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Saik, was convicted of money laundering under the Criminal Justice Act 1988 (CJA).
• He was accused of providing financial facilities to criminals for transferring illegal funds.
• In compliance with the CJA, he was proven guilty of having reasonable grounds to suspect that the funds to be transferred were the proceeds of drug trafficking.

Issues
• The appellant appealed, arguing that a conviction under the CJA required actual knowledge that the funds were criminal proceeds, not mere suspicion.
• The prosecution argued that the Act only required reasonable grounds to suspect, not actual knowledge.

Decision
• The House of Lords dismissed the appeal, confirming that the CJA did not require actual knowledge of the funds' criminal origin.
• It held that a conviction could be secured where the defendant had reasonable grounds for suspicion based on objectively assessed circumstances.

Key passage(s)
• 'That seems to me to underline the fact that the relevant mens rea under section 93A(1) is suspicion based on reasonable grounds, rather than knowledge or indeed suspicion based on knowledge of facts which, if actually known to the defendant, would lead to the guilty mind in question.' - Lord Hope (para. 59)

cases.name: R v Pace and Rogers [2014] EWCA Crim 186
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendants, Pace and Rogers, were partners in a business that stored and sold scrap metal.
• They were prosecuted under the Scrap Metal Dealers Act 1964 for receiving stolen scrap metal, knowing or believing it to be stolen.
• At trial, the prosecution argued that the defendants had bought the metal from an undercover police officer for less than its true value, thereby acquiring the metal with the knowledge or belief that it was stolen.

Issues
• The issue before the court was whether the statutory phrase 'knowing or believing' in the Scrap Metal Dealers Act 1964 required any subjective mens rea (mental element) on the part of the defendants, or whether it was simply enough that they ought to have known or believed that the metal was stolen.
• The prosecution argued that 'knowing or believing' constituted an objective test, while the defendants contended that it required a subjective element.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the proper interpretation of 'knowing or believing' in the Scrap Metal Dealers Act 1964 was an entirely subjective test.
• It required proof that the defendants actually knew or believed the metal to be stolen; it was not enough that they ought to have known or believed.
• Accordingly, the court quashed the defendants' convictions as the trial judge had not properly directed the jury on this issue of statutory interpretation.

Key passage(s)
'We have come to the clear conclusion that the natural and ordinary meaning of the words 'knowing' and 'believing' does not include 'ought to have known' or 'ought to have believed'... The conviction of both appellants accordingly must be quashed.' (Lord Justice Davis)

cases.name: R v Williams (Gladstone) [1984] 78 CrAppR 276
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Williams (Gladstone) was a case involving an attempted theft and assault.
• Williams, the defendant, noticed a struggle between a man and a woman and mistakenly believed that the man was assaulting the woman.
• He intervened by using force against the man, but it later transpired that the man was trying to gain possession of his own property, which the woman had earlier stolen.
• Williams was charged with assault.

Issues
• The main issue in this case revolved around whether Williams's mistaken belief justified his use of force against the man.
• The prosecution argued that Williams's mistake was not a lawful excuse for his actions, as he used excessive force in the situation.
• The defence argued that Williams's genuine belief in the need to use force to protect the woman and the fact that he used reasonable force in light of the circumstances made his actions legally justifiable.

Decision
• The court decided in favor of Williams, stating that a genuine error in judgment that led to the mistaken use of force in self-defence or defence of another could provide a lawful excuse for assault.
• The judgment confirmed that the level of force used by Williams was not excessive in light of his mistaken belief.
• The court also emphasized that the defendant's mistake must be judged on the particular facts of each case and not on an objective standard of reasonableness.

Key passage(s)
• 'The golden rule is that the degree of force used must be proportionate to the circumstances as the defendant honestly believed them to be' (Lord Justice Waller).

cases.name: R v Riddell [2017] EWCA Crim 413
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Riddell, was charged with blackmail under section 21(1) of the Theft Act 1968, after sending threatening letters to his former partner and demanding money.
• Riddell claimed that the demands he made were conditional on certain conditions being met.
• He was convicted and appealed, arguing that Conditional Intention required a different mens rea (mental element).

Issues
• The appellant argued that there was a requirement of 'unwarranted demand' under section 21(1) and that conditional demands do not meet this criterion.
• Additionally, the appellant argued that there was a separate requirement of mens rea (mental element) when it came to conditional intention.
• The Crown argued that 'unwarranted demand' had nothing to do with conditional demands, and a threat could still be deemed unwarranted even if it was subject to conditions being met.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal (Criminal Division) upheld the conviction, finding that the appellant's demand was indeed unwarranted under section 21(1).
• The court also clarified that the mens rea for conditional intention was the same as that for unconditional intention, rejecting the appellant's argument.
• Consequently, the requirement of mens rea remained unaltered by the conditions set, and the appellant's conviction was not quashed.

Key passage(s)
• 'Even if the demand contains a proviso or is in some way conditional, the simple issue for the jury will always be whether that condition, or proviso, turns that which would otherwise be an unwarranted demand into a warranted one' (Lord Justice Hickinbottom).
• 'In cases of a conditional threat, there is no reason why the existing tests for mens rea cannot accommodate the circumstance in which the conditions are not fulfilled, and the defendant does not intend that they should be' (Lord Justice Hickinbottom).

cases.name: R v Hudson & Taylor [1971] 2 QB 202
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendants, Hudson and Taylor, were young women working in a factory where they witnessed a serious assault.
• After reporting the incident to the police, they received death threats from the assailant's associates.
• They were called to testify in court, but due to the threats, they committed perjury (both lied under oath) to avoid identifying the assailant.
• The defendants were convicted of committing perjury and appealed their conviction on the ground of duress.

Issues
• The central issue was whether the defence of duress by threats could be applied to the crime of perjury.
• The defendants argued that due to the death threats and genuine fear for their lives, they had no other choice but to commit perjury, thus claiming duress as a defence.
• The prosecution argued that the defence of duress cannot be applied to perjury and that the defendants had other alternatives available to them instead of lying under oath.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the defence of duress was available for the crime of perjury, quashing the defendants' convictions.
• The decision was based on the genuine fear of death or serious injury, the imminence of the threat, and the lack of reasonable alternatives for the defendants to avoid committing perjury.
• The court distinguished this case from R v Howe (1987), where duress was not allowed as a defence for murder, by emphasizing the defendants' limited options in the current scenario.

Key passage(s)
• 'The basic question is whether this defence should in principle be available in cases of perjury, and we can see no valid reason for its exclusion.' (Lord Justice Edmund-Davies)
• 'In a case of duress the jury should decide whether the defendant acted as a result of reasonably fearing death or serious injury from the threats and whether a person of reasonable firmness sharing the defendant's actual characteristics would similarly act as the defendant did.' (Lord Chief Justice Widgery)

cases.name: R v Quayle and others [2005] EWCA Crim 1415
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Quayle and others [2005] EWCA Crim 1415, the defendants were charged with various offences relating to cannabis.
• They argued that they used cannabis to alleviate chronic pain or nausea arising from medical conditions.
• At trial, they sought to rely on the defence of necessity.

Issues
• The principal issue was whether necessity could be a valid defence to the offences.
• The defendants argued that their actions were necessary due to their medical conditions and the failure of conventional treatments to address their symptoms.
• The prosecution contended that necessity was not a valid defence to drug offences.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the defence of necessity was not available in cases involving possession or cultivation of cannabis.
• The Court followed R v Reardin [1996] Cr App R 1, where a similar argument for necessity had been rejected in the context of a Class A drug.
• The Court reasoned that the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971 reflected Parliament's decision to criminalise certain drugs and did not provide for a defence of necessity. Consequently, courts should not create such a defence.

Key passage(s)
• 'It would, in our judgment, be wrong in principle for this court in the context of the criminal law to interpret such a carefully graduated legislative scheme on the basis that it was open to a defendant in possession of one of the controlled drugs to set himself up as the judge of the medical necessity for the leading prohibited drug so as to claim a ground of necessity via a means, a defence to criminal prosecution.' (Latham LJ)

cases.name: R v Hasan [2005] UKHL 22, [2005] 2 WLR 709
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendant, Safak Hasan, stabbed the victim during a burglary upon instruction from his accomplice, Bennett.
• Hasan alleged he had been stationed there under duress; Bennett, an organized crime associate, had threatened both Hasan and his partner if he refused.
• A jury convicted Hasan of wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm (GBH) and burglary. Hasan appealed.

Issues
• Hasan argued the trial judge erred in ruling the defence of duress unavailable.
• The Crown argued that, due to Hassan's voluntary participation in organized crime, the defence of duress should not be applicable.

Decision
• The House of Lords upheld the conviction and held that the defence of duress was not available to Hassan.
• The court reasoned that Hasan's knowledge of Bennett's criminal activities and willingness to associate with him denied him the duress defence.
• The court acknowledged that the public interest in discouraging criminal association supports a restrictive approach to the duress defence.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Bingham of Cornhill: 'A person who voluntarily and with knowledge of its nature associates with a combination of persons engaged in criminal activities, thus becoming a member of an organized criminal group, cannot rely on the defence of duress if he commits an offence in response to orders given in the course of carrying out the activities of the group, so as to avoid criminal responsibility for that offence.'

cases.name: R v Morris [1984] AC 320
cases.summary:
Facts
• R v Morris involved two defendants who were caught dishonestly taking items from a supermarket shelf, switching the price labels, and then paying the lower price at the checkout.
• They were subsequently charged with theft under section 1(1) of the Theft Act 1968, which provides that a person is guilty of theft if they dishonestly appropriate property belonging to another with the intention of permanently depriving the other of it.
• The trial judge directed the jury to consider whether the defendants' conduct amounted to an 'appropriation' and whether they had an intention to permanently deprive the supermarket of the items.
• The jury found the defendants guilty, and they appealed their convictions on the grounds that their actions did not amount to an appropriation under the Theft Act 1968.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether the defendants' conduct amounted to an 'appropriation' under section 3(1) of the Theft Act 1968, which states that an appropriation occurs when 'any assumption by a person of the rights of an owner amounts to an appropriation'.
• The defendants argued that their actions did not involve an assumption of the supermarket's property rights, since they merely interfered with the pricing labels and paid for the items.
• The prosecution contended that the defendants' conduct involved an assumption of the supermarket's property rights by taking exclusive control and possession of the items and paying a lower price for them.

Decision
• The House of Lords upheld the defendants' convictions, finding that their conduct amounted to an appropriation.
• The court held that the defendants' interference with the pricing labels and subsequent purchase of the items at a lower price involved an assertion of a right to deal with the items as though they were the owner.
• This amounted to an appropriation under section 3(1) of the Theft Act 1968, and the defendants were therefore guilty of theft.

Key passage(s)
• 'What the appellant did in this case amounted in our opinion to an appropriation. By substituting... the price ticket...the appellant was doing an act which was plainly an assertion of a right in the property inconsistent with the rights of the owner.' (Lord Roskill)

cases.name: Ivey v Genting Casinos (UK) Ltd [2017] UKSC 63
cases.summary:
Facts
• Phil Ivey, a professional gambler, won £7.7 million playing a card game (Punto Banco) at a casino in London, operated by Genting Casinos.
• Ivey used a technique called 'edge sorting', which involved exploiting defects on the back of playing cards, allowing him to identify card values before they were flipped.
• Genting refused to pay Ivey his winnings, claiming he cheated.
• The Court of Appeal upheld the finding that Ivey cheated and his actions were dishonest.

Issues
• The main issue was whether Ivey's actions amounted to dishonesty or cheating under sections 42 of the Gambling Act 2005.
• Genting argued that the test for dishonesty established by R v Ghosh [1982] QB 1053 was not required as the Gambling Act had a separate, objective standard for cheating.
• Ivey argued that the Ghosh test, a two-stage test requiring subjective and objective dishonesty, was the correct test to apply.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Ivey's appeal, finding his actions amounted to cheating under the Gambling Act 2005.
• The court held that the Ghosh test was no longer the appropriate test for dishonesty in criminal law.
• Instead, the court adopted a single, objective test, requiring only that Ivey's behaviour be dishonest by the standards of ordinary, reasonable people.

Key passage(s)
• 'When dishonesty is in question the fact-finding tribunal must first ascertain (subjectively) the actual state of the individual's knowledge or belief as to the facts.' (Lord Hughes)
• 'The question whether the conduct was honest or dishonest is to be determined by the fact-finder by applying the (objective) standards of ordinary decent people. There is no requirement that the defendant must appreciate that what he has done is, by those standards, dishonest.' (Lord Hughes)

cases.name: R v Valujevs [2014] EWCA Crim 2888
cases.summary:
Facts
• The defendants were charged with conspiracy to commit fraud by false representation under the Fraud Act 2006, Section 1, after deliberately deceiving the immigration authorities to accelerate the process of securing permanent residence in the United Kingdom.
• They created false employment histories and wage slips, showing they had been employed when they had not.
• The defendants argued they did not have the required mens rea (guilty mind) for conviction because they had been wrongly advised by their lawyers.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the defendants had the mens rea for the crime.
• The prosecution argued that it was met, as the defendants had an intention to deceive the immigration authorities by providing false information.
• The defence argued that the mens rea had not been met because they were acting on legal advice and therefore did not think they were deceiving the authorities.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal upheld the guilty verdicts.
• The court held that the defendants' reliance on legal advice did not negate the mens rea for the offence as they intended their actions based on the false representations made.
• The court found that the defendants' mistaken belief in the reliability and legality of their lawyer's advice did not negate their intention to deceive the authorities.

Key passage(s)
• 'There was no inconsistency between the appellant having acted dishonestly, knowing that he was not working but providing false information in the belief that this was a lawful way of acquiring the necessary [qualifying] period, and being able to rely on that belief as negating the necessary dishonest intent under the Act.' (Mr Justice Leggatt)

cases.name: Jaggard v Dickinson [1981] QB 527, [1981] 2 WLR 118
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Jaggard, damaged the door of a property that she mistakenly believed belonged to her friend.
• She honestly believed that her friend would have consented to her damaging the door in order to gain entry, if she had been asked.
• She was convicted of causing criminal damage under the Criminal Damage Act 1971, s (1)(1).

Issues
• The appellant argued that she had not committed the actus reus of the offence because she had an honest belief in consent from the owner of the property.
• The prosecution argued that this belief, even if honestly held, was objectively unreasonable and that it should not provide a defence in this case.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal quashed the appellant's conviction, holding that an honest belief in consent was sufficient to negate the actus reus of the offence, even if that belief was objectively unreasonable.
• The court applied the reasoning of the House of Lords in DPP v Morgan [1976] AC 182, which held similarly in the context of rape, where a mistaken belief in consent was found to be a defence irrespective of whether it was reasonable.

Key passage(s)
