• 'If on a charge of causing criminal damage, the defendant honestly believes that the person to whom the property belongs would consent to his acts, then, however unreasonable that belief, he does not have the necessary mens rea for the crime.' (Lawton LJ)

cases.name: R v Ghosh [1982] EWCA Crim 2 [1982] QB 1053
cases.summary:
Facts
• Dr Ghosh, a surgeon, was charged with theft for obtaining payments by deception.
• The main issue was whether Dr Ghosh's actions were dishonest, as required by the Theft Act 1968.
• The trial judge directed the jury using a subjective test for dishonesty, which required them to consider whether Dr Ghosh believed his actions were dishonest.
• The jury convicted Dr Ghosh, and he appealed on the grounds that the judge misdirected the jury about the test for dishonesty.

Issues
• The main issue was the correct test for dishonesty in criminal law.
• Dr Ghosh argued for the subjective test used by the trial judge, while the prosecution argued for an objective test, based on the standards of ordinary, reasonable people.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal dismissed Dr Ghosh 's appeal, upholding his convictions for theft.
• The court established a two-stage test for dishonesty in criminal law, requiring both subjective and objective dishonesty (known as the Ghosh test).
• First, jurors must determine whether the defendant's actions were dishonest by the standards of ordinary, reasonable people (objective component).
• Second, if the answer is yes, jurors must determine whether the defendant realized that his actions would be considered dishonest by those standards (subjective component).

Key passage(s)
• 'In determining whether the prosecution has proved that the defendant was acting dishonestly, a jury must first of all decide whether according to the ordinary standards of reasonable and honest people what was done was dishonest.' (Lord Lane)
• 'If it was dishonest by those standards, then the jury must consider whether the defendant himself must have realized that what he was doing was by those standards dishonest.' (Lord Lane)

cases.name: Watt v Hertfordshire County Council [1954] 2 All ER 368
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Watt v Hertfordshire County Council [1954] 2 All ER 368, the plaintiff, Watt, was a firefighter employed by Hertfordshire County Council (the council).
• One day, the fire authority received an emergency call to attend a road traffic accident involving a trapped woman, requiring urgent attention.
• The appliance carrying the necessary equipment to release the trapped woman was not available, so the captain decided to load the equipment onto another available vehicle, even though it was not designed for this purpose.
• During the rescue operation, the heavy equipment fell on Watt while he was unloading it from the vehicle, causing him severe injuries.

Issues
• Watt claimed that the council was negligent for allowing the equipment to be carried on an unsuitable vehicle and the captain was also negligent for deciding to load the equipment on such vehicle.
• The council argued that there was no negligence, as the decision to use the unsuitable vehicle was a necessary and reasonable one in light of the urgent emergency situation.

Decision
• The court held that there was no negligence on the part of the council or the captain.
• The decision on how to transport the equipment in such an emergency situation was considered reasonable and justified, given the urgency and seriousness of the rescue operation.
• The court took into account the balance of risk and urgency inherent in rescue operations, which may lead to decisions for the greater good, even if it involves risk for the rescuers.

Key passage(s)
• 'Reason is the life of the law; nay, the common law itself is nothing else but reason.' - (Denning LJ)

cases.name: Haley v London Electricity Board [1965] AC 778
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Haley v London Electricity Board (LEB) [1965] AC 778, the blind plaintiff, Mr. Haley, was injured after tripping over a wooden barrier placed across a public footpath.
• LEB had positioned the barrier prior to carrying out construction work to repair a cable beneath the footpath.
• Haley, who was blind and unable to see LEB's warnings, tripped over the barrier resulting in severe injuries, including hearing loss.

Issues
• The principle legal issue in this case was whether the defendant (LEB) owed a duty of care towards the plaintiff (Haley) in regards to avoiding the risk of injury.
• Haley argued that LEB was negligent in failing to take reasonable precautions to avoid harm, even though it was unforeseeable that a blind person would be injured in this particular situation.
• LEB argued that they had taken reasonable precautions by erecting a barrier and that the level of foreseeability of harm to a blind person was too low to constitute a duty of care.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that LEB was indeed negligent in the case at hand.
• It was ruled that LEB should have foreseen the risk of injury to Haley, even though he was in a particularly vulnerable category as a blind person, and as such, failed to exercise the expected level of care to prevent such harm from occurring.
• The court emphasized that LEB had failed to warn Haley through alternative means, such as by providing a physical barrier or aural warning.

Key passage(s)
• 'The standard of foresight of the reasonable man is in one sense an impersonal test. It eliminates the personal equation and is independent of the idiosyncrasies of the particular person who takes the matter in his hands...' (Lord Reid)

cases.name: Walker v Northumberland County Council [1995] 1 All ER 737
cases.summary:
Facts
• Walker, a social worker employed by the Northumberland County Council (NCC), suffered two nervous breakdowns as a result of an excessive workload and the Council's failure to alleviate the working conditions.
• After the first breakdown, Walker and NCC reached a settlement, and NCC promised to provide reasonable adjustments.
• However, upon returning to work, Walker faced the same working conditions and suffered a second breakdown.

Issues
• Walker argued that NCC was negligent by breaching their duty of care and failing to take reasonable steps to prevent his work-related stress, which caused his psychiatric injury.
• NCC argued that the injury was not foreseeable and that they had taken reasonable steps to alleviate Walker's working conditions. They relied on the legal principles in Sutherland v Hatton [2002] ICR 613, where the employer's liability was limited for a psychiatric injury relating to work-related stress.

Decision
• The court found in favor of Walker, holding that NCC had breached their duty of care by failing to implement the promised reasonable adjustments, rendering them liable for Walker's second nervous breakdown.
• The court decided the case based on the concept of employer's liability in tort for work-related psychiatric injuries inflicted upon employees by negligent employers, especially when harm is foreseeable and the employer fails to act reasonably to prevent it.

Key passage(s)
• 'As an employer you owe a duty of care, a responsibility for the safety and health of your workers' (Mr. Justice Drake).

cases.name: Mullin v Richards [1998] 1 All ER 920
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Mullin v Richards [1998] 1 All ER 920, two 15-year-old schoolgirls were playing with plastic rulers during a school lesson, pretending to sword fight.
• One of the rulers shattered, and a shard of plastic penetrated the claimant's eye, causing serious injury, including the loss of sight in the injured eye.
• The claimant sued the defendant schoolgirl for the tort of negligence.

Issues
• The key issue was determining the appropriate standard of care to be applied in this case.
• The claimant argued that the defendant should be held to the standard of an adult, and thus be liable in negligence.
• The defendant argued that she should be held to the standard of care of a reasonable child of the same age, arguing that the injury was a tragic accident and not the result of negligence on her part.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the defendant was not liable in negligence.
• It found that the appropriate standard of care was that of a reasonable child of the same age, not that of an adult.
• The defendant's actions were not negligent when measured against the lower standard of care applicable to children.
• This decision followed the principle established in Orchard v Lee [2009] EWCA Civ 295, which also considered the appropriate standard of care for child defendants.

Key passage(s)
• 'There is no reason why a child... should be held to a higher standard of care in respect of his physical acts than in respect of his mental acts' (Lord Justice Beldam).
• 'The test for a 15-year-old school girl must be whether, in engaging in what she did, she fell below the standard to be expected of an ordinary, reasonable, prudent 15-year-old school girl' (Lord Justice Waite).

cases.name: Mansfield v Weetabix Ltd [1998] 1 WLR 1263
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Mansfield v Weetabix Ltd [1998] 1 WLR 1263, the plaintiff (P) was driving on a road when a lorry driven by an employee (D) of Weetabix Ltd collided with P's car.
• D suffered from hypoglycemia, a diabetic condition causing low blood sugar and occasional loss of consciousness. D's hypoglycemic episode affected his ability to control the lorry and led to the accident.
• D had been unaware of his condition and Weetabix was unaware of the risk posed by the driver.
• P claimed for damage to his car and property.

Issues
• P argued that D was negligent in not recognizing and managing his condition, leading to the accident.
• P also claimed that D's employer, Weetabix, was vicariously liable for their employee's negligence.
• D conceded some responsibility but argued that P should bear some liability for contributory negligence by driving too close to the lorry and not trying to avoid the collision.

Decision
• The court held that D's unforeseen hypoglycemic episode should not be attributed with negligence as he had no reason to know his condition would render him unfit to drive.
• However, the court found P to be 80% contributorily negligent as he could have taken greater care to avoid the accident.
• Weetabix Ltd was not found vicariously liable as D's condition and risk were both unknown.

Key passage(s)
• '[Even if] the lorry driver was presented with an emergency, cannot be deemed to be the effective cause of the accident until one has measured the degree of blame that should be attributed to the other driver.' - Lord Justice Evans

cases.name: Hatton v Sutherland [2002] 2 All ER 2
cases.summary:
Facts
• Hatton v Sutherland [2002] 2 All ER 2 is a landmark case in English law concerning an employer's liability for psychiatric injury caused by work-related stress.
• Four employees (teachers, a health visitor, and an administrative worker) sued their employers for damages, claiming they had suffered injuries from their jobs.
• All four claimed they had not received sufficient support from their employers and experienced intolerably high levels of stress, causing their mental breakdowns.

Issues
• The employees argued that their employers had breached their duty of care by failing to protect them from psychiatric injury.
• The employers countered that the employees' conditions were caused by a combination of different factors, making it unreasonable to impose liability on the employers.
• It was crucial to the employees' success that they establish the employers had breached a legal duty of care.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal provided guidance on the principles for determining an employer's liability for psychiatric injury.
• Key factors were the foreseeability of harm, the existence of a duty of care, the reasonability and practicability of preventative action, and causality between breach and injury.
• The court emphasized an employer is not required to bear an unreasonable burden in predicting and preventing injury.
• Of the four cases, two employees were successful in their claims and two were not.

Key passage(s)
• 'An employer who offers a confidential advice service, with referral to appropriate counselling or treatment services, is unlikely to be found in breach of duty' (Hale LJ).
• 'It is only fair to add that there are some approved codes of practice which may set standards which, if not met, could be evidence of a breach of duty' (Hale LJ).

cases.name: Dunnage v Randall [2015] EWCA Civ 673
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimant, Lesroy Dunnage, brought a claim in tort for personal injury caused by the negligence of his deceased cousin, Vincent Randall.
• On 12 July 2007, Randall, suffering from an acute and previously undiagnosed paranoid schizophrenia, poured a bucket filled with petrol over himself and lit it.
• Dunnage, in an attempt to save him, was badly burned.
• Randall died from his injuries while Dunnage suffered £1.4m worth of damage.

Issues
• The claim was whether a person, though suffering from a mental illness or disability, could still owe a duty of care in tort to those around him.
• The claimant argued that even though the defendant was mentally ill, he still owed a duty of care and acted negligently.
• The defendant's estate argued that Randall lacked the requisite capacity due to his mental illness and his actions were therefore not negligent.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal (the court) held that there is no principle in English law that a mentally ill person who commits an irrational and violent act cannot owe a duty of care, if their illness still left them capable of appreciating the foreseeable consequences of their actions.
• It was decided that Randall, though suffering from paranoid schizophrenia, still owed a duty of care to Dunnage.
• The court found that Randall had breached that duty and was therefore liable in negligence.

Key passage(s)
• 'A defendant is not to be judged at the standard of the reasonable patient, but of the reasonable person: that means the person they are, with such mental capacity as they have.' (Lady Justice Macur)

cases.name: FB (by her mother and litigation friend, WAC) v Princess Alexandra Hospital NHS Trust [2017] EWCA Civ 334
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case involved a claim of medical negligence against Princess Alexandra Hospital NHS Trust, resulting from the claimant (FB) suffering a brain injury as a baby, alleged to be due to the hospital's negligence during her birth.

Issues
• The central issue in this case concerned causation, i.e., whether the hospital's medical treatment and decisions during the birth were the direct cause of FB's brain injury.
• The claimant argued that the failures of the hospital staff during the delivery caused her injury, whereas the defendant argued that the injuries would have occurred anyway because FB was exposed to infection in the womb.

Decision
• The court found that the hospital was not liable for FB's injuries.
• At trial, it was established, on the balance of probabilities, that the brain injury had already irreversibly occurred before the hospital's alleged negligence took place.
• The court therefore concluded that causation could not be established.

Key passage(s)
'In my judgment, the question whether an injury which would have occurred anyway but has been materially contributed to by the defendant's negligence has been caused by that negligence depends on what the judge means by the word 'injury'. If she means the irreparable brain injury caused by hypoxia-ischemia (as, in my view, she does), then the answer is that it was not caused by the negligence because that injury occurred in any event.' (Lady Justice Davies)

cases.name: McKew v Holland & Hannah & Cubbits (Scotland) Ltd [1969] 3 All ER
cases.summary:
Facts
• In McKew v Holland & Hannen & Cubitts (Scotland) Ltd [1969] 3 All ER, the plaintiff, McKew, was an employee of the defendant company.
• While working, he sustained an injury due to his employer's negligence, causing his leg to occasionally collapse without warning.
• Knowing of his leg condition, McKew chose to descend a steep staircase without a handrail; his leg gave way, and he sustained further injuries.
• McKew argued that the defendant was liable for these additional injuries as a consequence of their original negligence.

Issues
• McKew claimed that the defendant's original negligence constituted a continuing breach of duty of care, and therefore, the defendant ought to be held responsible for the additional injuries sustained.
• The defendant, on the other hand, argued that McKew acted unreasonably by attempting to descend the staircase, knowing his leg could give way, and thus, his actions constituted contributory negligence, breaking the chain of causation.

Decision
• The House of Lords found in favor of the defendant, ruling that McKew's decision to descend the staircase was a ‘non-natural’ and ‘unreasonable’ use of the original injury, and therefore acted as a novus actus interveniens (intervening act).
• McKew's action was deemed to be an independent cause of his subsequent injuries.
• The defendant was not found liable for these further injuries as the causal link between their initial negligence and the subsequent injuries was broken by McKew's unreasonable act.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is evident ... that there may be cases in which the injured party can so act on his injury, or defect, as to shift from the defendant's shoulders on to his own the responsibility for further damage which might otherwise have been foreseeable. I think this is such a case.' (Lord Reid)

cases.name: Baker v Willoughby [1970] AC 467
cases.summary:
Facts
• In this case, the plaintiff, Mr. Baker, was a pedestrian who was hit by the defendant, Mr. Willoughby's vehicle in November 1964, resulting in severe leg injuries.
• The plaintiff's leg injuries led to a loss of earnings from his job as a metal machinist, as his capacity to work was restricted.
• In December 1967, while pursuing the first claim, Mr. Baker experienced another unrelated accident at work involving a printing machine, causing an amputation of the same injured leg.
• The result of the second accident brought about a further loss of earnings.

Issues
• The issue was whether the defendant, Mr. Willoughby, should be held liable for the plaintiff's loss of earnings following the amputation of his leg due to the unrelated accident.
• The defendant argued that the amputation of the leg following the second accident was a 'new cause' (novus actus interveniens) which broke the chain of causation and limited his liability for the loss of earnings.
• The plaintiff argued that Mr. Willoughby should be held liable for the loss of earnings until the time of his retirement, despite the second accident.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the defendant, Mr. Willoughby, was liable for the plaintiff's loss of earnings due to his negligence, and this liability extended after the second, unrelated accident and up to Mr. Baker's retirement.
• The ruling in this case departed from the decision in the Jobling v Associated Dairies [1982] AC 794 case, where the court held that the defendant's liability ceased once a new intervening act occurred.
• The court, in contrast, established that liability for a tortfeasor's negligence was not altered by the occurrence of an unrelated later event affecting the extent of the injury.

Key passage(s)
• 'In these circumstances it would, speaking generally, be inaccurate to describe the second accident as merely increasing or prolonging damage which flowed from the first accident.' (Lord Reid)

cases.name: Wilsher v Essex AHA [1988] 1 All ER 871
cases.summary:
{Facts
• The plaintiff, Wilsher, was born prematurely at 27 weeks.
• During his treatment, an overdose of oxygen was administered by a doctor with six months' clinical experience.
• The plaintiff developed retrolental fibroplasia (RLF), a condition resulting in blindness.
• The mother alleged medical negligence and sued Essex Area Health Authority (Essex AHA).

Issues
• Whether Essex AHA was negligent in administering excessive oxygen to the infant plaintiff.
• Whether the doctor's inexperience was an excuse for the error or whether greater supervision should have been provided.
• On the other hand, Essex AHA contended that the plaintiff's blindness could have resulted from one of several other factors.
• If negligence was found, the consideration of Bonnington Castings Ltd. v. Wardlaw [1956] AC 613 required determining whether the oxygen administration was a 'material contribution' to the plaintiff's condition, or merely a 'cause in fact'.

Decision
• The trial judge found for the plaintiff, determining the Essex AHA was negligent for administering excessive oxygen.
• On appeal, the Court of Appeal held that the doctor's inexperience did not excuse the error and that the Bolam test applied (Bolam v. Friern Hospital Management Committee [1957] 1 WLR 582) - they failed to provide the plaintiff with a 'responsible body of medical opinion'.
• The House of Lords, however, overturned the Court of Appeal ruling on the grounds that the plaintiff's blindness could have been caused by one of several factors.
• Thus, Wilsher failed to establish causation and the Bolam test was not applicable.

Key passage(s)
• 'In my opinion, the decisions in Bonnington Castings Ltd. v. Wardlaw and McGhee v. National Coal Board do not assist [the plaintiff]' - Lord Bridge
• 'In my opinion, [plaintiff] has failed to establish that excess oxygen caused...blindness and that the defendants were accordingly negligent' – Lord Keith

cases.name: Allied Maples Group Ltd v Simmons & Simmons [1995] 1 WLR 1602
cases.summary:
Facts
• Allied Maples Group Ltd (the claimant) acquired a carpet retail business from Carpetland plc (the defendant) and sought professional advice from Simmons & Simmons (the solicitors) regarding the transaction.
• The solicitors allegedly failed to advise the claimant to negotiate warranties from the defendant, which resulted in the claimant suffering financial losses.
• The claimant sued the solicitors for professional negligence, claiming that had they received proper advice, they would have negotiated the warranties.

Issues
• The central issue was causation: whether the claimant's loss could be attributed to the solicitors' negligence.
• The claimant argued that had they received proper advice, they would have negotiated the warranties, thus avoiding the losses.
• The solicitors contended that even if the claimant had sought warranties, the defendant would not have agreed to them, and there was no certainty that the claimant would have been better off had the warranties been negotiated.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the claimant needed to prove that on a balance of probabilities, they had lost a real or substantial (above 50%) chance of obtaining the warranties.
• The court found that the claimant satisfied this test and had lost the opportunity to negotiate the warranties.
• Therefore, the solicitors were held liable for professional negligence and the claimant's losses.

Key passage(s)
• 'In a case such as this, when considering whether a claimant has suffered damage as a result of a solicitor's negligence, it appears to me that the correct approach is to ask whether, if the advice had been provided, there would have been a significant or real chance that the plaintiff would have achieved a more favourable outcome.' (Stuart-Smith LJ)

cases.name: Reeves v Metropolitan Police Commissioner [1999] 3 WLR 363
cases.summary:
Facts
• The plaintiff, Reeves, brought an action against the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, claiming damages because of negligence by police officers, resulting in the suicide of her husband.
• Her husband, Martin Lynch, was a known suicide risk and had been remanded in custody at a police station.
• Police officers had removed Lynch's belt and shoelaces but left him unattended in his cell for 30 minutes, during which time he hanged himself using his shirt.

Issues
• Whether the police owed Lynch a duty of care to prevent his suicide.
• Reeves argued that the police officers were negligent as they failed to take reasonable steps in guarding Lynch against his known risk of suicide.
• The police argued that there was no duty of care as the suicide was a voluntary act, which broke the chain of causation.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the police indeed owed a duty of care to Lynch, considering he was a known suicide risk and under their control.
• The House of Lords ruled that in cases like these, the damages awarded must be reduced to take account of the victim's own responsibility for their death due to their voluntary act of suicide.
• The House of Lords reduced the damages award by 50% due to Lynch's own responsibility for his death.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is the voluntary taking of one's own life. The whole concept of assessing responsibility is therefore difficult territory. But in this field of the law we are not strangers to an approach ... There is a sufficiently close nexus between the defendant's lack of due care and the deceased's act of suicide to enable responsibility to be justly reduced ...' (Lord Hoffmann)

cases.name: Barker v Corus [2006] 2 WLR 1027
cases.summary:
Facts
• Barker v Corus [2006] 2 WLR 1027 concerned compensatory damages for mesothelioma, a fatal asbestos-related lung disease, which Mr. Barker had developed due to his employers' negligent exposure to asbestos.
• The claimant, Mr. Barker, had worked for various employers, all of which had negligently exposed him to asbestos, and it was not possible to identify which employer was responsible for causing his mesothelioma.
• Mr. Barker's widow claimed compensation from multiple employers under the tort of negligence.

Issues
• The House of Lords was to consider whether the defendants should be held jointly and severally liable, whereupon they would each be responsible for paying the entirety of the damages to the claimant, or whether they should be held severally liable, whereupon they would be responsible for paying only a proportionate share of the damages.
• The claimant argued for joint and several liability.
• The defendants argued for several liability.

Decision
• The House of Lords rejected joint and several liability and applied several liability instead.
• The court held that although it could not identify which employer caused the mesothelioma, it was possible to approximate their contribution to the risk.
• Each defendant was to be held liable for a proportionate amount of the damages based on their individual contribution to the claimant's total chances of becoming ill.
• Following this decision, Parliament enacted the Compensation Act 2006, which removed several liability for mesothelioma claims and replaced it with joint and several liability.

Key passage(s)
• 'In my opinion, the fairest approach is ... to make the employer who increased the risk of mesothelioma to his employee liable for a proportion of the employee’s indivisible injury, the proportion being the extent to which he has increased the risk of the employee contracting that disease.' (Baroness Hale, paragraph 78)

cases.name: Corr v IBC Vehicles Ltd [2008] UKHL 13
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Corr v IBC Vehicles Ltd, the claimant, Mr. Corr, was an employee of the defendant, IBC Vehicles.
• He suffered a serious head injury at work due to the defendant's negligence.
• As a result of the injury, Mr. Corr developed a post-traumatic depressive disorder and eventually committed suicide.
• His widow brought a claim against the defendant for damages, arguing that her husband's suicide was a foreseeable consequence of the injuries he sustained in the accident and the defendant's negligence.

Issues
• The main issue before the House of Lords was whether the defendant could be held liable for Mr. Corr's suicide, despite it being an intentional act, as a result of their negligence causing Mr. Corr's injury.
• The defendant argued that Mr. Corr's voluntary act of suicide broke the chain of causation between their negligence and the resulting death.
• The claimant argued that Mr. Corr's suicide was a foreseeable consequence of his injury and psychiatric harm, and therefore, the defendant should be held liable.

Decision
• The House of Lords ultimately held in favour of the claimant.
• They ruled that the defendant was liable for Mr. Corr's suicide, finding that it was a foreseeable consequence of the injury sustained due to their negligence.
• The court considered previous cases such as White v Chief Constable of South Yorkshire Police [1998] 3 WLR 1499, and concluded that the defendant's negligence had directly caused Mr. Corr's psychiatric harm and subsequent suicide.
• The court acknowledged that, in certain circumstances, a voluntary act such as suicide would not break the chain of causation.

Key passage(s)
• 'In these circumstances, I see no reason why [the deceased's] suicide should be regarded as novus actus interveniens (a new intervening act) which broke the chain of causation between the defendant's negligence and the deceased's suicide.' (Lord Hope)

cases.name: Spencer v Wincanton Holdings Ltd [2009] EWCA Civ 1404
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimant, Mr. Spencer, injured his leg due to the negligence of his employer, Wincanton Holdings Ltd (defendant) and had it amputated.
• After the amputation, Mr. Spencer, despite being handicapped, tried to fill his car with petrol, tripped and fell, resulting in him becoming wheelchair bound.

Issues
• The issue the court had to determine was whether the defendant was liable for the additional disability caused by the claimant's fall.
• The defendant argued that the claimant's own act of trying to fill his car with petrol was a new intervening act that broke the chain of causation, and therefore they were not liable for the additional disability.
• The claimant argued that the defendant's negligence was still a continuing cause of his additional disability.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that the defendant was liable for the additional disability, but reduced the damages by 1/3 for contributory negligence on the part of the claimant.
• The court held that the claimant's act was not a novus actus interviens (new intervening act) that broke the chain of causation, because it was not highly unreasonable for him to attempt to fill his car with petrol.

Key passage
• ‘Perhaps of more relevance is what Waller LJ said about the McKew test in Emeh v Kensington etc AHA [1984] 3 All ER 1044, 1049: ‘… the degree of unreasonable conduct which is required [to break the chain of causation] is, on Lord Reid's view, very high.'' – LJ Sedley

cases.name: Sienkiewicz v Greif (UK) Ltd [2011] UKSC 10
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimants, Eileen Sienkiewicz and the family of deceased Winifred Greif, brought separate claims against the defendants, Greif (UK) Ltd and New Hythe Foundry Ltd, in relation to the deaths of the claimants from mesothelioma.
• Mesothelioma is a fatal cancer that is largely caused by asbestos exposure.
• The defendants did not dispute that they had negligently exposed their employees to asbestos, but argued that the claimants' exposure was within the limits allowed by the Factories Act 1961 and Asbestos Industry Regulations 1931, and that the employees had also been exposed to asbestos from other sources.

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether the defendants could be held liable for the deaths caused by mesothelioma.
• The claimants argued that the defendants should be held liable for their employees' exposure to asbestos, even if their exposure was within the legal limits and there were multiple possible sources of exposure, under the 'material contribution' test.
• The defendants argued that they should not be held liable as there was no single cause of mesothelioma identified and the law required the claimants to show that their exposure to asbestos had 'doubled the risk' of developing mesothelioma.

Decision
• The Supreme Court (UKSC) held that, applying the 'material contribution' test, the defendants were liable for the deaths of the claimants caused by mesothelioma.
• It was not necessary for the claimants to prove that their exposure to asbestos had 'doubled the risk' of developing mesothelioma, as the 'material contribution' test was sufficient to establish liability.
• The Court applied the House of Lords ruling in Fairchild v Glenhaven Funeral Services Ltd [2002] 3 All ER 305, which held that where it was impossible to identify the exact cause of mesothelioma, multiple defendants could be held liable if they had materially increased the risk of the claimant developing the disease.

Key passage(s)
• 'Where it is impossible for a claimant to identify the source of the exposure which has, on the balance of probabilities, more likely than not caused the mesothelioma, he or she is ordinarily entitled to recover damages on a causation basis in accordance with the Fairchild exception if he or she can establish that the defendant has materially increased the risk of his or her contracting the disease.' - Lord Phillips (paragraph 78)

cases.name: Smith v Littlewoods [1987] 1 All ER 710
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Smith v Littlewoods [1987] 1 All ER 710, a fire broke out in an unoccupied cinema owned by the defendants, Littlewoods, which subsequently spread to the plaintiffs' premises, causing extensive damage.
• The fire was started by unknown trespassers.
• The defendants were aware that trespassers had previously entered the building but had taken some measures to secure it.

Issues
• The plaintiffs claimed that the defendants were liable in tort (nuisance and negligence) for failing to take sufficient care to prevent the trespassers from entering the premises and causing the fire.
• The defendants argued that they owed no duty of care to the plaintiffs, as the damage was a result of the unforeseeable and reckless act of the trespassers.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the defendants were not liable for the damage caused by the fire.
• The court ruled that a duty of care did not exist in this situation, as the defendants could not reasonably have foreseen the harm caused by the trespassers.
• Additionally, the court found that the defendants had taken reasonable steps to prevent potential harm by securing the premises.
• The decision in this case distinguished it from earlier cases such as Hughes v Lord Advocate [1963] AC 837, where the defendants were found to owe a duty of care even though the exact manner the harm occurred was not foreseeable.

Key passage(s)
• 'It may not be part of the ordinary function of ownership to guard against harm to one's neighbours by third parties, but if the circumstances are such that a reasonable man would take steps to guard against such harm, then it may well be that he will become answerable for any such harm which a reasonable man would have guarded against' (Lord Goff).
• 'In the present case, the precautions taken by the defendants might have been thought reasonable by a jury had the case gone to them' (Lord Goff).
• 'For present purposes, it is enough to say that a person who creates a thing on his land, or brings a thing on to it, or fails to remove it (an 'occupier'), is not responsible for physical harm to his neighbours resulting from his creation or his thing unless he has a duty of care' (Lord Mackay).

cases.name: Alcock v Chief Constable of South Yorkshire [1991] 4 All ER 907
cases.summary:
Facts
• Alcock v Chief Constable of South Yorkshire was a UK tort law case related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster.
• In the tragedy, 96 fans of Liverpool Football Club were killed and hundreds were injured when a massive crush occurred during a match between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest.
• The scene was shown live on television, and several relatives or friends of the victims (the plaintiffs) claimed that they suffered psychiatric injuries (post-traumatic stress disorder – PTSD) as a result of witnessing the disaster from various locations.
• The plaintiffs brought actions against the Chief Constable of South Yorkshire, claiming the police failed in their duty of care to ensure the safety of the fans.

Issues
• The plaintiffs argued that they were owed a duty of care due to their close-ties with the direct victims, and that the defendants' negligence led to their psychiatric injury.
• The defendants argued that the plaintiffs did not meet the proximity requirements necessary to establish a claim for psychiatric injury and therefore, a duty of care was not owed.

Decision
• The House of Lords dismissed all actions from the plaintiffs, ruling that there was no direct relationship of proximity between the police and those who had witnessed the tragedy and suffered psychiatric injury.
• The court held that the plaintiffs must have witnessed the event with their own senses in order to be owed a duty of care, and that they must either have been at the scene or a 'rescuer'.

Key passage(s)
• 'In my judgment, the requirements that can properly be imposed in the present case are, firstly, that the plaintiff must be reasonably proximate to the accident in time and space, secondly, that he must have sustained the nervous shock as a result of direct perception of the accident by sight or hearing and, thirdly, that his nervous shock must arise from an apprehension of physical injury to the primary victim.' - Lord Ackner

cases.name: Stovin v Wise and Norfolk County Council [1996] 3 WLR 388
cases.summary:
Facts
• Stovin v Wise and Norfolk County Council involved a road accident at a junction where visibility was obstructed due to an earthen bank.
• The council had identified the bank as dangerous, but did not remove it.
• The claimant, Stovin, was involved in a collision with the first defendant, Wise, who was found to be 70% responsible for the accident due to her negligent driving.
• Stovin sued the second defendant, Norfolk County Council, for its failure to remove the hazardous bank, claiming they were 30% responsible due to their negligence or breach of statutory duty.

Issues
• Whether the council owed a duty of care to the claimant.
• If so, whether the council was liable in negligence for failing to remove the hazardous bank, which resulted in the road accident.
• Stovin argued the council should be liable for its omission (not removing the bank).
• The council countered, arguing that it had no duty of care due to the absence of a clear legal obligation to act; it also referenced Gorringe v Calderdale Metropolitan Borough Council [2004] 1 WLR 1057, which involved a similar argument on non-feasance (failure to act) leading to negligence.

Decision
• The court ultimately held that the council did not owe a duty of care to the claimant in this case.
• It was acknowledged that although the Highway Authority had the power to remove the bank, there was no absolute duty to do so; the council possessed discretion.
• The court maintained that the council's omission to act did not render it liable for negligence.

Key passage(s)
• 'The council would not be responsible for the accident unless the combination of the discretionary powers and the existence of the public nuisance, the fact that the bank amounted to a public nuisance yet still remained in the state highway triggered a duty owed by the council to the individual road user' - Lord Hoffmann.

cases.name: Barrett v Enfield LBC [1999] 3 WLR 79
cases.summary:
Facts
• The plaintiff, John Barrett, suffered from mental illness and behavioural issues since childhood.
• At 14, he came under the care of Enfield London Borough Council's (LBC) Social Services Department.
• Barrett claimed that the council's negligence in providing adequate care and treatment led to his lifelong mental illness.
• He sued Enfield LBC for damages, alleging that the council owed him a duty of care to exercise reasonable skill and care in their provision of social services.

Issues
• The main issue was whether Enfield LBC owed a duty of care to Barrett.
• Enfield LBC argued that imposing a duty of care in this context would create an undesirable interference with its exercise of discretionary powers.
• Barrett contended that the extent of Enfield LBC's control over his upbringing and the foreseeability of harm made it appropriate for a duty of care to be imposed.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Enfield LBC did owe Barrett a duty of care.
• The Lords emphasized that establishing a duty of care did not necessarily interfere with or undermine the council's discretionary powers.
• In this case, the negligence claim was not based on policy decisions but rather on the specific actions taken in relation to Barrett's care.

Key passage(s)
• 'The decisions which are the subject of Mrs. Barrett's claim in negligence were made by operational level officers responsible for providing for his welfare. They were not decisions of a policy-making character' (Lord Slynn).
• 'What has to be identified in each case … is whether there exists a relationship between the claimant and the defendant which gives rise to a duty of care, the scope and extent of which deprive the defendant of any relevant functions or powers conferred by statute or delegated legislation' (Lord Millett).

cases.name: Phelps v Hillingdon LBC  [2000] 4 All ER 504
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimant, G, suffered from dyslexia.
• At age 6, she was tested by a psychologist employed by the defendant, Hillingdon London Borough Council ('the Local Authority').
• The psychologist negligently failed to diagnose G's dyslexia and recommended mainstream education.
• As a consequence, G did not receive the specialist assistance she needed and experienced significant difficulties throughout her education, ultimately affecting her career prospects.

Issues
• Claimant argued that the Local Authority owed her a duty of care, which had been breached, causing harm.
• The Local Authority contended that it owed no such duty, or alternatively that any duty did not extend to the specific harm suffered.
• The claimant also needed to establish that the negligence was too remote to establish liability, relying on Lord Bridge's test in McLoughlin v O'Brian [1983] 1 AC 410 (HL).

Decision
• The House of Lords found that a tortious duty of care was owed by the Local Authority to G.
• They decided that the negligent misdiagnosis of dyslexia caused G long-term harm.
• The Local Authority was held vicariously liable for its employee's negligence and was ordered to compensate G.

Key passage
• 'The relevant principle...is that to which Lord Bridge referred in McLoughlin v O'Brian [1983] 1 AC 410, 430, that foreseeability of injury in the circumstances is in law an insufficient criterion of liability...' (Lord Slynn).

cases.name: Gorringe v Calderdale MBC [2004] 2 All ER 326
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Gorringe v Calderdale MBC [2004] 2 All ER 326, the claimant, Gorringe, was driving along a steep, residential road when she encountered a patch of ice and lost control of her vehicle, causing an accident.
• The defendant, the local highway authority, had not applied a sufficient amount of grit on the roads to prevent ice formation.
• Gorringe brought a claim in the tort of negligence against the highway authority for its failure to grit the roads adequately, causing her accident.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the highway authority owed a duty of care towards the claimant and, if so, whether that duty was breached in this case.
• The claimant argued that the highway authority had a duty to take reasonable steps to ensure the safety of road users, including applying sufficient grit to prevent ice formation, and had breached this duty.
• The defendant argued that it had completed its statutory duty under the Highways Act 1980 to maintain the road and had not assumed any duty of care by applying any grit at all.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the highway authority did not owe a duty of care in respect of the non-feasance of failing to prevent ice formation on the roads.
• The defendant's duty under the Highways Act 1980 was limited to the maintenance of the road and not to the prevention of ice formation, and there was no basis to impose a common law duty of care in this case.
• The claim was therefore dismissed.

Key passage(s)
• 'The question is whether, in the exercise of their statutory functions and powers, the highway authorities owed the appellant a common law duty of care, independent of any express or implied statutory obligations, to protect her from the consequences of their tortious conduct.' (Lord Steyn)
• 'In my view the obligation on a highway authority to maintain a highway should not be construed as placing upon the authority an obligation to take reasonable care for the safety of road users.' (Lord Hoffmann)

cases.name: Robinson v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire Police [2018] UKSC 4
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Robinson v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire Police [2018] UKSC 4, an elderly pedestrian was injured when two police officers engaged in the attempted arrest of a suspected drug dealer.
• As the officers struggled with the suspect, they collided with the injured party, Mrs. Robinson, and fell to the ground with her.

Issues
• The issue in Robinson was whether the police had a duty of care to protect a bystander from injury during an operation and, if so, whether they had breached that duty in this case.
• The claimant, Mrs. Robinson, argued that the police's actions amounted to negligence and a breach of the duty of care.
• In response, the defendant, the Chief Constable of West Yorkshire Police, argued that the police did not owe a duty of care to bystanders during operations and were not liable for injuries caused.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court found in favour of Mrs. Robinson, holding that the police did owe a duty of care to bystanders in certain circumstances.
• The Court concluded that there was an operational breach of that duty, making the police liable for Mrs. Robinson's injuries.
• The Court clarified the three-stage test from Caparo Industries plc v Dickman [1990] UKHL 2, focusing on foreseeability, proximity, and whether it is fair, just and reasonable to impose a duty of care.
• The Court emphasized that the police's public functions did not confer blanket immunity from liability in tort law.

Key passage(s)
• 'The police may owe a duty of care where the injury caused is a direct and foreseeable result of their actions.': (Lord Reed)
• 'The whole purpose of arresting the suspect was to prevent the commission of offences. In circumstances where the police decided to intervene, it was reasonably foreseeable that their intervention might cause physical injury to members of the public.': (Lord Reed)

cases.name: Spartan Steel & Alloys Ltd v Martin [1973] 1 QB 27
cases.summary:
Facts
• In the case of Spartan Steel & Alloys Ltd v Martin [1973] 1 QB 27, the defendants negligently caused a power outage.
• This power outage prevented the claimant, a third-party metal processing company, from collecting and transferring molten metal from the furnace to the casting machine, causing loss of property.
• Additionally, the claimant claimed damages for the lost profit on the destroyed metal and the lost profit on the metal that could not be produced during the power outage.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the claimant could recover damages for the purely economic losses resulting from the defendant's negligence.
• The claimant argued they should be entitled to claim for both the lost profits and property damage.
• The defendant countered that the claimant should only be able to claim for the damaged property, not the economic loss.

Decision
• The court held that the claimant could only recover damages for the property damage, not the lost profit.
• The rationale for this decision was to limit potential economic consequences stemming from a single negligent act, as too wide a scope would place an unfair burden on the defendant.
• This established the principle that pure economic loss is not recoverable in a claim for negligence.

Key passage(s)
• '…if the law does go so far, it might have disastrous effects on those who carry on a public service. It might open up a new field of legal responsibility which, if lightly undertaken, would put potential defendants in fear of consequences, which are difficult to assess.' (Lord Denning MR)

cases.name: The Nicholas H [1995] 3 All ER 307
cases.summary:
Facts
• A vessel experienced a fracture in its hull during a trip. The vessel's proprietor sought an assessment of the damage by the classification society responsible for the vessel.
• At first, the classification society's representative suggested the vessel be placed in dry dock for repair. However, due to the owner's objections regarding the expenses, the recommendation was revised, and provisional repairs were executed instead.
• Following this, the vessel sank, causing the claimant to lose cargo valued at USD 17.6 million. The claimant obtained USD 17.5 million from the vessel's proprietor, corresponding to the total liability based on the vessel's size.
• The claimant then pursued the remaining sum from the classification society. Though initially successful, the claim was eventually overturned upon appeal. The claimant consequently appealed to the House of Lords.

Issues
• The central issue was determining whether the required factors for assigning a duty of care to the classification society were established based on the facts presented.

Decision
• The House of Lords ultimately ruled that the classification society did not owe a duty of care to the claimant in this case.
• The court restated the three criteria necessary for assigning a duty of care as set forth in Caparo Industries plc v Dickman [1990] 2 AC 605: proximity of relationship, foreseeability of damage, and whether the imposition of the duty would be equitable, just, and reasonable.
• While the first two components of this test were satisfied in the case, it was decided that assigning a duty of care to the classification society against the vessel's proprietor would be inequitable, unjust, and unreasonable. This decision was grounded in the fact that the vessel's proprietor should be the primary party responsible for recovery in such circumstances, in line with the globally acknowledged contractual framework in this domain.
• In addition, it would be inequitable, unjust, and unreasonable to impose liability on the classification society concerning the cargo owner, considering that classification societies operate for collective benefit and are not subject to any limitation provisions.

cases.name: White v Blackmore [1972] 2 QB 651
cases.summary:
Facts
• Mr White, a jalopy driver, attended a race as a competitor and later as a spectator with his family.
• Warning notices were displayed at the entrance and within the programme purporting to exclude liability for accidents.
• Mr White died from injuries sustained when a car's wheel became entangled with the spectator's rope.
• Mrs White claimed damages in negligence and for breach of s2 Occupier’s Liability Act 1957.

Issues
• Organisers claimed Mr White was aware of the risks and that the defence of volenti non fit injuria applied.
• Organisers argued they had reasonably brought the exclusion of liability to the spectators' attention and were entitled to exclude liability under s2(1) Occupier’s Liability Act 1957.
• Mrs White argued that the defence did not apply due to her husband's lack of knowledge about the negligent setup of the ropes and the notices' ineffectiveness in excluding liability for negligence.

Decision
• Mrs White’s claim was unsuccessful.
• The defence of volenti non fit injuria did not apply because Mr White did not have full knowledge of the risk of harm.
• The notices were effective in excluding liability for Mr White's death as they had taken care to bring the exclusion to the spectator’s attention and were entitled to exclude their duty of care under the Occupier’s Liability Act 1957.

Key passage(s)
• 'I am satisfied that with the notices placed on the programme and at the turnstiles and around the track the defendant had taken all reasonable steps to draw to the attention of Mr. White and any other spectator the thrust of the exclusion terms' (Lord Denning).

cases.name: Halsey v Esso Petroleum [1961] 2 All ER 145
cases.summary:
Facts
• Halsey v Esso Petroleum [1961] 2 All ER 145 is a tort law case dealing with private nuisance.
• The claimant, Mr. Halsey, lived in a residential area near the defendant's (Esso Petroleum) petrol station.
• Esso Petroleum operated the petrol station 24/7 causing occasional noise, smell and vibration in Mr. Halsey's property.
• Mr. Halsey sued Esso Petroleum for damages and an injunction to prevent the defendant from operating at night due to the nuisance caused.

Issues
• The issue was whether Esso Petroleum's operation of the petrol station constituted a private nuisance to Mr. Halsey's property.
• The claimant argued that the defendant unreasonably interfered with his use and enjoyment of his property through noise, smell and vibration.
• The defendant argued that their operation was not unreasonable as they were serving a public need and following all appropriate regulations.

Decision
• The court found in favour of the claimant and held that Esso Petroleum's operation constituted a private nuisance.
• The court granted an injunction requiring the defendant to cease operation between 8pm and 7am.
• The court took into account that the petrol station was in a primarily residential area and that the defendant's operation unreasonably interfered with the claimant's use and enjoyment of his property.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is a question of degree whether the annoyance caused by noise is such as materially to interfere with the ordinary comfort of human existence' – Lord Justice Romer
• 'Those whose occupation or recreation causes noise must exercise that occupation or recreation so as not unreasonably to interfere with the comfort of their neighbours' – Lord Justice Willmer

cases.name: Goldman v Hargrave [1967] 1 AC 645
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case of Goldman v Hargrave [1967] 1 AC 645 concerned a tort of private nuisance involving a fire which had arisen from a lightning strike to a gum tree on the defendant's land.
• The defendant, Hargrave, took some action to mitigate the risk of the fire spreading, but did not take all necessary steps to ensure the fire's extinguishment.
• As a result, the fire spread to the plaintiff's land, causing significant damage.

Issues
• The primary issue in this case was whether the defendant's failure to take reasonable care in extinguishing the fire constituted a private nuisance
• The plaintiff argued that the defendant was liable for the damage caused to his land, as he had not taken all available steps to prevent the fire from spreading
• The defendant, on the other hand, argued that the fire was caused by a natural event (lightning) and that he had taken some measures to mitigate the risk. He further argued that he could not be liable for private nuisance as his inaction was not an unreasonable interference with the plaintiff's use of land.

Decision
• The court held that the defendant was liable for private nuisance.
• It was found that the defendant had a duty of care to take reasonable steps (within his power) to prevent or minize the risk of fire spreading
• The court concluded that Hargrave's actions were insufficient, and his failure to take all necessary steps to prevent the fire from spreading amounted to an unreasonable interference

Key passage(s)
• 'In my opinion, the right to use land, so far as it may be affected by fire originating on neighbouring land, is ordinarily the right to be protected against fire caused by the neighbour's failure to use reasonable care to prevent the spread of fire occurring on his land. This may be an affirmative duty.' (Lord Wilberforce)

cases.name: Leakey v National Trust [1980] QB 485
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Leakey v National Trust [1980] QB 485, the claimants owned land adjacent to a hill owned by the defendant, the National Trust.
• Over time, a natural landslide caused the hill to subside, resulting in damage to the claimants' house. The National Trust did not do anything to prevent or mitigate the landslide.

Issues
• The claimants argued that the National Trust was liable for the natural hazard under the tort of nuisance, claiming that they had a duty to take reasonable steps to mitigate the landslide.
• The National Trust argued that they were not liable for the natural hazard as they did not cause it, and there was no obligation to take steps to prevent or mitigate the landslide.

Decision
• The court held that the National Trust was liable for the natural hazard. Although they did not cause the hazard, they had a duty to take reasonable steps to prevent or mitigate it due to their ownership of the land.
• The court stated that a possessor of land has a duty of care towards their neighbours if it is reasonably foreseeable that a natural hazard on their property may cause damage to others. This is a principle of 'reasonable user of land' (per Lord Goff in Cambridge Water Co. v. Eastern Counties Leather plc [1994] 2 AC 264).

Key passage(s)
• 'If a person brings or keeps on his land something which would not naturally be there, and which is a nuisance, he is liable for any damage which is the natural consequence of its being there' (Lord Denning).
• 'The possessor of land should not use it in such a way as to cause injury to his neighbour' (Lord Wilberforce).

cases.name: Barr and others v Biffa Waste Services Ltd [2012] EWCA Civ 312
cases.summary:
Facts
• Barr and others v Biffa Waste Services Ltd [2012] EWCA Civ 312 is a leading English tort law case involving nuisance claims.
• In this case, local residents sued Biffa Waste Services Ltd for nuisance due to the foul odours emanating from a landfill site operated by the company.
• The trial judge found in favour of the residents and ordered Biffa to pay damages.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether the operation of a landfill site that caused odour, and interfered with the enjoyment of neighbouring properties, amounted to a nuisance in tort law.
• Biffa argued that it operated the site under a permit issued by the Environment Agency and complied with the terms of the permit, which should provide a defence against the nuisance claim.
• The residents argued that Biffa's operations caused a significant and unreasonable interference with their use and enjoyment of their properties, and that the permit did not protect Biffa from liability for the nuisance.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal upheld the trial judge's decision, finding in favour of the residents.
• The Court held that a public authority's permit does not automatically provide a defence against a nuisance claim.
• The fact that Biffa complied with the terms of its permit was not sufficient to shield it from liability for the nuisance caused to the residents.
• The Court referred to Gillingham Borough Council v Medway (Chatham) Dock Co Ltd [1993] QB 343, which held that a local authority planning permission does not automatically immunize a defendant against an action in private nuisance.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is important to recognize that ... even if a public authority has given permission for a state of affairs which amounts to a nuisance, that does not mean that the private law of nuisance ceases to apply' (Carnwath LJ)

cases.name: Stannard (t/a Wyvern Tyres) v Gore [2012] EWCA Civ 1248
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Stannard (t/a Wyvern Tyres) v Gore [2012] EWCA Civ 1248, the claimant, Mr. Gore, owned a warehouse which was next to a property occupied by the defendant, Mr. Stannard, trading as Wyvern Tyres.
• A fire started on Mr. Stannard's property, causing extensive damage to Mr. Gore's warehouse.
• The fire was caused by a spark from Mr. Stannard's work on a customer's vehicle, which ignited in proximity to a large pile of tyres stored on his premises.

Issues
• The key issue was whether Mr. Stannard was liable in tort for the damage caused by the escape of fire from his property under the rule in Rylands v Fletcher [1868] UKHL 1 (strict liability for non-natural use of land causing escape and harm).
• The claimant argued that the defendant's storage of tyres constituted a non-natural use of land and that the defendant was strictly liable for the resulting damage.
• The defendant argued that the storage of tyres was not a non-natural use of land, and there was no escape in accordance with the rule in Rylands v Fletcher.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that neither the storage of tyres nor the use of the land were non-natural, and thus there was no strict liability under the rule in Rylands v Fletcher.
• The court also emphasized that the rule only applied if the defendant had brought something onto the land (such as water, gas, or electricity), which had a potential to escape. The escape of fire from the land was not enough to engage the rule.
• Consequently, Mr. Stannard was not held liable for the damage caused to Mr. Gore's property.

Key passage
• '[T]he presence on the land of the substance or thing and its capacity to do damage must be essential to the purpose for which those occupying or controlling the land are on it or are using it.' (Rix LJ)

cases.name: Rose v Plenty [1976] 1 WLR 141
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Rose v Plenty [1976] 1 WLR 141, a milkman, Mr. Rose, took his employer's vehicle to deliver milk without the employer's permission.
• During the delivery round, a boy, who regularly helped Mr. Rose with his deliveries, accompanied him on the milk round.
• While making a delivery, the vehicle accidentally ran over and injured the boy.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the employer was vicariously liable for the tort committed by Mr. Rose, even though Mr. Rose was acting without authority.
• The claimant argued that there was a sufficient connection between Mr. Rose's employment and the accident, thereby making the employer vicariously liable.
• The defendant argued that Mr. Rose was acting outside the scope of his employment and therefore, the employer was not responsible for the accident.

Decision
• The court held that the employer was vicariously liable for the tortious act of Mr. Rose, regardless of his lack of authority to use the vehicle for the milk round.
• The court determined that Mr. Rose was engaged in an authorized act (i.e., delivering milk), even if he was not authorized to use the particular vehicle for the job.
• The court reasoned that employers could still be held liable for the torts of their employees even if the employees act without authority, as long as there is a sufficient connection between their employment and the tortious act.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is sufficient to say that there is here such a close connection between the servant's employment to deliver milk and his wrongful act in allowing the boy to help him that the employers must be held answerable.' - Lord Denning MR
• 'To my mind, therefore, there is a risk pertaining to the business which is sufficiently close to render it just that Rose's employers should be held liable although Rose's conduct was unauthorized' - Ormrod LJ

cases.name: Mohamud v WM Morrison Supermarkets Plc [2016] UKSC 11
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimant, Mr. Mohamud, visited a Morrisons petrol station to request assistance printing documents.
• An employee, Mr. Khan, verbally abused Mr. Mohamud using offensive language.
• Mr. Mohamud left, but was pursued by Mr. Khan who physically assaulted him.
• At the time of the assault, Mr. Khan was acting in his capacity as an employee.

Issues
• The central question was whether Morrisons was vicariously liable for Mr. Khan's actions.
• The claimant argued that a sufficient connection existed between Mr. Khan's employment and the assault for Morrisons to be held liable.
• Morrisons argued that Mr. Khan's actions were so distant from his duties that there was no connection to establish liability.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously found in favour of the claimant, holding Morrisons vicariously liable for the assault.
• The court concluded that there was a sufficiently close connection between Mr. Khan's employment and the wrongful conduct.
• The court considered the principles established in Lister v Hesley Hall Ltd [2001] UKHL 22 and Dubai Aluminium Co Ltd v Salaam [2002] UKHL 48.

Key passage(s)
• 'The distinction between “field of activities” and “nature of his employment” may not, in the last resort, be very material. They are but ways of expressing the essential test of agency, which is subject to no special rules whether the agent, for whose conduct the defendant is said to be liable, was employed by the defendant as a servant or otherwise.' (Lord Reed)

cases.name: A v National Blood Transfusion Service [2001] 3 All ER 289
cases.summary:
Facts
• A v National Blood Transfusion Service (NBTS) is a case concerning the tort of negligence arising from a blood transfusion.
• In 1984, the plaintiff (A) received a blood transfusion during surgery.
• The blood provided by the NBTS was later discovered to be infected with HIV.
• As a result, A contracted HIV.
• A sued the NBTS for negligence on the basis that it had failed to adequately screen the blood for HIV before its transfusion.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether the NBTS owed A a duty of care and, if so, whether NBTS had breached that duty by failing to exercise reasonable care in screening the blood.
• The NBTS argued that it had not been negligent in its screening process and contended that the risk of HIV infection was not reasonably foreseeable at the time of the transfusion (in 1984).
• A argued that the NBTS should have known of the risk of HIV infection and taken reasonable steps to reduce that risk through blood donor screening.

Decision
• The court held that the NBTS owed A a duty of care to safeguard her health.
• The court also found that the risk of HIV infection was reasonably foreseeable at the time, and that the NBTS had breached its duty by not taking reasonable care in screening its blood donors.
• A was awarded damages for the injury she suffered as a result of the negligence.

Key passage(s)
• 'In my judgement, the authority accepts that the material risks of harm, with the prospect of the consequences being so devastating, are to be foreseen.' (Lord Phillips)

cases.name: Gee v DePuy International Ltd [2018] EWHC 1208 (QB)
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Gee v DePuy International Ltd, the claimants brought a product liability claim against the defendant, DePuy International Ltd, a manufacturer of hip implants.
• The claimants alleged that the defendant's hip implants, specifically the Pinnacle Ultamet Metal-on-Metal (MoM) hip system, had caused them injury as a result of the release of metal ions from the implants.
• The claimants sought damages for personal injury.

Issues
• The claimants argued that the defendant's liability arose from negligence in design, manufacturing, and testing of the product, and from marketing the product with an inadequate warnings.
• The defendant contested liability, arguing that the implants' long-term performance results were consistent with the pre-existing standard set by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE).

Decision
• The High Court found that the MoM implants had inherent defects which led to the increased risk of injury from metallosis.
• The court held that the defendant should have conducted additional tests to identify potential risks before marketing the product and could have marketed alternative designs with lower risks.
• The court found the defendant liable on the basis of negligence and breach of statutory duty under the Consumer Protection Act 1987 (CPA).
• The claimants were awarded damages for personal injuries.

Key passage(s)
• Mrs Justice Andrews: 'The claimants have established their primary case on causation by showing that but for the defendant's negligence, each would not have sustained the injuries of which they complain. They have also established that the defendant's breaches of duty were a material cause, i.e., that the negligent act or omission materially increased the risk that the claimants would suffer the type of harm they sustained.' (Paragraph 1207)

cases.name: ICI Ltd v Shatwell [1965] AC 656
cases.summary:
Facts
• In ICI Ltd v Shatwell [1965] AC 656, the two brothers, George and Frederick Shatwell, were employed as shotfirers in a quarry owned by the appellant, ICI Ltd (Imperial Chemical Industries Ltd).
• The brothers were responsible for triggering explosives, and despite being aware of the statutory safety precautions that required a one-hour interval between charged hole wiring and firing, they proceeded to carry out the firing after only ten minutes.
• An explosion occurred, resulting in Frederick suffering severe injuries.
• ICI Ltd faced legal proceedings under the Regulations for Safety, Health and Welfare in Quarries.

Issues
• The issue raised was whether the defence of volenti non fit injuria - 'to one who has consented, no injury is done' - could be available to the defendant (ICI Ltd) in a case of negligence.
• The appellant argued that volenti non fit injuria should be applied, as Frederick Shatwell willingly participated in the negligent act.
• The respondent (Frederick Shatwell) contended that volenti non fit injuria should not be applicable in this case, as ICI Ltd had a duty to enforce the statutory safety precautions.

Decision
• The House of Lords held in favour of the appellant, ICI Ltd, and concluded that volenti non fit injuria does in fact apply in this case.
• It was held that Frederick Shatwell voluntarily and willingly participated in the negligent act, fully knowing of the risks involved.
• Consequently, ICI Ltd was not found liable in negligence as it successfully relied on the defence of volenti non fit injuria.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is submitted by the respondents…that the maxim volenti non fit injuria has no application in the case of a master and servant, but their Lordships are unable to agree. There seems no reason why the maxim should not be applicable where it is clearly established that there has been a perfectly voluntary acceptance of a known risk by a servant of a master.' (Lord Morris of Borth-y-Gest)

cases.name: Chester v Afshar [2005] 1 AC 345
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Chester, sought damages for the failure of the respondent, Dr. Afshar, to explain the risks of a proposed lumbar discectomy, which resulted in her sustaining cauda equina syndrome.
• Dr. Afshar had failed to inform Chester of the 1%-2% chance of this complication occurring.

Issues
• The appellant argued that Dr. Afshar's duty was to obtain informed consent by disclosing the risk of injury, and the failure to do so caused her injury.
• Dr. Afshar contended that even if he had informed Chester, she would have proceeded with the surgery, albeit at a different time, and the same injury could have occurred.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Dr. Afshar was liable for Chester's injury, as he breached his duty of care in not informing her of the potential risk.
• The usual 'but-for' test of causation was not strictly applied, as the House of Lords reasoned that the duty to inform patients is a valuable one, and emphasising policy considerations over the causation test.
• The five law lords were unanimous in deciding that Dr. Afshar was liable, but there was no majority opinion on the precise reasoning.

Key passage(s)
• 'The critical point in a case such as the present is whether there has been a breach of [the doctor's] duty of care which has a sufficient causal connection with the injury which the patient has in fact sustained as a result of the treatment which the doctor has administered.': Lord Steyn
• 'The function of the law is to enable rights to be vindicated and to provide remedies when duties have been breached. If one asks in this case what has gone wrong, the answer is [the doctor's] failure to warn the appellant.': Lord Hope

cases.name: West Bromwich Albion Football Club Ltd v El-Safty [2006] EWCA Civ 1299
cases.summary:
Facts
• West Bromwich Albion Football Club Ltd (the Club) brought a claim against Mr. El-Safty, a consultant orthopaedic surgeon, alleging professional negligence in relation to surgery performed on their football player.
• The player underwent ankle surgery and later developed complications, causing the Club financial losses and harming the player's career.
• The Club asserted that Mr. El-Safty, who had a contract with them to perform the surgery, owed them a duty of care in tort and that he breached that duty by negligently performing the surgery.

Issues
• The key issue in the case was whether Mr. El-Safty owed a duty of care to the Club as well as to the player.
• The Club argued that Mr. El-Safty owed them a duty of care because of their contractual relationship and the foreseeability of the harm suffered.
• Mr. El-Safty argued that he owed a duty of care only to the player, as the direct recipient of the medical treatment.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that Mr. El-Safty did not owe a duty of care to the Club.
• The court found that the primary responsibility of Mr. El-Safty was to his patient, the player, and that extending a duty of care to the Club would impose conflicting duties upon the surgeon.
• The court also held that the contractual relationship between the parties did not automatically give rise to a tortious duty of care.

Key passage(s)
• 'It would involve a potential conflict of duties owed by the surgeon to his patient and to the third party. It would not be fair, just and reasonable to impose such a potentially conflicting duty on the surgeon.' (Lord Justice Mummery)

cases.name: Hollywood Silver Fox Farm v Emmett [1936] 2 KB 468
cases.summary:
Facts
• In this case, a defendant (Mr. Emmett) built a facility nearby the Hollywood Silver Fox Farm, which was breeding valuable silver foxes for fur.
• Mr. Emmett then deliberately fired loud guns on the nearby land, intending to startle the foxes so that they would miscarry their young, rendering them less able to produce valuable fur.
• The plaintiff, Hollywood Silver Fox Farm, sued Mr. Emmett for causing private nuisance and claimed damages.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether Mr. Emmett's conduct could establish private nuisance, even if the act of creating a nuisance did not interfere with the use or enjoyment of another's land.
• The plaintiff argued that Mr. Emmett's intentional creation of a noise to disrupt their business operations amounted to a private nuisance.
• The defendant argued that he had not interfered with the use or enjoyment of the plaintiff's land, and as such, the claim in nuisance should fail.

Decision
• The court held that the defendant's conduct amounted to private nuisance.
• The court found that the defendant's intentional act of creating noise with the purpose of damaging the plaintiff's business was sufficient to establish the tort of nuisance.
• The court awarded damages to the plaintiff for the loss of fur production as a result of the defendant's actions.

Key passage(s)
• 'I think what the plaintiff is really complaining of is not a nuisance to land; he is complaining of an interference with the carrying on of his trade upon it.' (Greer LJ)

cases.name: Sedleigh-Denfield v O'Callaghan [1940] AC 880
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Sedleigh-Denfield v O'Callaghan [1940] AC 880, a trespasser had installed a poorly constructed pipe on the defendant's land which caused flooding.
• The defendant, although aware of the trespasser's actions, took no steps to remove or remedy the pipe.
• The plaintiff was a nearby landowner who suffered damage to his property as a result of the flooding.
• The plaintiff sued the defendant in tort for private nuisance, claiming that he had a duty of care to prevent the flooding.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the defendant could be held liable in tort for the flooding caused by the trespasser's acts despite not being the person responsible for installing the pipe.
• The plaintiff argued that the defendant had a duty of care to prevent the flooding since he was aware of the pipe and the potential harm it could cause.
• The defendant contended that he had no liability as he had not installed the pipe or committed any act of trespass or nuisance himself.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the defendant was liable in tort for the flooding caused by the trespasser's acts.
• The Court found that although the defendant did not commit the original act of trespass, he had continued the nuisance by failing to take reasonable steps to abate the hazard after becoming aware of the risk of harm.
• The duty of care imposed on the defendant extended to ensuring that his land did not cause harm to others as a result of allowing the nuisance to continue.

Key passage(s)
• 'The general rule is that an occupier is liable in respect of a nuisance created by somebody else on his premises, if he has the right of entry to abate the nuisance, if he has the right to obtain possession, and, above all, if he knew or ought to have known of the existence of the nuisance.' (Viscount Maugham)

cases.name: Network Rail v Morris [2004] EWCA Civ 172
cases.summary:
Facts
• In this case, Mr. Stephen Morris, the claimant, operated a recording studio near the defendant's railway line, Network Rail.
• Following the track's upgrade, noise and vibration from passing trains disrupted the studio's activities.
• In order to mitigate the issue, Network Rail agreed to build an acoustic fence between the railway and the claimant's property.
• However, the claimant alleged that the fence was ineffective in reducing noise and vibration, and initiated a lawsuit for nuisance.

Issues
• The primary issue was whether Network Rail had caused a nuisance by exposing the claimant’s property to the noise and vibration.
• The claimant argued that the defendant had failed to take reasonable steps to reduce the disturbance once they were aware of it.
• Network Rail contended that they were not responsible for the nuisance, as they were only obliged to maintain the railway and had no duty to rectify the noise disturbance.

Decision
• The case reached the Court of Appeal, which held that Network Rail was not liable for the noise and vibration as they had not caused the nuisance.
• The court found that the vibrations and noise were an inevitable consequence of the lawful use of the railway and, as such, Network Rail was not at fault.
• The claimant's case was dismissed.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is important to make a distinction between operating a railway and causing a nuisance. Operating the railway by itself does not cause a nuisance; it is the noise and disturbance that cause a nuisance' (Sir Anthony Clarke).
• 'The test of liability for statutory undertakers is to be found in negligent operation: did Network Rail do all that was reasonable, bearing in mind the extent of their statutory duties?' (Sir Anthony Clarke).

cases.name: Gorris v Scott (1874) LR 9 Ex 125
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Gorris v Scott (1874) LR 9 Ex 125, the defendant had contracted with the plaintiff to ship his sheep on his vessel.
• The defendant failed to comply with the Contagious Diseases (Animals) Act 1860, which required a certain type of partition to be used to separate the animals when being transported by sea.
• The ship was caught in a storm, causing the sheep to be swept overboard and lost.

Issues
