cases.name: Allcard v Skinner (1887) 36 Ch D 145
cases.summary:
Facts
• Miss Allcard, a devout young woman, joined the Society of the Sisters of the Poor, which was run by Mrs. Skinner.
• Upon joining, Miss Allcard transferred her property to Mrs. Skinner as a gift, influenced by her religious vows, faith, and love for the sisterhood.
• She later left the sisterhood and filed a suit for the restitution of her property, claiming undue influence by Mrs. Skinner.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the gift was voidable due to undue influence by Mrs. Skinner.
• Miss Allcard argued that she had been subjected to undue influence by Mrs. Skinner, despite no actual fraud or coercion occurring.
• Mrs. Skinner argued that the transaction was a result of Miss Allcard's own free will and accord, thus not meriting any claims of undue influence.

Decision
• The Court held that the gift was voidable due to undue influence, but Miss Allcard was not entitled to restitution because she had affirmed the transaction while knowing her right to rescind it.
• The Court emphasized that undue influence exists where a person is in a position of power over another, such as a religious leader over their followers, and the transaction is unfair.
• Despite finding undue influence, the Court declined to set aside the transaction because Miss Allcard had waited too long to seek relief (laches) and had affirmed the transaction after discovering her right to rescind it.

Key passage(s)
• 'The Court ought to be satisfied either that the advantage has not been unduly obtained, or that the disadvantage has not been unduly suffered.' - Lord Justice Lindley.

cases.name: Taylor v. Caldwell (1863) 3 B. & S. 826
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Taylor v. Caldwell, the plaintiffs entered into a contract with the defendants to rent Surrey Gardens and the Music Hall for four concerts and daytime fetes.
• The parties agreed upon a fixed rent, but before the first concert, the Music Hall was destroyed by fire. Both parties were unaware of and had not contemplated this possibility.
• As no express provision regarding this situation was made in their contract, the plaintiffs sued the defendants for breach of contract.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the destruction of the Music Hall frustrated the contract, thereby excusing the parties from performance.
• The plaintiffs argued that they should be awarded damages for breach of contract, while the defendants contended that the contract had been frustrated by the fire and that no damages were due.

Decision
• The court held that the contract was frustrated due to the unforeseen destruction of the Music Hall, which rendered performance impossible.
• It was determined that the contract's object was not merely to rent the hall, but rather to provide the particular place for the specific purpose of holding concerts and fetes.
• Consequently, the destruction of the hall frustrated the contract, discharging both parties from their obligations without liability for breach.

Key passage(s)
• 'The principle seems to us to be that, in contracts in which the performance depends on the continued existence of a given person or thing, a condition is implied that the impossibility of performance arising from the perishing of the person or thing shall excuse the performance.' (Blackburn J.)

cases.name: Krell v. Henry (1903) 2 KB 740
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Krell v. Henry (1903) 2 KB 740, the plaintiff (Krell) had rented out a room to the defendant (Henry) for the purpose of viewing the coronation procession of King Edward VII.
• The coronation was subsequently postponed due to the King's illness, and Henry refused to pay the balance of the rent for the room.
• Krell sued to recover the amount, and Henry counterclaimed for the return of his deposit.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the contract had been frustrated by the unforeseen event of the coronation's postponement, thus discharging the parties from their respective obligations.
• Krell argued that the contract was still valid, though the purpose of the contract had failed and it should be enforceable.
• Henry argued that the contract had been frustrated, as the specific purpose for which the room was rented no longer existed.

Decision
• The court held in favor of Henry, finding that the contract had been frustrated.
• It was ruled that the postponement of the coronation was an unforeseen event that rendered the contract's purpose impossible to achieve, thus discharging the parties' obligations.
• As a result, Henry was not required to pay the balance of the rent, and Krell was not required to return the deposit.

Key passage(s)
• 'It seems to me that the substance of the agreement was that the room was taken for a particular thing, and if that particular thing goes, it is not the thing described in the contract which the defendants got.' (Vaughan Williams LJ)
• 'If, during the currency of the contract, owing to an event which cannot be controlled by either party, the object of the contract becomes impossible, the contract is discharged.' (Kennedy J)

cases.name: Benedetti v Sawiris [2013] UKSC 50
cases.summary:
Facts
• Benedetti (the claimant), an advisor to Sawiris (the defendant), was seeking remuneration for his services based on a quantum meruit (reasonable sum) argument.
• Benedetti claimed that he had spent substantial time and effort helping Sawiris in the acquisition of a company, Wind Telecom Spa, and thus was entitled to remuneration beyond the agreed terms of their contract.
• Sawiris argued that Benedetti had been paid the agreed contractual rate and was therefore not additionally entitled to a quantum meruit claim.

Issues
• The primary issue concerned whether Benedetti could seek remuneration for his services on a quantum meruit basis beyond their contractual agreement.
• Benedetti argued that due to his expertise, efforts, and contributions, Sawiris was unjustly enriched, and he was entitled to a reasonable sum for his services.
• Sawiris contended that Benedetti had been fully compensated according to their contract, and additional remuneration was unwarranted.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Benedetti's appeal, holding that the contractual terms covered the services rendered and Sawiris had not been unjustly enriched.
• The Court ruled that when determining the measure of restitution (i.e., the reasonable sum) for a quantum meruit claim, the defendant's subjective benefit – or whether Sawiris placed subjective value on Benedetti's services – was not relevant.
• Instead, the court should objectively assess the value of the services rendered, such as market rates or providing a reasonable charge.

Key passage(s)
• '...any claim to payment for services rendered will necessarily be based on the value of the services rendered rather than on the subjective benefit obtained by the defendant.' (Lord Clarke)

cases.name: Beswick v Beswick [1968] AC 58
cases.summary:
Facts
• Beswick v Beswick [1968] AC 58 is a landmark English contract law case that concerns the nature of privity and the ability of third parties to enforce contractual rights.
• Mr. Beswick, an elderly coal merchant, transferred his business to his nephew, Peter, in return for both a lump sum payment and an annuity to be paid to his wife upon his death.
• When Mr. Beswick died, Peter paid the lump sum but refused to pay the annuity.
• Mrs. Beswick (the widow) sued Peter in two capacities: as the deceased's personal representative, and also as a third party beneficiary of the contract.

Issues
• The main issue in dispute was whether Mrs. Beswick could enforce her rights as a third party to the contract even though there was no consideration moving from her under the contract.
• Peter argued that since Mrs. Beswick was not a party to the contract, she lacked standing to enforce it.
• Mrs. Beswick argued that as the personal representative of her late husband, she should be able to enforce the contract on his behalf.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Mrs. Beswick was entitled to enforce the contract, as the personal representative of her late husband.
• However, the court ruled against her claim to enforce the contract as a third party beneficiary based on the principle of privity prohibiting a non-party from enforcing a contract.

Key passage(s)
• 'As the law stands at present, in the ordinary way a person who is not a party to the original contract cannot sue for damages for breach of contract: but a person who is a party to the covenant to assign and who has performed his part of the bargain is entitled to some remedy.' (Lord Reid)

cases.name: Derry v Peek (1889) 14 App Cas 337
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Derry v Peek, a company (Plymouth, Devonport, and Stonehouse Tramways Company) formed to run tramways in Plymouth received a license to use steam as the mode of propulsion instead of horses.
• However, the license was later revoked by the Board of Trade.
• Prior to the revocation, the company issued a prospectus inviting people to purchase shares, which falsely declared that the company had the right to use steam instead of horses.
• Peek, a purchaser of the shares, brought an action against the directors of the company for fraudulent misrepresentation, claiming to have suffered a loss due to the false statement in the prospectus.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the company's directors were guilty of fraudulent misrepresentation or merely negligent misrepresentation.
• Peek argued that the directors knowingly made a false statement, thereby committing fraud, whereas the directors asserted that they did not know of the statement's falsity and thus were at most guilty of innocent misrepresentation.

Decision
• The House of Lords ultimately held that the directors' actions amounted to innocent misrepresentation as there was no evidence demonstrating that they intended to deceive the plaintiff.
• It was established that fraud requires proof of a false representation made knowingly, without belief in its truth, or recklessly, careless as to whether it is true or false.
• Since the directors did not act with intent to deceive, they were not guilty of fraudulent misrepresentation.

Key passage(s)
• 'Fraud is proved when it is shown that a false representation has been made (1) knowingly, or (2) without belief in its truth, or (3) recklessly, careless whether it be true or false.' (Lord Herschell)

cases.name: Hirachand Punamchand v Temple [1911] 2 KB 330
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Hirachand Punamchand v Temple [1911] 2 KB 330, the plaintiff, Hirachand Punamchand, was a moneylender.
• The defendant, Temple, was a customer of the plaintiff's.
• The defendant owed the plaintiff a debt.
• The parties entered into a new contract where the defendant promised to pay the plaintiff a sum of money in exchange for the plaintiff forbearing to sue for a certain period of time.
• The plaintiff had already decided not to sue the defendant before the contract was made, but the defendant was not aware of this intention.

Issues
• The issue was whether there was sufficient consideration for the defendant's promise to pay the plaintiff under the new contract.
• The plaintiff argued there was consideration as they agreed to forbear suing the defendant for a certain period in exchange for the defendant's payment.
• The defendant argued that there was no consideration as the plaintiff had already decided not to sue the defendant before the contract was made, and thus, there was no legal detriment suffered by the plaintiff that could amount to consideration.

Decision
• The court held there was sufficient consideration for the defendant's promise to pay the plaintiff under the new contract.
• The court reasoned that the plaintiff's agreement to forbear indefinitely constituted a legal detriment which provided value to the defendant and thus amounted to valid consideration for the defendant's promise to pay.
• The court also established that the defendant's lack of knowledge of the plaintiff's pre-existing intention not to sue was irrelevant.

Key passage(s)
• 'The forbearance of the [plaintiff] to sue, to be of any value, must be a forbearance with the knowledge of all the material facts...' (Darling J.)
• 'The forbearance by a creditor to sue his debtor is a good consideration for a fresh promise by the debtor to pay the debt...' (Kennedy J.)

cases.name: Hyde v Wrench (1840) 3 Beav 334
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Hyde v Wrench (1840) 3 Beav 334, the defendant, Wrench, offered to sell his farm to the plaintiff, Hyde, for £1,000.
• Hyde replied, proposing to purchase the farm for £950 instead.
• Wrench rejected Hyde's counter-offer.
• Later, Hyde decided to accept Wrench's initial offer of £1,000, but Wrench refused to sell.

Issues
• The plaintiff argued that there was a binding contract formed when he accepted the defendant's initial offer of £1,000.
• The defendant contended that the plaintiff's counter-offer of £950 amounted to a rejection of the original offer, thus terminating it and leaving nothing to be accepted.

Decision
• The court held in favour of the defendant, finding that the plaintiff's counter-offer had indeed amounted to a rejection and termination of the original offer.
• The court also found that when the plaintiff tried to accept the original offer, it had already been terminated by his prior counter-offer and could not be resurrected.
• This case established the rule that a counter-offer amounts to a rejection of the original offer and terminates it. This is known as the 'counter-offer rule'.

Key passage(s)
• '...when Mr. Hyde offered to buy the property for a smaller sum...he rejected that offer by which it was put an end to, and he could not afterwards revive it.' (Lord Langdale MR)

cases.name: Interfoto v Stiletto [1989] QB 433
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Interfoto Picture Library Ltd v Stiletto Visual Programmes Ltd [1989] QB 433, the claimant (Interfoto) was a picture library that supplied transparencies to the defendant (Stiletto) for commercial use.
• Stiletto requested a selection of transparencies from Interfoto, who delivered them along with a delivery note containing 17 terms and conditions.
• Among these terms was an unusually onerous one which provided that if the transparencies were not returned within 14 days, the customer had to pay £5 per transparency per day.
• Stiletto failed to return them in time, resulting in a sum of over £3,000 owed to Interfoto.

Issues
• The main issue at stake was whether or not the term relating to the fee for late return of transparencies had been effectively incorporated into the contract between Interfoto and Stiletto.
• Interfoto argued that the term had been properly incorporated because it was included in the delivery note that accompanied the transparencies.
• Stiletto, on the other hand, counter-argued that the term was not properly incorporated because it was not brought to their attention and it was not a term that would ordinarily be expected in such a contract.

Decision
• The court held that the term had not been effectively incorporated into the contract.
• The court emphasized the importance of giving reasonable notice of unusually onerous terms, citing the case of Thornton v Shoe Lane Parking Ltd [1971] 2 QB 163, in which the court held that an exclusion clause in a car park ticket had not been incorporated because there had been insufficient notice given to the customer.
• Since the term in question was not properly incorporated, Stiletto was not required to pay the amount claimed by Interfoto.

Key passage(s)
• 'Incorporation of such a term...requires reasonable notice: the customer must know the full extent of his liability.' (Bingham LJ)

cases.name: ParkingEye Ltd v Beavis [2015] UKSC 67
cases.summary:
Facts
• ParkingEye Ltd (ParkingEye) managed a car park at a retail park, where a two-hour free parking period applied.
• Mr. Beavis overstayed the free period by 56 minutes and received a parking charge notice of £85.
• Mr. Beavis challenged the charge, arguing it was an unenforceable penalty and an unfair term under the Unfair Terms in Consumer Contracts Regulations 1999 (UTCCRs).

Issues
• Mr. Beavis argued that the £85 charge was an unenforceable penalty, as it was disproportionately high compared to the loss suffered by ParkingEye (the penalty rule).
• Alternatively, Mr. Beavis argued that the charge was unfair under the UTCCRs.
• ParkingEye claimed that the charge was necessary for managing the car park and deterring overstays and that it was not an unenforceable penalty.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the £85 charge was not an unenforceable penalty.
• The court found ParkingEye had a legitimate interest in charging overstaying motorists which went beyond the recovery of any loss, such as managing the car park and deterring overstays.
• In assessing whether a charge is an unenforceable penalty, the court should consider whether the charge is out of all proportion to the innocent party's legitimate interest.
• The court also held that the charge was not unfair under the UTCCRs, as Mr. Beavis had adequate notice of the terms and the charge was neither extravagant nor unconscionable.

Key passage(s)
• '[The penalty rule] is an ancient, haphazardly constructed edifice which has not weathered well… it is time to re-examine the foundations' (Lord Neuberger and Lord Sumption).
• 'The test should be whether the sum stipulated as a consequence of a breach of contract is exorbitant or unconscionable when regard is had to the innocent party's interest in the performance of the contract' (Lord Neuberger and Lord Sumption).

cases.name: Prenn v Simmonds [1971] 1 WLR 1381
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Prenn v Simmonds [1971] 1 WLR 1381, the parties had entered into a deed for the sale of shares.
• The deed included a clause which granted the seller an 'annual payment' from the purchaser.
• The issue arose when both parties disagreed on the interpretation of the clause and as a result, the exact nature and purpose of the payment remained unclear.

Issues
• The main issue before the court was the interpretation of the deed and more specifically, the meaning behind the 'annual payment' clause.
• The claimant argued that the payment represented a share in future profits, while the defendant contended that it was a provision for the payment of a pension.

Decision
• The court held that extrinsic evidence of the parties' negotiations should not be considered when interpreting the deed and, therefore, the court should rely solely on the language used in the deed.
• The result of this approach was that the court could not determine the true intention of the parties, ultimately declaring the 'annual payment' clause to be void for uncertainty.
• The court's decision demonstrates the traditional approach to contractual interpretation, which has since evolved in subsequent cases like Investors Compensation Scheme v West Bromwich Building Society [1998] 1 WLR 896, where Lord Hoffmann introduced the modern approach to the interpretation of contracts.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is the words that are the best evidence of the intention of the parties' (Lord Wilberforce).
• 'What is not admissible, on principle and on authority, is evidence of the parties' declared but unexpressed intentions on the bona fide assumption that those intentions must be common to both parties and that the use of words will fit their meaning exactly.' (Lord Wilberforce).

cases.name: Rock v MWB Business Exchange Centres Ltd [2018] UKSC 24
cases.summary:
Facts
• MWB Business Exchange Centres Ltd (MWB) and Rock Advertising Ltd (Rock) entered into a contract (License) for serviced office space, containing a 'no oral modification' (NOM) clause that stated all variations to the contract must be in writing and signed by both parties.
• Rock fell into arrears, and an oral agreement was allegedly made between both parties to reschedule the payments. However, Rock's payments remained unpaid and MWB subsequently locked Rock out of the premises, serving notice of termination.
• Rock sued MWB for wrongful lock-out, arguing that an oral agreement had varied the License, whilst MWB claimed any oral agreement was invalid.

Issues
• The issue for the Supreme Court was whether an oral agreement purporting to vary the payment schedule could be effective, despite the existence of a NOM clause in the original contract.
• Rock argued, relying on recent case law such as World Online Telecom Ltd v I-Way Ltd [2002] EWCA Civ 413, that in the absence of an estoppel, an oral agreement could be effective, subject to contractual intention.
• MWB argued that the NOM clause was valid and must be enforced to ensure contractual certainty and prevent abuse.

Decision
• The Supreme Court, overruling the Court of Appeal, held that the NOM clause was legally effective, and an oral variation could not override it.
• The Court maintained that oral agreements were valid, except where expressly excluded by a valid NOM clause within the contract.

Key passage(s)
'Party autonomy operates up to the point when the contract is made, but thereafter only to the extent that the contract allows.' (Lord Sumption)
'No Oral Modification clauses are included in contracts for good commercial reasons, including minimising the risk of unreliable evidence of oral variations.' (Lord Briggs)

cases.name: Rose v Pim [1953] 2 QB 450
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case, Rose v Pim [1953] 2 QB 450, involves a contract for the sale of goods.
• The plaintiff (Pim) agreed to buy a quantity of potatoes from the defendant (Rose) under a written contract specifying the exact quantity (87.816 quarters) and type of potatoes to be delivered.
• The defendant delivered a larger quantity of potatoes (89.47 quarters).
• The plaintiff returned the wrong type of potatoes and claimed he had not accepted the contract as the goods were not in accordance with the contract.

Issues
• The primary issue in the case was whether the plaintiff's wrongful rejection amounted to an acceptance of the goods.
• The defendant argued that the plaintiff had accepted the goods because the plaintiff's wrongful rejection of the correct type of potatoes (i.e., the additional quantity) constituted acceptance.
• The plaintiff argued that he had not accepted the goods because they were not in accordance with the contract, and therefore, he was entitled to reject them.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held in favor of the defendant.
• The court ruled that the plaintiff's wrongful rejection of the correct type of potatoes constituted acceptance of the goods.
• Consequently, the plaintiff was held liable for the price of the goods.

Key passage(s)
• 'In my judgment, the conduct of the [plaintiff] on 24 and 25 September amounted to an acceptance of the potatoes so far as they differed from the contract, and that discharges the [defendant].' (Lord Denning)

cases.name: Scriven Bros v Hindley [1913] 3 KB 564
cases.summary:
Facts
• Scriven Bros and Co (plaintiff), instructed an auctioneer to sell bales of tow and hemp at an auction.
• The bales were packaged similarly and were not easily distinguishable.
• Hindley (defendant), believed they were bidding for two lots of hemp, but one of the lots was actually tow.
• Upon realizing the mistake, the defendant refused to pay for the tow lot, and the plaintiff sued for the price.

Issues
• The issue was whether there was a valid contract between the parties or whether it was void for mutual mistake as to the subject matter of the contract.
• The plaintiff argued that there was a contract and the defendant was obligated to pay for the tow.
• The defendant argued that there was no contract due to mutual mistake, as there was no consensus ad idem (meeting of the minds).

Decision
• The court held that there was no contract between the parties due to mutual mistake, resulting in a lack of consensus ad idem.
• The plaintiff had not made the hemp and tow samples sufficiently clear, whilst the defendant had not brought a catalogue to the auction or inspected the samples carefully before bidding.

Key passage(s)
• 'It seems to us that there was not any real consensus ad idem as to the subject matter of the alleged contract, which was entered into under mutual mistake.' (Atkin LJ)

cases.name: Sumpter v Hedges [1898] 1 QB 673
cases.summary:
Facts
• Sumpter, a builder, agreed to build two houses for Hedges.
• No formal contract was drawn up, only an oral agreement.
• Sumpter completed most of the work, but Hedges failed to provide the necessary materials for completion.
• Sumpter ceased work, and Hedges finished the work using another builder.
• Sumpter sued for payment on the basis of quantum meruit (payment for work done) for the work he had completed.

Issues
• Sumpter argued that he was entitled to payment on a quantum meruit basis, as there was no formal contract and he had completed the majority of the work.
• Hedges argued that the oral agreement did not create a contract and therefore Sumpter had no right to payment.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that there was no contract between the parties, as the agreement was not sufficiently certain or complete.
• However, the court allowed Sumpter to recover on a quantum meruit basis for the work he had completed, as Hedges had freely accepted it.
• The court also held that the doctrine of part performance (which allows for specific performance of a contract even if it was not fully executed) did not apply, as it requires a binding contract to exist.

Key passage(s)
• 'I think it is impossible to say that any contract to build was ever made, but I think it is quite clear that there was an agreement by the defendant to pay the plaintiff whatever the work was reasonably worth, and that is the basis on which the plaintiff is entitled to recover.' (Lord Justice A.L. Smith)

cases.name: Gray v Thames Trains Ltd [2009] 1 AC 1339
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimant, Gray, was involved in a train crash caused by Thames Trains Ltd's negligence where he suffered from severe post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
• Due to his PTSD, Gray killed a pedestrian in a separate incident and was incarcerated.
• Gray sued Thames Trains Ltd for the loss of earnings resulting from his imprisonment and the criminal act he committed under the influence of PTSD.

Issues
• The Court had to decide if Gray’s claim for loss of earnings due to imprisonment was recoverable in tort for Thames Trains Ltd’s negligence causing the PTSD.
• Gray argued that the 'narrow rule' in Clunis v Camden and Islington Health Authority [1998] QB 978 should apply, only barring recovery for direct consequences of the criminal conduct.
• Thames Trains Ltd argued for the application of the 'wide rule', barring recovery for loss of earnings resulting from imprisonment entirely due to public policy considerations and the illegality principle.

Decision
• The House of Lords rejected Gray's claim for lost earnings.
• The Court applied the 'wide rule' on the grounds of illegality and public policy, disallowing Gray’s claim for his loss of earnings during imprisonment.

Key passage(s)
• 'The public policy in question is that the law should be even-handed and should not enable a man to found a cause of action on his own criminal conduct or on a situation [...] to which his own criminal conduct has given rise.' (Lord Hoffmann)
• 'A person who has been sentenced to imprisonment [...] is precluded by reasons of public policy from claiming compensation for the time he was prevented from working by his imprisonment.' (Lord Scott)

cases.name: Clunis v Camden HA [1998] QB 978
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Claimant, who had a mental disorder, was detained in a hospital and then discharged.
• Who months later, the Claimant stabbed a stranger to death in an unprovoked attack and thereafter, pleaded guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility.
• He was sentenced to be detained in a hospital pursuant to section 37 of the Mental Health Act 1983 with an indefinite restriction order under section 41.
• The Claimant sued the Health Authority, alleging negligence in discharging him and not providing adequate aftercare and claimed damages for his loss of liberty.

Issues
• The Health Authority sought to strike out the action, arguing that even if it was negligent and had they not discharged the Claimant, he would not have committed manslaughter. Moreover, damages could not be recovered for the consequences of the Claimant's own unlawful act.
• The Claimant argued that the Health Authority's negligence led to his actions and subsequent loss of liberty.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal allowed the Defendant's appeal, striking out the Claimant's action.
• The Court held that public policy precluded the court from entertaining the Claimant's claim, as he had been convicted of a serious criminal offence and knew his actions were wrong.
• Although the Claimant's responsibility for the killing was diminished, his mental state did not justify a verdict of not guilty by reason of insanity.

Key passage(s)
• Beldam LJ: 'In the present case the plaintiff has been convicted of a serious criminal offence. In such a case public policy would in our judgment preclude the court from entertaining the plaintiff's claim unless it could be said that he did not know the nature and quality of his act or that what he was doing was wrong...The court ought not to allow itself to be made an instrument to enforce obligations alleged to arise out of the plaintiff's own criminal act and we would therefore allow the appeal on this ground.'

cases.name: Lister v Hesley Hall Ltd [2001] UKHL 22
cases.summary:
Facts
• Lister v Hesley Hall Ltd [2001] A.C. 215 involved tort claims of sexual abuse by an employee (the Warden, the Listers) against children residing in a boarding house operated by the Hesley Hall Ltd.
• The abuse occurred while the Warden was performing his duties, which required him to reside with and care for the children in the boarding house.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether Hesley Hall Ltd, as the employer, could be held vicariously liable for the wrongful acts of the Warden.
• The claimants argued that the employer should be held vicariously liable since the abuse occurred during the Warden's employment while performing his duties.
• On the other hand, the employer argued that it should not be held liable as the wrongful acts were not committed within the scope of the Warden's employment.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Hesley Hall Ltd was indeed vicariously liable for the Warden's wrongful acts.
• Their decision was based on the 'close connection' test, which states that if the wrongful acts are so closely connected to the employment that it would be fair and just to hold the employer liable, then vicarious liability can be imposed.
• In this case, they found that the Warden abused his position and authority as an employee of the boarding house, and this was sufficiently closely connected to his employment for the employer to be held liable.

Key passage(s)
• 'In light of these authorities and the policy considerations identified by Lord Steyn, in my view the question whether acts of sexual abuse were so closely connected with the employment that it would be fair and just to hold the employers vicariously liable for their employee's conduct cannot be answered by reference simply to the factors or tests I have mentioned. The question must be looked at more broadly.' (Lord Millett)

cases.name: Michael v Chief Constable of South Wales Police [2015] UKSC 2
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Michael v Chief Constable of South Wales Police [2015] UKSC 2, the claimant called the police after receiving a threat from her ex-partner.
• The police misclassified her call, resulting in a delayed response and her eventual death at the hands of her ex-partner.
• The claimant's estate brought a claim against the police alleging that their negligence caused her death.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the police owed a duty of care to individuals in the claimant's position.
• The claimant's estate argued that a duty of care arose because the police's negligence created a foreseeable risk of harm, and there was a sufficiently proximate relationship between the parties.
• The police argued that they did not owe a duty of care, as they are generally not liable for omissions in providing assistance, citing cases such as Hill v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire [1989] AC 53.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the police were not liable.
• It reasoned that the police do not owe a duty of care for their acts or omissions in the course of investigating or preventing crime save for certain exceptions, such as where they create a danger or assume responsibility for someone's safety.
• The court found no exceptional circumstances here that would give rise to a duty of care.

Key passage(s)
• '[T]he police, like anyone else, may be liable in tort for their positive acts which cause personal injury or death.' (Lord Toulson)
• 'In the generality of cases, however, a common law duty of care will not be owed by the police towards victims or potential victims of crime in relation to the conduct of their operations in the prevention, investigation and suppression of crime, unless the particular circumstances of the case fall within one of the established exceptions.' (Lord Toulson)

cases.name: James-Bowen v Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis [2018] UKSC 40
cases.summary:
Facts
• In James-Bowen v Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis, four Metropolitan Police officers were involved in an arrest and alleged assault of a terrorist suspect back in 2003. After the incident, the suspect sued the force, claiming damages for assault and negligence.
• The Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis settled the claim, paying out damages without any admission of liability. However, the four police officers brought a claim in tort against the Commissioner, arguing that he did not defend their innocence and seeking indemnification

Issues
• The question before the UK Supreme Court was whether the Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis owed a duty of care to its police officers in a potentially tortious act and whether he was obliged to indemnify them.
• The police officers argued that the Commissioner owed them a duty of care and should protect them from having to meet a third-party claim.
• On the other hand, the Commissioner contended that he did not and that such an obligation fell outside of the scope of an employer-employee relationship

Decision
• The Court held unanimously that the Commissioner did not owe a duty of care or indemnification to the four police officers against potential third-party claims.
• The Court noted that 'such a duty had not previously been identified and acknowledging it would raise significant public policy challenges.'
• The Court also cited the previous case of Friar v Newham London Borough Council [2011] EWCA Civ 281, where a duty of care to protect from pure economic loss was also rejected

Key passage(s)
• 'There is simply no basis for concluding that the Commissioner owed a duty to the officers not to cause, or to protect them from, pure economic loss caused by the wrongdoing of others.' (Lord Kerr)
• 'The undoubted responsibility of the Commissioner to manage litigation in which the police service is involved does not sound in a duty of care of the kind sought in this case.' (Lord Toulson)

cases.name: GN v Poole Borough Council [2019] UKSC 25
cases.summary:
Facts
• In GN v Poole Borough Council [2019] UKSC 25, the claimants (GN and CN) alleged that the defendant local authority (Poole Borough Council) failed in its duty to protect them from harassment and abuse by a neighboring family, resulting in physical harm and psychological trauma.
• GN and CN were young children and their family were receiving social services assistance from the local authority at the time. The claimants' family requested a transfer to a different housing location but were denied.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the local authority owed a duty of care to the claimants under the principles of tort and negligence.
• The claimants argued that the local authority's failure to protect them or relocate their family demonstrated negligence in their duty of care.
• The local authority argued that, as a public body exercising statutory discretion, it did not owe the claimants a duty of care.

Decision
• The Supreme Court dismissed the claimants' appeal, agreeing with the local authority that it did not owe the claimants a duty of care.
• The Court reasoned that imposing a duty of care on local authorities in such cases would lead to a risk of defensive practices and diversion of resources from their statutory functions.
• The Court relied on previous cases such as Mitchell v Glasgow City Council [2009] UKHL 11 and Michael v Chief Constable of South Wales [2015] UKSC 2 to reinforce that public authorities do not owe a general duty of care to protect individuals from harm caused by third parties.

cases.name: Smith v Eric S. Bush [1989] 3 WLR 790
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Smith v Eric S. Bush [1989] 3 WLR 790, the defendants were surveyors instructed by the plaintiffs' mortgage lender to value the plaintiffs' house.
• The plaintiffs purchased the house for £35,000 based on the defendants' valuation.
• It was later discovered that the house suffered from structural defects requiring extensive repair work, causing the property value to be worth much less.
• The plaintiffs sued the defendants for negligent misstatement, claiming that they breached their duty of care by providing a valuation that significantly overestimated the house's actual worth.

Issues
• The primary issue was whether the defendants owed a duty of care to the plaintiffs, resulting in liability for negligent misstatement.
• The defendants argued that no duty of care was owed because they were chosen by and acted solely for the mortgage lender, with no direct relationship with the plaintiffs.
• The plaintiffs argued that such a duty existed, as they relied on the valuation provided by the defendants when deciding to purchase the house.

Decision
• The court held in favour of the plaintiffs, finding that the defendants owed a duty of care to the plaintiffs.
• The court noted that surveyors providing valuations owe a duty of care to house buyers who reasonably rely on their advice. This was based on the test established in Hedley Byrne v Heller & Partners Ltd [1964] AC 465, that a duty of care arises when there is reliance on advice given in a situation where the adviser knows, or ought reasonably to know, that the recipient relies and intends to act on that advice.
• In this case, the defendants knew or ought to have known that their valuation would be relied upon by the plaintiffs in deciding whether to purchase.

Key passage(s)
• 'The lender may reasonably foresee that, if the [valuation] is prepared negligently, a borrower who relies upon it in entering into the transaction may suffer loss. The test of reasonable foreseeability...is in my view satisfied.' (Lord Templeman)

cases.name: Banca Nazionale del Lavoro SPA v Playboy Club London Ltd [2018] UKSC 43
cases.summary:
Facts
• Banca Nazionale del Lavoro (BNL) provided a reference to London Clubs Management Ltd, a subsidiary of Playboy Club London Ltd (Playboy).
• In reliance on this reference, Playboy allowed Hassan Bakarat to gamble on its premises and suffer losses.
• Later, it emerged that BNL had neither made proper inquiries about Bakarat's financial position nor confirmed his creditworthiness.
• Playboy sued BNL for negligence and claimed that the bank should be held accountable for its losses.

Issues
• Whether a tort of negligent misstatement could be established given that there was no direct relationship between BNL and Playboy.
• Playboy's argument: BNL breached a duty of care owed to it by providing a negligently-prepared letter of credit in favor of Bakarat.
• BNL's argument: BNL did not owe a duty of care to Playboy.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court dismissed Playboy's appeal.
• The Court confirmed that there must be 'reasonable foreseeability of harm' and a 'sufficient relationship of proximity' between the parties for a tort of negligent misstatement to be established.
• The Court held that BNL owed no duty of care to Playboy as the relationship between the two parties was not 'proximate' enough.

Key passage(s)
• 'It has long been established that a tort of negligent misstatement underlies a duty of care when giving a reference: Hedley Byrne v. Heller & Partners Ltd [1964] AC 465' (Lord Sumption).
• 'The critical question is whether it is just and reasonable to impose a duty of care' (Lord Sumption).
• 'In the present case, the reference was not provided to the claimant or anyone on its behalf and was not addressed to it. There was no direct relationship between the claimant and the defendant at all' (Lord Sumption).

cases.name: Fearn v Tate Gallery Board of Trustees [2020] EWCA Civ 104
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimants, owners of flats in a building overlooking Tate Modern's public terrace, sued the Tate Gallery Board of Trustees alleging a breach of privacy due to the museum's viewing platform.
• They claimed that the platform constituted an actionable nuisance and sought an injunction to restrict access to the platform.
• Their claim was dismissed in the High Court, and they appealed to the Court of Appeal.

Issues
• The claimants contended that the Tate's platform invasion of their privacy amounted to an actionable nuisance.
• The defendants, however, argued that the claimants had no reasonable expectation of privacy as the flats had floor-to-ceiling windows and were in close proximity to public spaces, nor does the tort of nuisance cover interference with one's privacy.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal upheld the High Court's decision.
• Lawton LJ opined that the tort of nuisance should not be extended to encompass an invasion of privacy, as it generally deals with land-related disputes.
• The court emphasized that a claim for privacy infringement should be based on Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) and not the tort of nuisance.
• The court also noted that to hold otherwise would create a new and independent tort of 'overlooking', and this was a matter for Parliament to decide.
• Accordingly, the claimants' appeal was dismissed.

Key passage
• 'The boundaries of accepted principles should not be expanded by analogy or the development of new categories of case. That task requires the evaluation of wider policy considerations which are a matter for the legislature.' - Lawton LJ

cases.name: Cox v Ministry of Justice [2016] UKSC 10
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Cox v Ministry of Justice [2016] UKSC 10, the claimant, Mrs. Cox, was a catering manager at a prison, working under the Ministry of Justice.
• During the course of her work, she sustained an injury when a sack of rice fell onto her, leading to her suffering a back injury.
• The sack was being carried by a prisoner who was working in the kitchen as part of a prison work program.

Issues
• The key legal issue in this case was whether the Ministry of Justice could be held vicariously liable for the tortious acts of the prisoner (negligence).
• The Ministry of Justice argued that there was no vicarious liability, as there was no employment relationship between them and the prisoner.
• On the other hand, Mrs. Cox argued that the prison context and relationship was sufficient to establish vicarious liability.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the Ministry of Justice was vicariously liable for the prisoner's negligence.
• In reaching this decision, the court applied the two-stage test for vicarious liability established in Catholic Child Welfare Society v Various Claimants [2012] UKSC 56 (CCWS):
1. Is there a relationship between the defendant (Ministry of Justice) and the tortfeasor (prisoner) that is capable of giving rise to vicarious liability?
2. Is there a sufficiently 'close connection' between the relationship and the tortious act?
• The court concluded that both elements were satisfied and therefore, the Ministry of Justice was vicariously liable.

Key passage
• 'Although the relationship between the Ministry of Justice and the prisoner who injured Mrs Cox was not one of employment in the ordinary sense, it was still a relationship that was sufficiently akin to that of employer and employee for the principle of vicarious liability to apply.' (Lord Reed)

cases.name: Wilkes v DePuy International Ltd [2016] EWHC 3096 (QB)
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Wilkes v DePuy International Ltd, the claimant, Keith Wilkes, sued DePuy International Ltd (DIL) for damages based on product liability and negligence in relation to a failed hip replacement.
• In 2007, Wilkes underwent a total hip replacement surgery during which he was fitted with the Pinnacle Ultamet Metal-on-Metal Acetabular Cup System (Ultamet) manufactured by DIL.
• In 2010, Wilkes experienced pain and other symptoms due to the presence of metal particles in his body, leading to the revision of his hip replacement in 2011.

Issues
• Whether DIL was in breach of the Consumer Protection Act 1987 (CPA) for supplying a defective Ultamet hip replacement system.
• Whether DIL was negligent in designing, manufacturing, and providing instructions and warnings in relation to the Ultamet system.
• DIL argued that the Ultamet system met the legal requirements and was not defective under the CPA, and that it was not negligent in its design, manufacturing, and provision of instructions and warnings.

Decision
• The court held that DIL was not in breach of the CPA because the Ultamet system was not considered a defective product.
• The court held that DIL was not negligent in designing, manufacturing, and providing instructions and warnings in relation to the Ultamet system.
• Therefore, Wilkes's claim was dismissed.

Key passage(s)
• 'I am not satisfied that, on the balance of probabilities, the claimant has shown that the Ultamet was a defective product under s.3(1) [of the CPA].' - (Andrews J)
• 'I am not satisfied that, on balance of probabilities, the claimant has proven that DIL was negligent in any of the ways alleged.' - (Andrews J)

cases.name: X v Bedfordshire CC etc [1995] 3 All ER 353
cases.summary:
Facts
• In X v Bedfordshire CC etc [1995] 3 All ER 353, several individuals who had been subject to child abuse sued their respective local authorities for negligence.
• The claimants alleged that the local authorities failed to take appropriate steps to protect them from harm while under the authorities' care, and the claimants had sustained harm as a result.

Issues
• The primary issue was whether the local authorities owed a duty of care in negligence.
• The claimants argued that they were owed a duty of care by the local authorities to prevent harm as they were under the authorities' care.
• The local authorities, on the other hand, argued that they did not owe a duty of care as they were acting as statutory bodies in performing their safeguarding functions.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the local authorities did not owe a duty of care to the claimants.
• The court reasoned that the imposition of a duty of care on local authorities in these circumstances would interfere with their statutory discretion in child protection matters.
• The court also took into consideration the potential for diversion of resources away from the provision of services if local authorities could be sued for negligence.

Key passage(s)
• 'A duty of care [in negligence] may readily be owed when no statutory duty exists, [...] but the imposition of a common law duty on public authorities in respect of the exercise of their statutory powers and duties inevitably [...] may influence and affect [their] performance.' (Lord Browne-Wilkinson)

cases.name: Owens v Brimmell [1977] QB 859
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Owens v Brimmell [1977] QB 859, the claimant, Owens, and defendant, Brimmell, went to several public houses together in which both consumed alcohol.
• Owens agreed to drive Brimmell to his home.
• While driving, Owens lost control of his car and collided with another vehicle, causing injuries to both parties.
• Both Owens and Brimmell were found to be intoxicated with amounts of alcohol in their blood above the legal limit.

Issues
• Owens brought a claim against Brimmell for damages in the tort of negligence.
• Brimmell argued that Owens was contributorily negligent and therefore should bear some responsibility for his own injuries.
• Owens rejected this argument and insisted that Brimmell's negligence was the sole cause of the accident and resulting injuries.

Decision
• The court held that both Owens and Brimmell were negligent.
• As a result, the damages awarded to Owens were reduced by 20% to reflect his contributory negligence.

Key passage(s)
• 'In my judgment, applying the rule in Jones v Livox Quarries Ltd [1952] 2 QB 608, 619, that a plaintiff cannot recover if he is guilty of contributory negligence which caused or materially contributed to some extent, the damage of which he complains, as distinct from the accident itself, the plaintiff should recover damages, but his damages should be reduced to the extent of 40 per cent on account of his contributory negligence.' (Lord Denning)

cases.name: Smith v Finch [2009] EWHC 53
cases.summary:
Facts
• In the case of Smith v Finch [2009] EWHC 53, the claimant, Mr. Smith, was involved in a motorcycle accident with the defendant, Mr. Finch.
• Mr. Smith was riding a motorcycle without wearing a helmet at the time of the accident, which occurred when the defendant pulled out of a side road and collided with the claimant's motorcycle.
• Mr. Smith suffered a head injury as a result of the accident and sought damages from the defendant.

Issues
• The main issues in the case were whether Mr. Finch was liable for the accident and whether Mr. Smith's failure to wear a helmet amounted to contributory negligence.
• The defendant argued that the claimant's failure to wear a helmet contributed to his injuries and therefore, reduced his entitlement to damages.
• The claimant, on the other hand, argued that his head injury would have occurred even if he had been wearing a helmet.

Decision
• The court held that the defendant was liable for the accident, as he had pulled out of a side road without ensuring it was safe to do so.
• However, the court also found that failure to wear a helmet amounted to contributory negligence when, on the facts of the case, the injuries would have been reduced by wearing a helmet.
• On the facts of this case, this could not be proven and thus there was no contributory negligence.

cases.name: Jones v Livox Quarries [1952] 2 QB 608
cases.summary:
Facts
• The claimant (C) worked in the defendant's (D) quarry.
• C breached company rules by hitching a ride on the tow bar of a traxcavator. The traxcavator driver was unaware of C's actions.
• A dumper truck, driven recklessly by another employee, collided with the traxcavator, causing severe injuries to C's legs which were later amputated.
• C sued D for negligence.

Issues
• C argued that D was liable for the injuries due to the reckless action of the dumper truck driver.
• D argued that C's contributory negligence, by breaching the company rules and exposing himself to danger, should reduce or eliminate their liability.

Decision
• The Court of Appeal held that D was liable, but C was 20% to blame under the Law Reform (Contributory Negligence) Act 1945.
• The court found that C acted against orders and exposed himself to danger, which contributed to his injuries.

Key passage(s)
• 'A person is guilty of contributory negligence if he ought reasonably to have foreseen that, if he did not act as a reasonable, prudent man, he might be hurt himself: and in his reckonings he must take into account the possibility of others being careless.' (Denning LJ)

cases.name: Jackson v Murray [2015] UKSC 5
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Jackson v Murray [2015] UKSC 5, the claimant, a 13-year-old child, was seriously injured in a road accident.
• The claimant had alighted from a bus and was crossing the road in front of the bus, and was hit by a car driven by the defendant.
• At the trial, it was accepted that the child's own negligence contributed to the accident - the child was racing with another child across the road without checking if it was safe.
• The trial judge assessed the damages at 90%. On appeal, this was reduced to 70%.

Issues
• The main issue was the apportionment of liability between the claimant and the defendant. The defendant argued that the trial judge had not applied the correct approach to apportionment because the claimant's greater contributory negligence should have resulted in a higher percentage of liability.
• The claimant argued that the trial judge correctly balanced the respective blameworthiness of both parties and the causative potency of their conduct.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the trial judge had applied the correct approach to apportionment but had nevertheless assessed the claimant's share of responsibility too high.
• The Court applied the test in Stapley v Gypsum Mines Ltd [1953] AC 663: the factors relevant to apportionment were those those affecting the parties' responsibility for the damage, i.e. their blameworthiness and the causative potency of their conduct.
• The Court reduced the damages to 50%.

Key passage(s)
• 'Where a person is responsible for creating a source of danger, it does not lie in his mouth to say that the other person was more careless because he did not perceive that danger quickly enough' (Lord Reed).
• '[T]he judge must weigh two factors: the respective blameworthiness of each party and the causative potency of their respective acts and omissions' (Lord Reed).
